questions.text: A 40-year-old alcoholic presented to the emergency department due to recurrent nosebleeds. He has a history of alcohol abuse and chronic mental illness. A more detailed check-up reveals that his gums are swollen, purple, and spongy. Physical examination revealed multiple splinter hemorrhages near the distal ends of the nail on patient’s fingers and also wound healing is not proper in this patient.Which of the following is the most probable cause of patient's examination findings?
questions.solution:
Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy)is very commonly reported in severely malnourished individuals (e.g. homeless, alcohol or drug abusers) in the United States. Vitamin C deficiency leads todefective post-translational modification of collagenresulting in loss of tensile strength of blood vessels leading to:

  • Bleeding gums
  • Ecchymoses
  • Easy bruisability
  • Poor wound healing
  • hyperkeratotic follicleswith corkscrew hairs.

Vitamin C is necessary for thehydroxylation of proline and lysineresidues in collagen synthesis. This reaction is catalyzed by prolyl and lysyl hydroxylases, with vitamin C serving as a reducing agent (see fig).

Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine are essential for cross-linking of collagen molecules. In scurvy, collagen cross-linking is diminished hence greatly reducing its tensile strength.

questions.text: Corneal verticillata is characterized by corneal deposits at the level of the basal epithelium forming a faint golden-brown whorl pattern. All of the below are causative factors for this condition except?
questions.solution:
Option D: Tay Sach's disease

  • Cornea verticillata is not associated with Tay Sachs disease.

Cornea verticillata

  • Corneal verticillata, vortex keratopathy, has a whorl-like pattern of golden brown or grey deposits in the cornea.
  • It is unusual for these deposits to result in the reduction of visual acuity or ocular symptoms.
  • The deposits typically resolve with the discontinuation of the responsible agents.
  • Tay-Sachs disease is a rare genetic disorder passed from parents to children. It is caused by the absence of an enzyme that helps break down fatty substances. These fatty substances, called gangliosides, build up toxic levels in the brain and spinal cord and affect the function of the nerve cells.
  • Causes of Cornea Verticillata
    • Indomethacin
    • Chloroquine
    • Fabry disease
    • Amiodarone
    • Phenothiazine
    • Hydroxychloroquine
    • Phenothiazines
    • Atovaquone

Option A: Indomethacin

  • Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to treat mild to moderate acute pain and relieve symptoms of arthritis (osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis) or gouts, such as inflammation, swelling, stiffness, and joint pain.
  • Cornea verticillata is most associated with amiodarone and Fabry disease. 

​​​​​​​Option B: Chloroquine

  • Chloroquine is a medication primarily used to prevent and treat malaria in areas where malaria remains sensitive to its effects. Certain types of malaria, resistant strains, and complicated cases typically require different or additional medication.
  • Antimalarials. The aminoquinolones chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine have been widely used in treating SLE. These drugs can cause a reversible, visually insignificant keratopathy (cornea verticillata) and, more importantly, an irreversible sight-threatening maculopathy.

Option C: Fabry disease

  • Fabry disease is a rare inherited disorder of glycosphingolipid (fat) metabolism resulting from the absent or markedly deficient activity of the lysosomal enzyme, α-galactosidase A (α-Gal A). This disorder belongs to a group of diseases known as lysosomal storage disorders.
  • Fabry disease is caused by variants (also known as mutations) in the GLA gene. This gene provides instructions for making an enzyme called alpha-galactosidase A.
  • This enzyme is active in lysosomes, which are structures that serve as recycling centres within cells.
  • Corneal disease: The classic and most common presentation of the corneal disease involves the presence of cornea verticillata. Verticillata can be observed stemming from the central cornea as opacified, snaking lines.
  • Verticillata presents early and is seen in up to 70% of patients with Fabry disease.

questions.text: There are only three stages of glaucoma classification: early, moderate, and severe. Which of the following is not a system for classifying the angles of the anterior chamber?
questions.solution:
Option D: Sun Classification

  • Shaffer, Scheie and Spaeth all three are used for grading the angle of the anterior chamber.
  • These classifications are based on gonioscopic findings.
  • Sun classification is for grading of cells and flare in uveitis and not for the angle of the anterior chamber.
  • The SUN criteria provide a grading system for intraocular inflammation which takes into account the anterior chamber (AC) cells, AC flare, vitreous cells and vitreous haze or debris.
  • This grading system can monitor the disease course and the patient's response to therapy.

Option A: Spaeth

  • Shaffer, Scheie and Spaeth are all used for grading the angle of the anterior chamber.

Option B: Scheie grading

  • Shaffer, Scheie and Spaeth are all used for grading the angle of the anterior chamber.
  • Scheie (1957) developed a grading system in which Roman numerals were used to describe the degree of angle closure.
  • In his system, one determines the angle structures visible on the gonioscopy. Larger numbers signify a narrower angle. The term “wide” was used to describe an angle at which all structures were visible.

Option C: Shaffer classification

  • The Shaffer system records the angle in degrees between two imaginary lines tangential to the inner surface of the trabecula and the anterior surface of the iris about one-third of the distance from its periphery. The system assigns a numerical grade to each quadrant of the angle.
    • Grade 4 (35–45°) is the widest angle, characteristic of myopia and pseudophakia. The ciliary body can be visualised without tilting the lens.
    • Grade 3 (25–35°) is an open angle in which the scleral spur is visible.
    • Grade 2 (20°) is an angle where the trabeculae can be seen but not the scleral spur.
    • Grade 1 (10°) is a very narrow-angle in which only the Schwalbe line and perhaps the top of the trabecula can be identified. Slit angle is one in which there is no obvious iridocorneal contact, but no angle structures can be identified.
    • Grade 0 (0°) is closed due to iridocorneal contact.
    • The indentation will distinguish appositional from synechiae angle closure.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true in regards to type 1 diabetes?

choices.text: Children with T1DM should be screened for autoimmune thyroiditis and celiac disease.
Depression is more prevalent in children and adolescents with diabetes than those without diabetes.
Adolescents with diabetes generally have higher systolic BP (SBP) and diastolic BP (DBP) than healthy adolescents.
Screening for retinopathy is not needed in adolescents with diabetes.

questions.solution:
To screen for retinopathy, we recommend a dilated ophthalmologic examination for children ≥11 years of age (or at onset of puberty if earlier) if the youth has had diabetes for three to five years, consistent with recommendations from the ADA. This examination generally should be repeated every two years; less frequent examinations may be acceptable if recommended by the child's eye care professional based on risk factor assessment, including an A1C of <8 percent. Note that a funduscopic examination without dilation of the pupils is not sufficient to screen for diabetic retinopathy.

Screening is mandated in order to detect early retinal changes, which may be reversible. Screening also identifies patients with more advanced disease that may be amenable to laser therapy, which, if applied in a timely manner, may prevent further progression of disease and vision loss.

To screen for retinopathy, we recommend a dilated ophthalmologic examination for children ≥11 years of age (or at onset of puberty if earlier) if the youth has had diabetes for three to five years, consistent with recommendations from the ADA.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the ER with complaints of double vision, difficulty in speaking, and struggle for balance while walking. She has a history of seizure disorder for the last 10 years and is on Antiepileptic drugs. She also has Bipolar affective disorder, with a history of mixed affective episodes 1 month back, for which Lamotrigine was initiated as a mood stabilizer on an outpatient basis. Which of the following drug interactions is the most likely cause of the patient’s presenting symptoms?
questions.solution:
? The patient in the above case scenario has signs of Lamotrigine toxicity. ? Valproate is a potent enzyme inhibitor. It also decreases Lamotrigine clearance by reduced glucuronidation. It can thus increase the levels of lamotrigine in the blood causing life-threatening rash, incoordination, drowsiness, blurred vision, diplopia. When given concomitantly, doses of Lamotrigine are reduced by 50% followed by slower titration. Continuous monitoring of serum lamotrigine levels is ideal.

Option A: Carbamazepine-Lamotrigine = Carbamazepine is an enzyme inducer, therefore when combined with lamotrigine, the dosage of the latter needs to be increased by 30-50%.

Option C: Phenytoin-Lamotrigine = Phenytoin increased lamotrigine clearance, thus less likely to cause signs of toxicity. The dose of lamotrigine needs to be increased when used in combination with phenytoin.

Option D: Oxcarbazepine - It increases Lamotrigine clearance slightly.

questions.text: Eczema is a common skin condition with multiple clinical patterns, characterized histologically by a spongiotic tissue reaction pattern. This histopathological finding k/a spongiosis is characterized by?
questions.solution:
• Spongiosis: Intercellular accumulation of fluid in stratum spinosum characterized by widening of intercellular spaces. Eg: Acute eczema

• Ballooning: intracellular accumulation of fluid marked by swelling and pallor. Eg: Herpesvirus infection

• Acanthosis: thickening of stratum spinosum. Eg: Chronic eczema

• Acantholysis: Loss of cohesion between cells due to breakdown of intercellular bridges. Eg - Pemphigus vulgaris.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the ER with complaints of irrelevant and increased talk, high-grade fever. Symptoms started 5 days after he was admitted to a hospital for alcohol-related withdrawal. His brother shows a prescription of Injection Haloperidol which was given to him during his inpatient stay. On examination, the patient has profuse sweating, a temperature of 102.8 F, and marked rigidity in bilateral outstretched hands. His blood pressure is 90/70mm Hg, PR is 110/minute. Which is the most appropriate step of management in the case?
questions.solution:
The patient in the above scenario has Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS), a life-threatening idiosyncratic reaction that occurs secondary to antipsychotics. Bromocriptine is a dopamine agonist that restores the lost dopamine tone in NMS. It is prescribed at a dose of 2.5mg every 6-8 hours and tapered slowly. Other steps in management include maintaining a euvolemic state, and temperature using cooling blankets.

Option A: Risperidone - While NMS results due to central dopamine blockade in the hypothalamus, Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic causing dopamine blockade. It is thus avoided in NMS as it can further worsen the prognosis.

Option B: Haloperidol - It is one of the most notorious agents to cause NMS.

Option D: Lorazepam - It can be given to control agitation related to NMS, but is not the treatment of choice for the primary condition.

questions.text: An infertility specialist is planning ART (Artificial Reproductive Techniques) cycles for a group of couples over the next 3 months. He prepares a proforma for his residents to be filled for working up each couple prior to ovulation induction to alert them about risk of ovarian hyperstimulation so that it can be actively prevented. All of the following warrant caution for OHSS, EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Risk factors for OHSS

  • Polycystic ovary syndrome
  • polycystic ovarian morphology with elevated AMH levels (>3.36ng/mL)
  • previous episodes of OHSS

  • high E2(estradiol) concentrations

  • more than 20 preovulatory follicles

questions.text: Due to immaturity of the fetal lungs and their function of oxygenation being carried out by the placenta, the fetal heart chambers work in parallel and as such the separation of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood is done by preferential shunting of one type of blood into one type of heart chamber. All of these are responsible for this preferential shunting of well oxygenated blood from fetal right atrium to left heart, EXCEPT?

choices.text: Pattern of blood flow in IVC
Size difference of left and right atrium

questions.solution: More oxygenated blood travels along the medial aspect of IVC and less along lateral aspect, facilitating shunting to opposite sides of heart, that is, more oxygenated travels to left heart through foramen ovale and less oxygenated to right ventricle. This is also facilitated by configuration of interatrial septum called crista dividens. So all are correct except option d.

questions.text: 70-year-old Anny is admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain and pneumonia. She had shortness of breath with increased cough for 2 days before admission. Treatment, consisting of supplemental oxygen, IV antibiotics, and pulmonary toilet, is instituted, and she improved within 2 days. Her abdominal pain worsened on 3rdday of admitting in the hospital. Physical examination revealed a mildly distended abdomen with bowel sounds with no signs of peritonitis. Further examination revealed a tender bulge in the medial left thigh below the inguinal ligament. Mild pressure causes more pain but does not change the size or shape of the bulge. Abdominal films show a nonspecific bowel gas pattern. Laboratory analysis shows her WBC dropped from 18,000 to 13,000 from the time of admission. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Incarcerated femoral hernia - The diagnosis of an incarcerated hernia must be considered in the differential diagnosis of a patient with abdominal symptoms and a nonreducible inguinal bulge. Femoral hernia presents as a bulge below the inguinal ligament medial to the femoral artery.

Option A: A lymph node with abscess may present as a tender, nonreducible mass, but should be accompanied by additional adenopathy and a source of the infection.

Option B: An aneurysm of the femoral artery should be pulsatile. If there is concern for an aneurysm, a Doppler ultrasound examination may be diagnostic.

Option C: Direct or indirect inguinal hernias would present above the inguinal ligament.

Note: An incarcerated femoral hernia is a hernia that becomes stuck in the femoral canal and is irreducible. An obstructed femoral hernia occurs when a part of the intestine becomes interwined with the hernia, causing an intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: A 28 years old man was recently diagnosed with Pulmonary Tuberculosis, the physician initiated the treatment. After 3 weeks during follow-up the patient complaints of Orange- Red Urine which of the following drug with this mechanism of action is known to cause this adverse effect?

choices.text: Inhibition of bacterial DNA-Dependent RNA polymerase
Binds to the 30S ribosomal subunit and interferes with initiation of protein synthesis

questions.solution:
An HIV positive patient with Pulmonary Tuberclousis is treated with 4-drug combination therapy which includes Rifampin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol. The adverse reaction of Red-orange urine is secondary to Rifampin, the mechanism of action of rifampin is by inhibition of bacterial DNA-dependent RNA polymerase.

Option A: Inhibition of Mycolic acid synthesis is the mechanism of action for Isoniazid

Option B: Inhibition of Arabinosyltransferase is the mechanism of action for Ethambutol

Option D: Aminoglycosides are class of drugs that binds to 30s ribosomal subunit and interferes with protein synthesis

questions.text: Which nerve is likely damaged in the patient presenting with a loss of knee joint extension and decreased sensation over the anterior aspect of the thigh?
questions.solution:
Option B: Femoral nerve

  • The femoral nerve supplies the extensor muscles, the quadriceps muscles at the knee joint and the skin over the anterior aspect of the thigh.
  • Injury of the femoral nerve is uncommon but may be injured by a stab, gunshot wounds, during hip operations, or a pelvic fracture leading to :
  • Motor loss:
    • Poor flexion at the hip joint because of paralysis of the iliacus and sartorius muscles.
    • Inability to extend the knee because of paralysis of the quadriceps femoris.
  • Sensory loss:
    • Over the anterior and medial aspects of the thigh
    • Over the medial side of the leg and foot up to the back of the great toe

Option A: obturator nerve

  • Obturator supplies the muscles of the medial thigh and skin over the medial thigh, and its damage can cause difficulty in adduction of the thigh due to loss of function of adductor muscles at the medial thigh

Option C: Common peroneal nerve

  • The common peroneal nerve gives off the superficial peroneal nerve and deep peroneal nerve
  • The sensory component supplies the skin on the anterior compartment of the leg. The motor component of the deep peroneal nerve supplies the muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg.
  • Common peroneal neuropathy can cause foot drop due to loss of dorsiflexion and eversion at the foot

Option D: Tibial nerve

  • The tibial nerve provides motor and sensory innervation to most of the posterior leg and foot. Its damage can cause loss of Plantar flexion and inversion

questions.text:
An article was published about the middle ear. 3rd-year medical students are given the assignment to read it thoroughly after the very next day. A question was displayed in class multimedia, which of the following statements is correct about the perilymph?


	Perilymph fills the Scala vestibuli & Scala media
	Perilymph resembles extracellular fluid and is rich in Na+ ions.
	Perilymph - High sodium & Low potassium
	Perilymph - Low sodium & High potassium
questions.solution:
The correct statement about the perilymph is:

A. Only 2 and 3 are correct.

Explanation:

  1. Incorrect: Perilymph does not fill the Scala media. The Scala media is part of the cochlea and contains endolymph, not perilymph.

  2. Correct: Perilymph does resemble extracellular fluid and has a composition similar to cerebrospinal fluid. It is rich in sodium ions (Na+).

  3. Correct: Perilymph has high sodium (Na+) and low potassium (K+) levels.

  4. Incorrect: Perilymph has low sodium (Na+) and high potassium (K+) levels. The statement is reversed.

So, the correct answer is option A. Only statements 2 and 3 are correct about perilymph.

Option B: Only 1, 2, and 3 are correct

  • Only statements 2 and 3 are correct.
  • So, this option is wrong.

Option C: Only 1, 2, and 4 are correct

  • Only statements 2 and 3 are correct.
  • So, this option is wrong.

Option D: Only 1 and 3 are correct

  • Only statements 2 and 3 are correct.
  • So, this option is wrong.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male came into your clinic for occasional headaches. He appeared to have scoliosis. You insist on full physical examination and the patient complied. Physical examination revealed pigmented spots on trunk, rubbery cutaneous tumors over neck region. The cells composing of these skin structures, most likely originate from?
questions.solution:
Pigment - cafe-au-lait macules

Headache - mostly due to glioma

Tumors - most likely neurofibromas

In this patient the presence of cafe-au-lait macules and headache leads to the diagnosis of Neurofibromatosis Type I. neurofibromas are tumors of schwann cells, which are derived from the neural crest. Pathgnomonic of neurofibromas, ‘buttonholing’ referring to the cutaneous neurofibromas which are skin-coloured or pink nodules with a rubbery texture. From the examiner’s perception these tumors ‘buttonhole’ down through the skin with gentle pressure.

Choice A Neuroectoderm All neurons of CNS, neurohypophysis, retina, pineal gland, preganglionic autonomic fibers, astrocytes, ependymal cells, and the choroid plexus
Choice B Surface ectoderm Skin and its appendages, the nasal and oral epithelium, the anal epithelium to the dentate line, the lens and cornea
Choice D Mesoderm Muscles, bones, blood, genital tissues, the dermis and most organ systems
Choice E Notochord Completely regresses in humans, major vestige is nulceus pulposus in intervertebral discs

questions.text: EMLA Cream (lidocaine 2.5% and prilocaine 2.5%) is an emulsion in which the oil phase is a eutectic mixture of lidocaine and prilocaine in a ratio of 1:1 by weight. This eutectic mixture has a melting point below room temperature and therefore both local anesthetics exist as a liquid oil rather than as crystals. All of the following procedure can be done under EMLA cream except:
questions.solution:
♥ It is a cream preparation of local anesthetic providing dermal analgesia. Intubation cannot be done under EMLA it requires general anesthetics.

♥ EMLA cream – Eubetic mixture of local anesthetics It is a cream that consists of 1:1

♥ Mixture of 2.5 % Lidocaine and 2.5% prilocaine

♥ Contact time required = 60 minutes ? Depth of Penetration = 3-5 mm.

♥ Duration of Analgesia = 1-2 hour

♥ The amount of drug absorbed depends on application time, dermal blood flow, keratin thickness and total dose administered.

♥ C/I of application of EMLA – 1. Mucous membrane 2. Broken skin 3. < 1 month

♥ Uses – laser removal of port wine stains Lithotripsy Circumcision Venous emulation Skin graft harvesting

questions.text: A 50 yr old female presented with a lump in her right breast. She noticed Changes in breast skin, such as reddening, dimpling, swelling or thickening, Nipple discharge and Changes in the appearance of both nipples. A mammogram of the breast is given below. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C:

The correct diagnosis is:

c. Inflammatory breast cancer

Explanation:

  • Inflammatory breast cancer is a rare but aggressive form of breast cancer that can lead to rapid changes in the appearance of the breast, including redness, swelling, and dimpling of the skin. It may also involve changes in the nipple and areola.
  • Paget disease of the breast can cause changes in the nipple and surrounding areola but typically does not present with the rapid and pronounced skin changes seen in inflammatory breast cancer.
  • Phyllodes tumor is a type of breast tumor, but it does not typically cause the specific nipple and skin changes described.
  • "Luminal carcinoma" is not a recognized medical term for a specific breast condition.

Option B: phyllodes tumour

  • Phyllodes tumours, also known as phyllodes tumours, are uncommon breast tumours that begin in the connective (stromal) tissue of the breast rather than the ducts or glands (where the majority of breast malignancies begin).
  • Most phyllodes tumours are benign, and only a small number are malignant (cancer).
  • A core needle biopsy can frequently be used to make the diagnosis. Still, sometimes the entire tumour needs to be removed (during an excisional biopsy) to know for sure that it's a phyllodes tumour and whether it's malignant or not.
  • Phyllodes tumours are a rare form of breast tumour; they can be benign (not cancerous), malignant (cancerous), or borderline (having characteristics of both). Phyllodes tumours account for fewer than 1% of all breast cancers.

Option D:  Paget disease of the breast

  • Paget's disease of the breast, often referred to as Paget's disease of the nipple is an uncommon disorder connected to breast cancer.
  • It results in eczema-like changes to the nipple's skin as well as the region of darker skin around the nipple (areola). In the tissue behind the nipple, breast cancer is typically an indication.
  • Symptoms:
    • Tingling, Itching, or redness in the nipple and areola.
    • Discharge from the nipple that may be yellowish or bloody
    • Crusty, Flaking, or thickened skin on or around the nipple.
    • A flattened nipple.
  • Mammography plays an important role in diagnosing and managing Paget's disease; however, it has its limitations and may be normal in some cases.

questions.text: A 58-year-old mother of 10 suffers from fecal incontinence. Usually, defecation occurs by increased intra-abdominal pressure via the Valsalva maneuver, increased rectal contraction, and relaxation of the puborectalis muscle, which forms a “sling” around the distal rectum, forming a relatively acute angle that distributes intra-abdominal forces onto the pelvic floor. With defecation, this angle straightens, allowing downward force to be applied along the axis of the rectum and anal, and opening of the anal canal. A dysfunction at which point of this pathway can lead to fecal incontinence?

choices.text: Repair of the internal or external sphincter during delivery.
Hypertrophic internal and external anal sphincters.

questions.solution: Defecation proceeds by coordination of increasing intra-abdominal pressure via the Valsalva maneuver, increased rectal contraction, relaxation of the puborectalis muscle, and opening of the anal canal. Impaired continence may result from poor rectal compliance, injury to the internal and/or external sphincter or puborectalis, or nerve damage or neuropathy.

questions.text: Which of the following substances most likely elicits the sensation of sour taste?
questions.solution:
Option D: Hydrogen ions

  • The taste sensation of sourness is proportional to the logarithm of the hydrogen ion concentration caused by acids.
  • Hence, the more acidic the food, the stronger will be the sour taste.
  • Hydrogen ions influence the TRPP3 channels, which leads to an inflow of sodium ions.
  • The sodium ion inflow results in membrane depolarization.
  • This causes the inflow of calcium ions and the release of vesicular neurotransmitters.
  • The taste sensation of sweetness is caused by a long list of chemicals, including sugars, alcohols, aldehydes, esters, sulfonic acid, halogenated acids, inorganic salts of lead and beryllium, ketones, and amino acids.
  • The taste sensation of bitterness is caused by many organic substances containing nitrogen and alkaloids.
  • The salty taste is because of ionized salts, mainly sodium ion concentration.
  • Umami taste is because of food containing L-glutamate, such as meat and aging cheese.

Option A: Aldehydes

  • Aldehydes are responsible for the sweet taste.
  • Other substances which produce sweet taste are sugars, alcohols and esters.

Option B: Alkaloids

  • Alkaloids and nitrogen-containing substances are responsible for bitter taste.

Option C: Amino acids

  • Amino acids and alcohols, and aldehydes are responsible for sweet taste.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman married for 3 years, presents with primary infertility. She has regular cycles, every 28-30 days, lasting 3-5 days. A tubal patency test shows patent fallopian tube. A pelvic scan is normal and husband’s semen analysis is also normal. An endometrial biopsy done on 22nd day of her cycle shows hypertrophied endometrium with endometrial glands filled with secretions and edematous stroma. Which of the following is the most likely explanation of these findings?
questions.solution:
Endometrial biopsy at 22 days is suggestive of secretory changes in endometrium, which is normally expected after ovulation and is secondary to progesterone

Menstrual phase : day 1-5 : shedding of endometrium, except deciduabasalis

Proliferative phase : day 5-14 : characterised be estrogen effect on the endometrium : endometrial proliferation, glands become more crowded with pseudostratification and dense stroma.

Ovulation : day 14 : first change after ovulation is subnuclear vacuolation in glands

Secretory phase : day 14-28 : secretory changes in endometrial glands with stromal edema, prominence of spiral arterioles

- In a normal menstrual cycle (ovulatory cycle), ovulation is characterised by secretion of progesterone by corpus luteum which induces secretory changes in endometrium, evident on a premenstrual biopsy.

questions.text: Concomittant use of NSAIDs and diuretics lead to diuretic resistance. Which of the following statement is false:

choices.text: NSAIDs administration can block prostaglandin-mediated cardiovascular protective effects in CHF
Prostaglandins reduce NaCl reabsorption in the distal nephron in CHF Patients
Prostaglandins potentiates effects  of ADH in CHF Patients
NSAID co-administration is a common preventable cause of diuretic resistance

questions.solution:
• NSAID co-administration is a common preventable cause of diuretic resistance.
  • Elderly patients have co prescription of  NSAID and diuretic prescriptions.
  • Prostaglandin production, especially PGE2, is an important counterregulatory mechanism in states of reduced renal perfusion such as volume contraction, congestive heart failure, and cirrhosis characterized by activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone (RAA) and sympathetic nervous systems.
  • Prostaglandins reduce NaCl reabsorption in the distal nephron, antagonize effects of ADH, and redistribute blood flow from cortex to juxtamedullary regions in this setting.
  • NSAID administration can block these prostaglandin-mediated effects that counterbalance the RAA and sympathetic nervous system, resulting in salt and water retention.
  • Interaction between NSAIDs and diuretics can result in important clinical consequences such as development or exacerbation of congestive heart failure.

questions.text: A patient is presented in the hospital ER after a severe roadside accident. When presented, he was unconscious and had signs of external chest injury at his back. On further examination, a CT scan was done, which is given below. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Traumatic aortic rupture

  • Traumatic aortic transection, also known as aortic rupture, is a condition in which the aorta is almost completely torn through due to trauma from a fall or a car accident. This disease is fatal most of the time and necessitates immediate medical care.
  • It is most commonly caused by blunt trauma, though it can also be caused by penetrating injury. The mortality associated with traumatic aortic injury is about 30 per cent within the first 24 hours.
  • Aortic rupture is commonly fatal as blood in the aorta is under very high pressure and can quickly escape the vessel through a tear, resulting in rapid hemorrhagic shock, exsanguination, and death.
  • After a traumatic event, a diagnosis of aortic rupture is almost always made at the emergency room. Imaging tests such as an aortic angiogram, CT scan or magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA) may be used to view the aorta and determine if a tear is present.

Option B: Pneumothorax

  • Traumatic pneumothorax, which results in partial or total lung collapse, is air in the pleural space.
  • Pneumothorax may result when blunt force (such as a motor vehicle crash or fall) or a penetrating injury (such as a stab or gunshot wound) damages the lungs or airways. The damage allows air to leave and collect between the lung and the chest wall.
  • Chest pain from the underlying damage is one of the symptoms, and occasionally dyspnea.
  • Chest X-rays are used to diagnose. The standard form of treatment is a tube thoracostomy.
  • Chest damage is one factor that can lead to a pneumothorax. Lung collapse can result from any chest wound that is piercing or blunt.

Option C: Cardiac tamponade

  • Cardiac tamponade occurs when the sac of the surrounding fluid heart fills with blood or another liquid and compresses the heart.
  • Your heart cannot fill up with blood due to the pressure, which reduces the amount of blood it can pump and ultimately results in a dip in blood pressure.
  • Cardiovascular tamponade can be brought on by trauma and specific illnesses. It is invariably lethal if untreated.
  • When blood or fluid accumulates between the heart's outer covering sac and its muscle, it puts pressure on the heart and is known as cardiac tamponade.

Option D: Flail chest

  • One of the most catastrophic injuries, the flail chest, is characterized by two or more contiguous rib fractures with two or more breaks per rib. It is frequently linked to significant morbidity and mortality.
  • It happens when a section of the chest wall becomes unstable, usually due to serious traumatic trauma.
  • Symptoms:
    • Bruising, discolouration, or swelling in the area of the broken bones.
    • Marks from being thrown against a seat belt (after a car accident)
    • Sharp, severe chest pain.
    • Difficulty inhaling or getting a full breath.
  • Patients are highly susceptible to respiratory problems because the strong force needed to generate a flail chest usually results in a sizable underlying pulmonary contusion. (See also Thoracic Trauma Overview.) A common and potentially fatal chest injury is pulmonary contusion.

questions.text: Chemoexfoliation or chemical peeling is a method of targeted cutaneous ablation using specific caustic agents that allow for rapid, predictable, and uniform thickness of chemoablation to a desired cutaneous depth, ultimately resulting in an improved appearance of skin. Which of the following cannot be used for chemical peeling?
questions.solution:
Chemical peels are used for acne scars.

Agents used are

1. Pyruvic acid

2. Glycolic acid

3. Malic acid

4. Citric acid

5. Lactic acid

6. Tartaric acid

7. Salicylic acid

8. Trichloroacetic acid

9. Mandelic acid

10. Jessners solution - Combination of Salicylic acid+ lactic acid+ resorcinol

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother as she has not attained menarche yet. She is not sexually active. Her vitals are stable, height is 150 cms and BMI is 24 kg/m2. Specific examination reveals breast development and presence of pubic and axillary hair, however her vagina appears blind. An ultrasound reveals absent uterus and cervix and a right ovarian simple cyst. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has primary amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characters ( by estrogen secreted from a normal ovary) and absence of Mullerian duct derivatives like uterus, cervix and vagina. This is suggestive of Mullerian agenesis/ MRKH (Mullerian Rokitansky Kuster-Hauser syndrome). The presence of ovarian cyst is incidental, as ovaries are functional and there may be functional cysts seen.

Primary amenorrhea is defined as absence of menstruation by 13 years in the absence of secondary sexual characteristics or by 15 years in the presence of secondary sexual characteristics.

MRKH (Mullerian agenesis/ Mayer Rokitansky Kuster hauser syndrome)

  • A female genotype (46 XX) with absence of development of mullerian structures such as vagina, cervix, uterus and fallopian tubes
  • Ovary is functioning normally, thus estrogen production is present, hence external sexual characters are feminine with normal breast development, female habitus and pubic and axillary hair.
  • Associated anomalies: renal anomalies, skeletal anomalies, hearing defects
  • Management : to be reared as a female. Vaginoplasty may be done prior to onset of sexual activity

An important differential is Androgen insensitivity syndrome

MRKH Androgen insensitivity syndrome
Genotype XX XY
Gonad Ovaries Testes
Breast development Normal Normal
Pubic and axillary hair Normal Absent (insensitivity to testosterone)
Vagina Shallow and blind Shallow and blind
Uterus Absent Absent
Vulva Normal Normal
Sr Androgen levels 20-80 ng/dl 200-800 ng/dl

Evaluation of primary amenorrhea

- MRKH or Mullerian agenesis is a normal female(genotype and appearance) with absence of Mullerian duct derivatives : vagina, uterus, cervix and fallopian tubes. Ovarian function is normal.

questions.text: In a 40-year-old female, total blood flow to all the muscles is 800 ml/min, her arterial pO2 is 90 mmHg, and her arterial pCO2 is 50 mmHg. Now, her sympathetic system is activated, decreasing blood flow to 400 ml/min to all the muscles. What will happen to Venous pO2 and Venous pCO2?
questions.solution:
Option A: ↓ Venous pO2  ↑ Venous pCO2

  • Sympathetic stimulation results in vasoconstriction, which causes a redistribution in cardiac output to the muscles. Still, due to no change in metabolism, there is an increase in oxygen diffusion from the blood, which lowers venous pO2. Still, simultaneously it also decreases the flushing out of carbon dioxide from the blood, increasing the venous pCO2.
  • Oxygen supply at tissue levels must be maintained due to high aerobic activity.
  • The diffusion of oxygen is crucial for survival.
  • The partial pressure of oxygen (pO2) results from the balance between oxygen consumption and delivery.
  • The delivery of oxygen depends on each organ tissue's metabolic needs.
  • Certain pathological conditions, e.g. diabetes, stroke etc., can result in a decrease in pO2.
  • On the contrary, the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) is a marker for adequate alveolar ventilation.

Option B: ↑ Venous pO2 ↓ Venous pCO2

  • This condition may be seen in polycythemia.
  • This condition is not seen with sympathetic stimulation.

Option C: ↔ Venous pO2 ↑ Venous pCO2

  • This condition is not seen with sympathetic stimulation.

Option D: ↓ Venous pO2 ↔ Venous pCO2

  • This condition may be seen in aerobic exercise due to the shunting of blood from non-metabolically active sites resulting in greater oxygen extraction.
  • pCO2 does not increase during exercise.
  • This condition is not seen with sympathetic stimulation.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic by his mother, complaining of a swollen abdomen. Physical examination reveals pallor in the conjunctiva and pigmentation of the skin. The physician diagnosed the child with kwashiorkor due to protein malnutrition. Which of the following statement is correct regarding the absorption of proteins?

choices.text: Dipeptides and tripeptides are transported into the enterocyte via sodium cotransport
Amino acids are transported into the enterocyte via peptide transporter-1 (PepT1).
Dipeptides and tripeptides are transported into the enterocyte via peptide transporter-1 (PepT1).
Most of the absorption of amino acids takes place in the ileum

questions.solution:
Option C: Dipeptides and tripeptides are transported into the enterocyte via peptide transporter-1 (PepT1).

  • In the duodenum, trypsinogen in the pancreatic secretions is converted to trypsin by the action of enterokinase.
  • Trypsin further activates other proteolytic enzymes present in the pancreatic juice.
  • These enzymes break down proteins into tripeptides, dipeptides, and amino acids that are absorbed in the small intestine into the bloodstream.
  • Most of the absorption of amino acids takes place in the duodenum and the jejunum.
  • Amino acids are mostly absorbed by the sodium-amino acid cotransport system.
  • Dipeptides and tripeptides are absorbed into the enterocyte by using a peptide transport-1 (PepT1) system.
  • PepT1 (peptide transporter 1) requires H+ instead of Na+ to cotransport dipeptides and tripeptides into enterocytes.
  • H+ ions are supplied by the sodium/hydrogen exchanger to cotransport dipeptides and tripeptides.
  • Cytosolic proteases digest the peptides into amino acids that enter the bloodstream via basolateral transport proteins.

 

 

  • The figure above shows that dipeptides and tripeptides use PepT1 to enter into the enterocyte. Whereas amino acids use sodium cotransport. Some small peptides may enter the enterocyte via transcytosis.

Option A: Dipeptides and tripeptides are transported into the enterocyte via sodium cotransport.

  • Dipeptides and tripeptides are transported into the enterocyte via peptide transporter-1 (PepT1).

Option B: Amino acids are transported into the enterocyte via peptide transporter-1 (PepT1).

  • Amino acids are transported into the enterocyte via sodium cotransport.

Option D: Most of the absorption of amino acids takes place in the ileum.

  • Most of the absorption of amino acids takes place in the duodenum and the jejunum.

questions.text: A 50-year-old alcoholic was brought to the emergency department. He had passed out in a bar after his usual drinking and his friends were unable to revive him. He was prescribed a thiamine injection followed by an overnight glucose through IV. The patient was alert and coherent next morning with normal serum thiamine and his blood glucose was 73 mg/dL (4mM) and was discharged from the hospital. Which of the following enzyme/proteins would have no significant physiologic activity in this patient soon after discharge?
questions.solution: After an overnight fast (plasma glucose 73 mg/dL), the liver will be stimulated to produce glucose. The activity of Glucokinase, an enzyme of glycolysis, would be insignificant as it requires high glucose concentration to be effective (high Km for glucose) and also due to low insulin.

questions.text: A 66 year old male has a long history of abdominal pain, heartburn and dyspepsia. He was evaluated for peptic ulcer disease by upper GI endoscopy. No gastric or duodenal ulcers are visualized, but a reddish mucosa extending proximally from gastroesophageal junction into the oesophagus is visualised. Biopsies of these areas show columnar metaplasia. All of the following statements are correct regarding this diagnosis, except:

choices.text: Finding high-grade dysplasia mandates further intervention.
High-dose proton pump inhibitor therapy will likely cause regression of the mucosal abnormalities.
The incidence of these lesions has increased in the era of potent acid suppression.
The patient has a high risk of coexisting cancer.
The patient is at significant risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

questions.solution:
Barrett metaplasia is a premalignant condition, in which the normal squamous lining of the lower oesophagus is replaced by columnar mucosa.

  • It is the most serious complication of GERD.
  • Strong association with development of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

Endoscopy:- Endoscopically it is seen as by tongues of reddish mucosa extending proximally from the gastroesophageal junction

Histopathologically

  • Specialized columnar metaplasia is seen.
  • Areas of Barrett and around should be extensively biopsied

Fig:-Gastroesophageal junction in Barrett esophagus. Note the transition between esophageal squamous mucosa (lower right) and metaplastic mucosa containing goblet cells (upper).

Treatment:-

  • Esophagectomy (Mortality of 3-10%)
  • Intensive endoscopic surveillance
  • Mucosal ablation

questions.text: Patient presented with colicky pain and diarrhea. On history of fever and stool sample is given for investigation and showed in the image diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts Quadri-nucleate cyst typically seen in E. histolytica

In case of E. coli there will be octanucleate cyst is seen.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old male comes to the outpatient door department with a history of nosebleeds whenever he removes crusts from his nose. On inquiry, he says that he went through sub mucous resection some years ago for deviated nasal septum. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the underlying cause of this patient's epistaxis?


	It is commonly symptomatic.
	Epistaxis may occur on the separation of crusts.
	Commonest cause is habitual nose picking.
	Wegner's granulomatosis involves both bony and cartilage perforation.
questions.solution:
Option C: Only 2 and 3, 4 are correct

Perforation of the nasal septum

Etiology

  • Traumatic Perforations
    • Trauma is the most common cause. Injury to mucosal flaps during sub mucous resection (SMR), cauterization of the septum with chemicals or galvanocautery for Epistaxis, and habitual nose picking are the common forms of trauma. Occasionally, the septum is deliberately perforated to put ornaments.
  • Pathological Perforations; They can be caused by:
    • Septal abscess
    • Nasal myiasis
    • Rhinolith or neglected foreign body causing pressure necrosis.
    • Chronic granulomatous conditions like lupus, tuberculosis, and leprosy cause perforation in the cartilaginous part, while syphilis involves the bony part. In these cases, evidence of the causative disease may also be seen in other systems of the body.
    • Wegener's granuloma is a midline destructive lesion that may cause total septal destruction.

Option A: 1,2,3, and 4 are correct

  • Statements 2,3, and 4 are correct. However, statement 1 is not true because septal perforation is mostly asymptomatic, and it becomes symptomatic on the removal of crusts occasionally.

Option B: Only 1,2 and 3 are correct

  • Statement 1 is not true because septal perforation is mostly asymptomatic, and it becomes symptomatic on the removal of crusts occasionally.
  • Statement 4 is correct that Wegener's granulomatosis involves both bony and cartilage perforation.

Option D: Only 4 is correct

  • Statement 4 is true Wegener granulomatosis involves both bony and cartilage perforation. However, statement 2 and 3 are also true.

questions.text: A 68-year-old patient came to your consultant’s clinic complaining of pain over the penis and posterior surface of the scrotum for the past few months. He is a known case of IBS with constipation and is on and off medications for the same. You, being an intern, ask about any history of trauma/fall/surgery as you suspect pudendal nerve involvement which has the root value:-
questions.solution:
• Pudendal nerve arises from the sacral plexus in the pelvis( S2- S4).
  • Pudendal nerve is nerve of perineum.
  • External urethral sphincter is supplied by the pudendal nerve.

questions.text: A 53-year -old female presents in medical OPD with a complaint of dysphagia and a burning sensation in his tongue for the last 3-months. She worries about her exertional dyspnea and palpitation, which have worsened over the last 8-weeks. Physical examination is unremarkable except for the findings shown below. Her barium swallow showed webs of mucosa in the upper third of the Esophagus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Paterson-Brown-Kelly syndrome

  • The patient described in the clinical vignette has dysphagia, oesophagal webs and exertional dyspnea. Palpitation that points to the anaemia makes it the classical case of Paterson-Brown-Kelly syndrome, also known as Plummer-Vinson syndrome. It is characterized by the following:-
    • Iron deficiency anaemia
    • Atrophic glossitis, cheilosis
    • Webs in upper 1/3rd of Esophagus
    • Most commonly seen in middle-aged females
    • Risk factor for hypopharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma

Option B:  Achalasia

  • Achalasia can cause dysphagia and anaemia.
  • A barium swallow will show a bird's beak appearance, not the oesophagal webs.

Option C: Esophageal adenocarcinoma

  • Oesophageal adenocarcinoma can cause anaemia and dysphagia
  • Endoscopy will show oesophagal mass

Option D: Zenker diverticulum

  • It can present with halitosis, regurgitation and dysphagia
  • However, anaemia and the presence of oesophagal webs are unlikely in Zenker diverticulum

questions.text: In a routine colonoscopy, a 70-year-old man is found to have a lesion similar to that shown in the illustration. The lesion shown is a classic example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
• The illustration shows a tubular adenoma, which is the most common form of adenomatous polyp.
  • Tubular adenomas tend to be small, pedunculated polyps composed of rounded, or tubular, glands.
  • In contrast, villous adenomas, which are often larger and sessile, are covered by slender villi.
  • Tubular adenomas can be single or multiple, or they can occur as components of various multiple polyposis syndromes.
  • Notable among these syndromes are Gardner (associated with osteomas and soft tissue tumors), Turcot (associated with central nervous system tumors), and FAP.
  • All of the foregoing is associated with an increased incidence of colon malignancy.
  • Peutz-Jeghers polyp is nonneoplastic hamartomata’s lesion.
  • Even though the polyp itself does not Transform into colon cancer, the Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is associated with an increased incidence of colon Cancer and malignancies elsewhere.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct about silent thyroiditis?

Postpartum thyroiditis
It is associated with thyrotoxicosis
It is associated with hypothyroidism
Glucocorticoids is almost always useful as a treatment option
questions.solution:
Silent thyroiditis / Post-Partum thyroiditis

  • It is an autoimmune mediated destruction of gland.
  • It occurs after 3-6 months post-partum in about 5% of pregnancies.
  • Patient first develops thyrotoxicosis which is followed by hypothyroidism and then resolution.
  • It is characterised by:
    • Normal ESR and presence of TPO antibodies
    • RAIU is supressed
    • No role of steroids
    • Recovery is the rule

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady with Idiopathic pulmonary artery hypertension. Which findings best describe this patient?

choices.text: Elevated JVP, normal SI S2, Diastolic murmur
Elevated JVP, singular loud S2, Systolic murmur
Elevated JVP, wide fixed split S2, Systolic murmur
Elevated JVP, barrel chest, reverse split S2

questions.solution:
• PAH is characterized by presence of large ‘a’ waves leading to elevated JVP. S2 is loud, due to higher pressure leading to P2 closing with more force.
  • The systolic murmur in these patients is explained by the presence of tricuspid regurgitation developing due to severe PAH
  • Barrel-shaped chest is seen with COPD.

Clinical feature of pulmonary hypertension Symptoms 1) Dyspnea and/or fatigue, 2)whereas edema, 3)chest pain, presyncope, and syncope are less common and associated with more advanced disease. SIGN In early phases of PAH, the physical examination is often unrevealing. As the disease progresses there may be evidence of right ventricular failure with 1) elevated jugular venous pressure, 2)lower extremity edema, 3)Ascites. , the cardiovascular examination may reveal an accentuated P2 component of the second heart sound, a right-sided S3 or S4, a holosystolic tricuspid regurgitant murmur. Signs of the diseases that are often concurrent with PH: clubbing may be seen in some chronic lung diseases, sclerodactyly and telangiectasia may signify scleroderma, and crackles on examination of the lungs and systemic hypertension may be clues to left-sided systolic or diastolic heart failure.

questions.text: What is the risk of using the contraceptive form a female purchased over the counter considering her heart condition, which is categorized as Category-4 in the WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria for contraceptive use?

choices.text: She can use it if no other contraceptive fulfills her requirement
It is meant only for a particular heart condition

questions.solution:
Option B: She should not use it

 

  • This patient has this contraceptive in category 4 for her heart condition, which means this particular contraceptive must absolutely NOT be used.

WHO: MEC: Medical Eligibility Criteria for Contraceptive Use

MEC categories for contraceptive eligibility

1. A condition for which there is no restriction for the use of the contraceptive method

2. A condition where the advantages of using the method generally outweigh the theoretical or proven risks

3. A condition where the theoretical or proven risk usually outweigh the advantages of using the method

4. A condition which represents an unacceptable health risk if the contraceptive method is used

 

Categories 1 and 4 are self-explanatory

Category 1 denotes indications and category 4 indicates absolute contraindications;

Categories 2 and 3 indicate relative contraindications)

Option A : She can safely use it

  • Category 1 is the contraceptive that she can safely use.

Option C : She can use it if no other contraceptive fulfils her requirement

  • Category 3 are contraceptives which can be used very rarely when no other contraceptive suits the patient, and using contraceptive is a necessity.

Option D : It is meant only for the particular heart condition

  • Category 4 does not imply that the contraceptive can be used only for that particular condition. There is no such category.

questions.text: An 18-month-old girl is brought to the ER with cyanosis. Over the past week, the patient has been teething and had mild nasal congestion and low-grade fevers. She has been eating and drinking normally. The patient was extremely fussy today despite her mother giving her acetaminophen and a topical anesthetic. Physical examination shows a sleepy child with blue discoloration of the skin and nails. BP = 90/60 mm Hg, PR = 158/min, and RR = 50/min. Pulse oximetry is 85% on room air. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. The abdomen is soft, non-tender, and has no hepatosplenomegaly. 100% oxygen is administered but fails to increase the pulse oximetry reading or the cyanosis. Which of the following laboratory findings would most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
? This patient has methemoglobinemia that can occur after excessive exposure to an oxidizing agent (eg, dapsone, nitrites, local /topical anesthetics) and results in cyanosis.

? In normal hemoglobin, iron is in the ferrous (Fe2+) state. When exposed to an oxidizing agent, iron is oxidized to the ferric (Fe3+) state, resulting in acute methemoglobinemia.

? Ferric iron is unable to bind oxygen; in addition, the ferric state changes the hemoglobin structure and causes ferrous sites to have an increased affinity for oxygen (ie left - shift on oxygen-dissociation curve). The increased oxygen affinity prevents oxygen release in peripheral tissues (ie, decreased oxygen delivery).

? Because methemoglobin absorbs light at a different wavelength than hemoglobin, patients have pulse oximetry readings of -85% regardless of the true oxygen saturation level (as seen in this patient). Supplemental oxygen has no effect on the altered methemoglobin structure; therefore, it does not improve cyanosis. In contrast, arterial blood gas testing analyzes only unbound arterial oxygen (as opposed to hemoglobin-bound oxygen) and displays a falsely elevated oxygen saturation level, shown as normal Pa02.

? The antidote for acquired methemoglobinemia is methylene blue. Methylene blue acts as an electron acceptor for NADPH and is reduced to leucomethylene blue, which in turn reduces methemoglobin to hemoglobin. High-dose ascorbic acid (vitamin C) acts as a reducing agent and can be used when methylene blue is unavailable

Choice B: PaC02 increases in respiratory system failure.

Choice C: An elevated plasma osmolal gap is seen after ethanol, methanol, or ethylene glycol ingestion. Patients with this condition are not cyanotic.

Choice D: Elevated transaminase levels signify can be due to an overdose of acetaminophen but there will be no cyanosis.

questions.text: Identify this marker of lipid peroxidation:
questions.solution:

questions.text: An AIDS patient presents with history of 2 weeks of watery diarrhoea. Stool examination, upon modified acid fast staining shows the organism depicted in the image given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The figure presented in the question shows a Cryptosporidium oocyst stained with modified acid-fast stain .

  • They are smaller than Cyclospora, which are yeast size, but larger than Enterocytozoon, one of the microsporidia.
Organism Oocyst Size
Cryptosporidium parvum 4-6 µ

Cyclospora

8-10 µ
Isospora belli

23-36 µ

All are acid fast.

Parasites causing watery diarrhea:

  • Giardia lamblia
  • Cryptosporidium species
  • Cyclospora species

  • Microsporidia

Stool findings:

  • No fecal leukocytes
