questions.text: A 3-year-old boy has a history of multiple hospitalizations for fever and infection and undergoes immunologic evaluation. Serum CH50 assay shows inappropriately low erythrocyte lysis, and further workup confirms C8 deficiency. Physical examination reveals a cleft lip, a prominent nasal bridge, and a small lower jaw. After further investigation patient is diagnosed with DiGeorge syndrome. Which of the following are true regarding the derivatives of the structure involved in patient's pathology?

choices.text: Eustachian tube develops from 1st pharyngeal pouch
Palatine tonsils develop from 1st pharyngeal pouch
Inferior parathyroid glands develop from the 4thpharyngeal pouch
Parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland develop from the 1st pharyngeal pouch and remnants of the 5th pharyngeal pouch

questions.solution:
Option A: Eustachian tube develops from 1st pharyngeal pouch

  • This is a case of DiGeorge syndrome in which the patient’s serum CH50 assay shows inappropriately low erythrocyte lysis, and further workup confirms C8 deficiency.
  • The physical examination reveals a cleft lip, a prominent nasal bridge, and a small lower jaw.
  • Eustachian tube is derived from 1st pharyngeal pouch.
  • The two lateral Anlagen, also known as the ultimobranchial bodies, are thought to develop as evaginations of the fourth pharyngeal pouches.
  • They become separated from them by attenuation and rupture from the common pharyngobranchial duct.
  • The ultimobranchial bodies fuse with the median thyroid anlage by the sixth.
  • week of development, contributing approximately 10% of the mass of the thyroid gland.
  • It is thought that rarely the ultimobranchial bodies can fail to fuse, resulting in a true 'lateral thyroid lobe,' although this has been disputed.

Option B: Palatine tonsils develop from 1st pharyngeal pouch

  • The palatine tonsils are not developed from the 1st pharyngeal pouch.
  • It is derived from 2nd pharyngeal pouch.

Option C: Inferior parathyroid glands develop from the 4th pharyngeal pouch

  • The inferior parathyroid gland arises from the 3rd pharyngeal pouch, while the superior parathyroids arise from the fourth pharyngeal pouch. So, this statement is incorrect.

Option D: Parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland develop from the 1st pharyngeal pouch and remnants of the 5th pharyngeal pouch

  • Parafollicular C cells are believed to develop from the ventral portion of the 4th pharyngeal pouch and the remnants of the 5th pharyngeal pouch.

questions.text: A person in a late night party have consumed several drinks with the meal. Keeping in mind the distribution and solubility of ethanol, in which of the following tissues would you find the LEAST amount of alcohol?
questions.solution:
Ethanol is both water- and lipid-soluble. It is easily absorbed from the Gastrointestinal tract and is distributed throughout the body via the blood stream.

It is mostly metabolized in the liver, so the level would be high in this tissue.

It is lipid-soluble, so it would be found in fatty tissue.

It has many central effects in the brain, so it easily passes the blood– brain barrier.

The central cornea has no arterial supply. The only way alcohol could accumulate in the central cornea would be through diffusion into the aqueous humor and then into the central cornea, a slower and less-efficient system. Therefore, the tissue with the lowest level of alcohol would be the central cornea.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male patient diagnosed with Meniere's disease comes to the E.N.T. outpatient department, and a 1st-year E.N.T. resident, on his first week at the hospital, asked a question by a senior doctor. Which of the following clinical features are seen in Meniere's disease?


	Vertigo
	Hearing loss
	Tinnitus
	Diplopia
questions.solution:
Option A: 1, 2, and 3 are correct

  • Meniere's disease, also called endolymphatic hydrops, is a disorder of the inner ear where the endolymphatic system is distended with endolymph.

Clinical symptoms of Meniere's disease

  • Episodic vertigo.
  • Fluctuating hearing loss.
  • Tinnitus.
  • Sense of fullness or pressure in the involved ear.
  • Vertigo attacks are usually preceded by an aura consisting of fullness in the ear, increasing tinnitus, and a decrease in hearing.
  • It is a distension of the endolymphatic system, mainly affecting the cochlear duct (scala media), the saccule, and, to a lesser extent, the utricle and semicircular canals. The dilatation of the cochlear duct is such that it may completely fill the scala vestibuli; there is marked bulging of Reissner's membrane, which may even herniate through the helicotrema into the apical part of scala tympani. The distended saccule may come to lie against the stapes footplate. The utricle and saccule may show outpouchings into the semicircular canals.

Option B: Only 1 and 2 are correct

  • This option is incorrect because not only statements 1 and 2 are correct but also statement 3 is correct.
  • According to statement 1, vertigo is the clinical feature of Meniere's disease.
  • According to statement 2, hearing loss is the clinical feature of Meniere's disease.
  • According to statement 3, tinnitus is the clinical feature of Meniere's disease.

Option C: Only 1, 2, and 4 are correct

  • This option is also incorrect because statements 1 and 2 are correct, but statement 4 is incorrect because, according to statement 4, diplopia is the clinical feature of Meniere's disease, which is a wrong statement.
  • Diplopia is the clinical feature of an autoimmune disease, myasthenia gravis.

Option D: All are correct

  • This option is also incorrect because statements 1, 2, and 3 are correct, but statement 4 is incorrect because, according to statement 4, diplopia is the clinical feature of Meniere's disease, which is a wrong statement.
  • Diplopia is the clinical feature of an autoimmune disease, myasthenia gravis.

Clinical symptoms of Meniere's disease:

  • Episodic vertigo.
  • Fluctuating hearing loss.
  • Tinnitus.
  • Sense of fullness or pressure in the involved ear.
  • Vertigo attacks are usually preceded by an aura consisting of fullness in the ear, increasing tinnitus, and a decrease in hearing.

questions.text: A 35 years old army personnel suddenly fall down while doing patrolling in Thar desert border in Rajasthan. He was immediately taken to Military hospital and assessed by Medical officer. On examination - he was unconscious and unresponsive and pulse was impalpable . ECG was done and diagnosis of PEA (Pulseless Electrical Activity) was made. Which of following condition is least likely to be the cause of this condition ?
questions.solution:
• The 5 H and 5 T of pulseless electrical activity → PEA implies that electrical activity is seen on ECG but the pulse is absent.
  • The leading cause of PEA is hypoxia secondary to respiratory failure (40-50% cases) and hypovolemia.
  • Hydrogen ion depletion implies alkalosis whereas PEA occurs with acidosis.

H

Hypovolemia

Hypoxia

Hydrogen Ion (acidosis)

Hypo / Hyperkalemia

Hypothermia

T

Toxins

Tamponade

Tension Pneumothorax

Thrombosis (heart: acute, massive MI)

Thrombosis (lungs: massive PEE)

questions.text: A patient with microcytic hypochromic anemia,has Hb-9%,serum iron 20 µg/dl, ferritin level 800 ng/ ml, and transferrin percentage saturation is 64. What is possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Interpretation of values given:

Low serum iron=Normal (50-170 µg/dl)

High serum ferritin=Normal (30-400 ng/ml)

High transferrin saturation =Normal (30-50%)

Iron deficiency anemia

  • Can be easily ruled out as serum ferritin is low in Iron deficiency anemia.

Hemochromatosis

  • Can be easily ruled out as hemochromatosis is characterized by increased serum iron level.

Atransferrinemia

  • Transferrin is an iron carrying protein that transmits iron to the erythroblasts.
  • Atransferrinemia or hypotransferrinemia results in reduced delivery of iron to erythroblasts and development of iron deficient anemia. This explains low serum iron.
  • This leads to massive but futile iron absorption and whatever little transferrin is there, it is saturated. This explains High transferrin saturation. The difference from DMT 1 mutation is that since the iron absorption is defective, the transferrin saturation is low.
  • Iron is deposited in the visceral organs rather than in the bone marrow.

DMT1 mutation

  • DMT1 is a transmembrane protein involved in dietary non heme iron uptake at the brush border of duodenal enterocytes and also plays a crucial role in iron utilization at the endosomal membrane of the erythroid precursors.Divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1) is a duodenal apical iron transporter encoded by the SLC11A2 gene.
  • In DMT1 mutation the iron absorption in the duodenum continues because the absorption of heme iron is not affected.
  • The mutation primarily affects iron utilization and not absorption. Iron utilization in erythroid precursors is disturbed leading to severe iron deficiency anemia.   DMT1 mutation Atransferrinemia
  DMT1 mutation Atransferrinemia
Age of diagnosis  At birth  Late onset
Anemia  Microcytic Hypochromic  Microcytic hypochromic 
Serum iron  High  Low 
Transferrin saturation  High  High 
Ringed sideroblasts No  No 
Liver iron overload  Yes  Yes 
Brain damage  No  No 
Hepcidin levels Low Not yet measured

questions.text: A child is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents for a well-child examination. He is healthy and immunization is up to date. He was born at 39 weeks gestation via vaginal delivery. The mother report that he can go from a crawling position to a standing position with the help and support of chairs or something to hold on to. On examination, he responds to simple instructions. Which of the following best estimates the age of the child:
questions.solution:
A 9-month-old child should be able to sit alone, crawl, use a pincer grasp, recognize familiar people, pull himself to a standing position, use gestures, respond to simple instructions. Apart from being expert crawlers, a 9-month-old can easily change positions, such as go from a crawling position to a standing position (with the help and support of chairs or something to hold on to).

Option A: At 2 years old, a child should be able to stack 6 blocks, kick a ball, use a spoon or fork, use approximately 250 words, play alongside other children in parallel play, and form 2-word sentences, name body parts, and use pronouns.

Option B: A 3-year-old child will achieve toilet training and speak in complete sentences, as well as stack nine blocks, climb stairs using alternating feet, identify colors, copy a circle, ride a tricycle, use scissors, partially dress himself,

Option C: A 5-month-old child should just be able to roll over, use a raking grasp, recognize familiar people, sit when propped, and babble.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male is diagnosed with multinodular goiter and is scheduled for thyroidectomy. The surgeon uses the following instrument during the procedure to hold and ligate the superior thyroid pedicle. What is the name of the given instrument?
questions.solution:
Option A: Kocher’s thyroid dissector

  • The above-given image shows Kocher’s thyroid dissector.
  • During a thyroidectomy, Kocher's thyroid dissector is used to secure and ligate the superior pedicle of the thyroid, which contains the superior thyroid artery.
  • Its blunt tip, which has an eye, is inserted beneath the superior thyroid pedicle, and a suture, similar to an aneurysm forceps, is threaded through the eye.
  • Three sutures are then ligated close to the gland.

Option B: Doyen’s Rib Raspatory

  • The Doyen’s rib raspatory is a specialist cardiothoracic device used by surgeons to scrape bone and other hard tissues of the ribs to smooth the edges of the chosen bone and expand the surgical approach.

Option C: Joll’s thyroid Retractor

  • The Joll’s self-retaining retractor is a speciality surgical tool used for challenging incision sites.
  • It is commonly used for thyroid and vaginal procedures due to its unusual form, which allows it to access these anatomical locations more effectively.

Option D: Deaver’s Retractor

  • The Deaver Retractor is a large, portable retractor frequently used to hold the abdominal wall back during abdominal or thoracic surgeries.
  • It can also be used to transfer or restrain organs from the surgical site.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents for routine pap smear. The result shows high grade squamous intraepithelial lesion following which a colposcopy directed biopsy is performed which reveals a CIN III. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
When a cytologic specimen suggests the presence of HSIL, colposcopy and directed biopsy should be performed. Although high-grade CIN can be treated with a variety of techniques, the preferred treatment for CIN 2 and 3 is loop electrosurgical excision procedure.

Hysterectomy is currently considered too radical for treatment of CIN, however may be offered in presence of a concurrent indication.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the physician preconceptionally for advice. She is a known epileptic on anticonvulsant therapy with phenytoin for 10 years. She has been well controlled on therapy and her last seizure was 8 years ago. She and her partner have been using contraceptive pills for the past two years but have now stopped use. She has no other significant medical history and has regular menses. Examinations show BP 122/78 mmHg, PR 105/min, systemic and abdominal examination is unremarkable. What is the most appropriate preconceptional counselling for this patient?

choices.text: Should not attempt a pregnancy and opt for adoption or surrogacy instead as epilepsy causes fetal malformations
Increase the dose of phenytoin due to high risk of seizures in pregnancy
Folate supplementation and consider switching to levetiracitam
Add another anticonvulsant to reduce chances of seizures in pregnancy

questions.solution:
Anticonvulsants like phenytoin and phenobarbitone are folate antagonists and are known to cause neural tube defects in the fetus, thus folate supplementation with 4 mg/day must be done.

EPILEPSY IN PREGNANCY

Anticonvulsant therapy

  • Lowest dose monotherapy is the goal. Multidrug therapy increases risk of malformations. It is preferable to increase dose if needed than add another drug
  • AED (Antiepileptic Drugs) : phenetoin, phenobarbitol, and sodium valproate are known teratogens with known fetal malformation risk. A consideration to switch to lamotrigine and leveteracitam should be made which have lowest risk of malformation. Most antiepileptics are safe with breastfeeding

Pregnancy related risks

  • increased seizure rates: upto 20-30%. This has two important causes:
  • lower seizure threshold
  • subtherapeutic anticonvulsant levels
  • fetal malformations: more likely due to anticonvulsant than epilepsy itself

pregnancy complications

  • spontaneous abortions
  • APH and PPH
  • hypertensive disorders
  • preterm birth
  • IUGR
  • cesarean delivery

- Antiepileptic drugs like phenytoin are folate antagonists, folate supplementation with 4 mg/day should be started, most congenital malformations are due to these drugs rather than epilepsy. Lowest dose monotherapy should be the goal and safer anticonvulsants like levetiracetam and lamotrigine must be used after consultation with the neurologist.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male, with history of myocardial infarction two years ago and coronary artery bypass surgery for stable angina one year ago, was admitted to hospital for uncomplicated right carotid endarterectomy. Patient was prescribed Ramipril. Which of the following effects should be considered most in this patient?
questions.solution:
Management of cardiovascular and peripheral vascular disease requires optimal blood pressure control. Although no specific agent is recommended, ACE inhibitors do have established benefits in this patient population. The HOPE trial demonstrated that ACE inhibitors decrease blood pressure as well as risk of cardiovascular events (MI, stroke, death) in high-risk patients with cardiovascular and peripheral vascular disease.

Patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular and peripheral vascular disease can also develop renovascular disease manifesting as renal artery stenosis. Patients with renal artery stenosis are dependent on ACE mediated efferent arteriole constriction to maintain renal perfusion and GFR. Use of ACE inhibitors can block this effect leading to decreased renal perfusion and thus ARF. Therefore ACR inhibitors are contraindicated in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis and unilateral stenosis in a solitary functioning kidney. So although patients with extensive atherosclerosis do benefit from ACE inhibitors, it is important to consider the presence of bilateral renal artery stenosis before initiating ACE inhibitor therapy.

Choice A: for aortic regurgitation, ACE inhibitors have been shown to decrease left ventricular volume on some studies and are widely prescribed.

Choice B: in patients with iliofemoral occlusive disorder, ACE inhibitors may be of significant benefit. Based on the HOPE trial, ACE inhibitors decrease blood pressure as well as risk of cardiovascular events (MI, stroke, death) in high-risk patients with cardiovascular and peripheral vascular disease.

Choice D: ACE inhibitors have been shown to reduce infarct expansion and progressive left ventricular remodelling in post infarction left ventricular aneurysm and thus have an established therapeutic role.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male into your private clinic with involuntary movements. You suspect a metabolic abnormality and orders a experimental radioisotope study of his brain, in order to localize the metabolic abnormality in his brain. The study revealed abnormal metabolic activity in the caudate nucleus. A slide of cross section of the brain is given below, which marked structure corresponds to the location of the abnormality?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the above mention case is Huntington’s disease. It is an autosomal dominant condition, due to an excessive number of CAG trinucleotide repeats as compared to the normal individual. The families with this disease experience a process called anticipation, which is progressive expansion of the trinucleotide repeats in successful generations. Imaging study shows atrophy of the caudate and metabolic imaging study shows, decreased metabolic activity in the striatum (caudate and putamen)

Choice A- the caudate nucleus is a curved or ‘C ‘shaped structure in its complete form. The head of the caudate nucleus is separated from the globus pallidus and putamen by the internal capsule

Chocie B- internal capsule. Globus pallidus and putamen are separated from the thalamus by posterior limb of the internal capsule, which carries the corticospinal motor and somatic sensory fibers. The genu or ‘knee’ of the internal capsule lies between the anterior and posterior branches and carries corticobulbar fibers.

Choice C- insular cortex (insula). this plays a important role in the limbic system.

Choice D- putamen

Choice E- globus pallidus

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Estramustine?

choices.text: Is a combination of estradiol coupled to normustine
Estramustine functions  in vivo as an alkylating agent and destroys DNA of cancer cells
Used only for the treatment of metastatic or locally advanced hormone-refractory prostate cancer

questions.solution:
Estramustine

·   is a combination of estradiol coupled to normustine through a carbamate link

·   has weaker estrogenic and antineoplastic activity than estradiol and other alkylating agents

·   Although the intent of the combination was to enhance the uptake of the alkylating agent into estradiol sensitive prostate cancer cells

·   Estramustine does not function in vivo as an alkylating agent but rather binds to β tubulin and microtubule-associated proteins, causing microtubule disassembly and antimitotic actions

·   used solely for the treatment of metastatic or locally advanced hormone-refractory prostate cancer

questions.text: A woman at 16 weeks pregnancy tests positive for COVID. Which of the following is TRUE regarding clinical manifestations of COVID 19 in pregnant women?

choices.text: Higher chances of high-grade fever compared to non-pregnant women of same age
Higher chances of more severe disease in early pregnancy
Less likely to need invasive ventilation than non-pregnant women

questions.solution:
Clinical manifestations of COVID 19 in pregnancy

  • Most commonly asymptomatic
  • Most common manifestations in symptomatic women are mild-moderate cold or flu like symptoms such as fever and cough. Less frequently, dyspnea, myalgia, diarrhea.
  • Pregnant women are less likely to have fever or myalgia than non pregnant women of same age
  • Severe symptoms of pneumonia and marked hypoxia are more common in older, immunocompromised and those with chronic conditions like diabetes, cancer, chronic lun disease and uncommon in young women of reproductive age.
  • Severe illness is more common in late pregnancy
  • ICU admission and mechanical ventilation are more likely in pregnant women than non pregnant, however this finding has low level of evidence and must be interpreted with caution.
  • Increased risk of maternal mortality than non pregnant women is still unclear

questions.text: A 34 years male presented to opd with pain abdomen, nausea and vomiting since 3 hrs. Pain is radiating to back. USG shows multiple renal stones . Blood investigations reveal increased serum cystine levels. Urinalysis shows hexagonal shaped crystals. All of following are indicated in treatment of this case scenario except?
questions.solution:
• The clinical diagnosis of profile given in the question is CYSTINURIA.
  • Cystinuria- AR, defect in re-absorptive transport of cystine and the dibasic amino acids ornithine, arginine, and lysine from the luminal fluid of the renal proximal tubule and small intestine.
  • Urinalysis- hexagonal shaped crystals: pathognomonic of cystinuria.
  • The foundation of cystine stone prevention is adequate hydration and urinary alkalinization.
  • When this conservative therapy fails, the addition of drugs, such as D-penicillamine and captopril.

→ The clinical profile should not be confused with Cystinosis which is treated with Cysteamine.

questions.text: During the latter stages of pregnancy, many women experience an increase in body hair growth in a masculine pattern. What is the explanation for this phenomenon?

choices.text: The ovaries secrete some testosterone along with the large amounts of estrogen produced late in pregnancy
The fetal ovaries and testes secrete androgenic steroids
The maternal and fetal adrenal glands secrete large amounts of androgenic steroids that are used by the placenta to form estrogen
The placenta secretes large amounts of estrogen, some of which is metabolized to testosterone

questions.solution: Estrogen secreted by the placenta is not synthesized from basic substrates in the placenta. Instead, it is formed almost entirely from androgenic steroid compounds that are formed in the adrenal glands of both the mother and the fetus. These androgenic compounds are transported by the blood to the placenta and converted by the trophoblast cells to estrogen compounds. Their concentration in the maternal blood may also stimulate hair growth on the body

questions.text: A 73-year-old man, mechanically ventilated for confirmed COVID-19, showed clinical and radiographic signs of a perforated duodenal ulcer, and he was transferred under sedation and intubation to a negative-pressure operating room for Emergency exploratory laparotomy. A neuromuscular blocker that has an ultrashort duration of action, no hepatic or renal involvement, and metabolized by cysteine adduction, reversal with sugammadex was selected for this patient. The neuromuscular blocker used in this patient would be
questions.solution:
? Gantacurium was the first compound of this new class of neuromuscular blocking drugs, the asymmetric mixed-onium chlorofumarates.

? Gantacurium is an asymmetric enantiomeric isoquinolinium diester of chlorofumaric acid. Gantacurium, like cisatracurium, is a single isomer as atracurium and mivacurium are consisting of a mixture of isomers.

? Gantacurium is an ultra-short acting non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking drug with a rapid onset and a wide safety margin. As cisatracurium and atracurium are inactivated by Hofmann elimination, gantacurium is metabolized by chemical degradation which involves cysteine adduction (fast process) and pH-sensitive hydrolysis (slow process).

? Cysteine adduction results in the replacement of chlorine by cysteine where a heterocyclic ring is formed which can no longer interact with the post-junctional acetylcholine receptor. Therefore, the metabolites of gantacurium showed no neuromuscular properties.

? Moreover, there is no renal and hepatic involvement in the elimination of gantacurium.

? Reversal of a gantacurium-induced neuromuscular block is possible with the administration of L-cysteine

? This first drug in class showed promising results in animal and human studies which will be discussed.

questions.text: Trypsin is a serine protease which cleave proteins by addition of water. In a polypeptide, it will act and cleave at the carboxy terminal of which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
Trypsin cleaves a polypeptide at the carboxy terminal of Basic amino acids (Arginine, Lysine).

EXTRA READING ON THIS TOPIC

Serine proteases:

  • Proteolytic enzymes with serine at their active site.
  • Amino acid triad in the active site of serine proteases - Serine, Histidine, Aspartate.

Examples of serine proteases: Chymotrypsin, Trypsin, Elastase, Thrombin, Plasmin, Complements, Factors X and XI

Serine Proteases differ in substrate specificity

Chymotrypsin: Cleaves at Carboxy terminal of bulky Hydrophobic amino acids (Tryptophan, Tyrosine, Phenylalanine)

Elastase: Cleaves at Carboxy terminal of small Neutral amino acids e.g. Glycine, Alanine

questions.text: A 59 Yr old patient presented to OPD with complains of weakness and fatigue, dyspnea on lying down and palpitations. Symptoms aggravate at night time when he tries to sleep at bed. He gives h/o of Rheumatic heart disease in past . O/E - BP = 120/ 80 mm Hg, Pulse = 90bpm , elevated JVP, Hyperdynamic Apex beat with apical thrill on palpation. ECHO was done which revealed Mitral regurgitation. A diagnosis of Chronic Mitral regurgitation was made. Which of following is false regarding Chronic Mitral Regurgitation?
questions.solution:
• Narrow split S1 is a feature of mitral Stenosis. Choice D is incorrect.
  • In case of Mitral Regurgitation, the extra blood that flows into left atrium has to come back to left ventricle during diastolic phase. This leads to mid diastolic murmur .Choice A is Correct.
  • Due to early A2, wide Split S2 is heard. Choice B is correct
  • The most characteristic auscultatory finding is grade 3/6 pansystolic murmur. Choice C is correct.

Chronic MR features

  • S1 = soft
  • S2 = Wide split = Early A2
  • S3++
  • S4++ = extreme LV dilatation
  • Opening snap = absent
  • Primary murmur = Pansystolic = Apex = High pitch = Radiating to Interscapular area or Axilla
  • Secondary murmur = severe MR = Mid-diastolic murmur

questions.text: Training is given to an ANM worker. Now you have to check her ability to do immunization. You are the medical officer. She is having cotton, lunch box and syringe-needle after immunization of a child. Which of the following is true?

choices.text: Syringe with needle in translucent White container
Used Vial in translucent White container

questions.solution:
Cotton swab is a soiled waste and so it will be thrown into yellow bag according to the Biomedical waste management disposal guidelines currently followed in India.

There are 4 types of colour coded biomedical waste management bags in India

Yellow Bag Red Bag White Bag(Puncture proof) Blue Bag

Human anatomical waste

Animal Waste

Soiled Waste

Medications

Liquid chemical waste

Microbiological waste

 Contaminated/Recyclable Waste Waste sharp Material

Glassware

Metallic Implants

questions.text: A 22-year-old male has presented to the emergency after being involved in a motorcycle crash. His arm is hanging by his side listless. X-rays show no fracture or dislocation. The registrar on-call suspects a brachial plexus injury. As there are many patients in the emergency, he gives the resident only 2 minutes to evaluate all the motor functions of the brachial plexus. Which of the following innervations is wrong?
questions.solution: Knowing the innervations of key muscle functions allows for a rapid assessment of any patient. As the brachial plexus consists of nerves originating from C5 to T1, the muscle functions can be tested in a rapid sequence to triage a possible neurological injury.

questions.text: The depicted instrument can be used for all of the following procedures except?
questions.solution: Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA) Syringe and cannula for first trimester MTP. It can also be used for incomplete or missed abortion up to 12 weeks and also for endometrial biopsy. After 10-12 weeks, the fetal products are large and bony and hence this may have a high chance of retained products if used.

questions.text: A 9 kg old child had a fever spike on day 3 of surgery and is mistakenly administered 10 times the recommended dose of paracetamol. What is the antidote to be administered in such a case?
questions.solution:
• When a toxic amount of acetaminophen is ingested, the first two processes are overwhelmed and more acetaminophen is metabolized by the cytochrome P450 system to a hepatotoxic metabolite (N-acetyl-p-benzoquinoneimine, NAPQI).
  • In therapeutic acetaminophen ingestions, the liver generates glutathione, which detoxifies NAPQI.
  • However, in overdose, the glutathione is depleted, leaving the metabolite to produce toxicity.
  • The antidote for acetaminophen toxicity,

N-acetylcysteine (NAC), initially works as a glutathione precursor and glutathione substitute and assists with sulfation.

OPTION 1,3 :Amyl nitrite, Hydroxocobalamin are used in case of Cyanide poisoning.

OPTION 4 : BZD poisoning can be treated with specific antidote, flumazenil.

questions.text: All are true regarding the vector shown in the image except

choices.text: The vector shown here is also known as Nuisance mosquito
Larva rest parallel to surface of water
It is responsible for transmission of malaria

questions.solution:
1. The vector shown here is ANOPHELES and is also known as SOPHISTICATED MOSQUITO [ Nuisance mosquito is the other name for Culex mosquito]
  2. TRUE STATEMENT
  3. TRUE STATEMENT
  4. TRUE STATEMENT

questions.text: A 9-month-old male child is brought to the physician by his mother with complaints of short arms and legs. She further gives a history of the progressively enlarging head. There is no past personal or family history of any chronic illness. The examination of the patient shows macrocephaly, prominent brow bones, and short extremities. The muscle power is 3/5 throughout. An x-ray of the skull shows midfacial hypoplasia and frontal prominence. Which of the following can also be seen in the patient’s current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option B: Champagne glass pelvis

  • This is a case of achondroplasia in which the patient is brought to the physician with complaints of short legs and arms.

  • The patient is also having a progressively enlarging head.

  • The patient has no history of any chronic illness.

  • The examination of the patient shows macrocephaly, prominent brow bones and short extremities.

  • The muscle power of the child is 3/5 throughout.

  • An x-ray of the skull shows mid-facial hypoplasia and frontal prominence.

  • Achondroplasia- trident hand, short stature, champagne glass pelvis on x-ray.

Option A: Wrist splaying

  • Wrist widening or splaying is seen in rickets.

  • Fraying & cupping are also seen in rickets.

Option C: Marble bone disease

  • Marble bone disease is also known as osteopetrosis.

  • It is called marble bone disease because bone appears pitched white because of an increase in the density of the bone.

Option D: Wimberger sign

  • Wimberger sign is seen in scurvy.

  • Pencil-thin outline of the cortex and subperiosteal haemorrhage are also seen in scurvy.

questions.text: A radiologist is writing an article on effective doses of different investigating modalities. He finds out that the radiation dose of a CT is more than a chest X-ray. What is the SI unit of an effective dose?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option D: Sievert

  • Effective dose is a dose quantity in the International Commission on Radiological Protection (ICRP) system of radiological protection.

  • The SI unit for effective dose is the sievert (Sv) which represents a 5.5% chance of developing cancer.

UNITS OF RADIATION

Physical quantity

S.I. Unit

Non-S.I. Unit

Conversion

Radioactivity

Becquerel (Bq)

Curie (Ci)

1 Ci = 3.7 X 1010 Bq

Absorbed dose

Gray (Gy)

Rad

1 Gy = 100 rads

1 rad = 0.01 gy

Dose equivalent

Sievert (SV)

Rem

1 SV = 100 rem

1 Rem = 0.01 Sv

kerma

Gray

Read

 

Effective dose

Sv

Rem

 

Exposure

coulomb/kg

Roentgen

1R= 2.58 x 10-4coulomb/kg of air

Option A: Becquerel

  • Becquerel is the SI unit of radioactivity

  • One becquerel is defined as the activity of a quantity of radioactive material in which one nucleus decays per second.

Option B: Gray

  • Gray is the SI unit of Kerma, defined as the sum of the initial kinetic energies of all the charged particles liberated by uncharged ionizing radiation in a sample of matter per unit of mass

  • It is used as a unit of the radiation quantity absorbed dose that measures the energy deposited by ionizing radiation in a unit mass of matter being irradiated

  • It is used for measuring the delivered dose in radiotherapy, food irradiation, and radiation sterilization.

Option C: Rem

  • Rem is the non-SI unit of effective dose, a unit of the radiation dose applied to humans.

  • The rem is defined as the dosage in rads that will cause the same amount of physical injury as one rad of X-rays or gamma rays.

  • 1 Rem=0.01Sv

questions.text: During the autopsy of the body brought in for examination by the medical officer, he documented some of the findings in association with Puppe's rule. What type of injury is the doctor documenting about?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Multiple impact injuries:

  • Multiple impact injuries of the skull are associated with Puppe's rule .

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sexual assault: Sexual assault does not associate with Puppe's rule.

Option C - Chemical injuries: Chemical injuries do not associate with Puppe's rule.

Option D - Percentage of burns: Burn injuries do not associate with Puppe's rule.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male with Down’s syndrome is brought to the OPD with neck pain for orthopedic review. The surgeon wants to review the atlantoaxial instability. Which of the following CAN’T be used for radiological review of this condition?
questions.solution:
Radiographic evidence of atlantooccipital instability is not as well defined as that for atlantoaxial instability, but the measurements described by Wackenheim, Wiesel and Rothman, Powers and Tredwell et al. are helpful.

The Ranawat line doesn’t exist. Ranawat criterion is used to determine basilar settling in Rheumatoid arthritis.

Radiographic screening for atlantoaxial instability in Down syndrome patients is controversial. Routine screening in pre-school patients and re-screening every decade had been recommended in the past but the present AAP guidelines stress the inability for screening radiographs or predict any future risk of developing atlantoaxial instability.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents to the pulmonology outpatient department with complaints of hemoptysis and hematuria for four days. He is a known case of chronic renal disease. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations are unremarkable. The lab studies of the patient show the presence of anti-basement membrane antibodies. The patient underwent plasmapheresis & her symptoms improved. Which of the following disease is of the same hypersensitivity category as the disease involved in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Myasthenia gravis

  • This is a case of Good pasture's syndrome in which the patient presents with complaints of hemoptysis and hematuria for four days.

  • Myasthenia gravis is in the same hypersensitivity category as this disease.

  • The given scenario suggests the diagnosis of Good pasture's syndrome: Anti-glomerular basement membrane disease- anti-basement membrane antibodies specific for collagen in glomerular and pulmonary basement membranes.

  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease categorized as a type II hypersensitivity involving autoantibodies binding acetylcholine receptors on skeletal muscle cells.

  • Good pasture's syndrome and Myasthenia gravis are type II hypersensitivity reactions.

Option A: Systemic lupus erythematosus

  • Systemic lupus erythematosus is a type III hypersensitivity reaction.

Option B: Seasonal allergies

  • Seasonal allergies are caused due to type I hypersensitivity reactions.

Option D: Poison ivy rash

  • Poison ivy rash is caused due to type IV hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.text: A seventy-year-old male is brought to your clinic for loss of vision and whiteness in his eyes. His loss of vision was gradual, and his son says that it seems like there is a pearl in his eyes. You explain the concept of cataracts and the surgery required to restore vision. Which of the following is true regarding the phakonit technique for cataract surgery?

choices.text: Rollable intraocular lenses are not used

questions.solution:
Option B: 1 mm incision is given

  • The term phakonit is derived from phacoemulsification (phako) being done with a needle (N) through an incision (I) and with the phaco tip (T).
  • This technique emulsifies a cataract lens through a 0.9 mm clear corneal temporal incision.
  • Sub 1 mm incision is done.
  • Very minimal astigmatism is the advantage.
  • Phaco tip does not include an infusion sleeve to reduce the size of the tip.
  • Infusion is done with an 18G needle in the left hand with a bend at the tip to make it like a chopper to enable proper phacoemulsification.
  • Rollable intraocular lenses are put inside through enlarging incision to a sub 2 mm incision.
  • A clear corneal incision is made.
  • Dr Amar Agarwal first described this technique.

Option A: Femtolaser is used

  • Femtolaser is not used in phakonit technique.

Option C: More chances of astigmatism

  • There is less chance of astigmatism with phakonit technique.

Option D: Rollable intraocular lenses are not used

  • Rollable intraocular lenses are used in the phakonit technique.

questions.text:
A 45 years old female presents to your OPD with symptoms of paralysis of one side of the face associated with difficulty in closing eyelids and smiling. There are no other abnormalities. The patient is vitally stable. You made a provisional diagnosis of Bell's palsy. Which of the following test will be used as full diagnostic tests of the facial nerve?


	Schirmer test
	Tympanometry
	Taste test
	Salivary flow test
questions.solution:
Option B: Only 1, 3, and 4 are correct

  • It is the correct option.
  • It is a case of Bell's palsy, which is caused due to lesion of the facial nerve.
  • Following are the 3 tests used as a full diagnostic for facial nerves.
    • Schirmer test.
    • Taste test.
    • Salivary flow test.
  • Schirmer's test determines whether the eye produces enough tears to keep it moist. This test is used when a person experiences very dry eyes or excessive watering of the eyes.
  • Taste tests can be tested using salty, bitter, or sweet solutions. The tongue is protruded and held gently by the examiner.
  • A small sample of the solution is applied to one side of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue using a cotton-tipped applicator saturated with the solution. With the tongue still protruding, the patient should be asked to point to a sign displaying one of the four possible tastes.
  • The patient is then given a small sip. Salivary flow is assessed by asking the patient to expect all saliva possible over 15 minutes without gustatory provocation. A volume of <1.5 mL of saliva in 15 min is considered abnormal.

Option A: Only 2 is correct

  • It is an incorrect option because statement 2 is tympanometry which is not used as a diagnostic test for facial nerve injury.
  • Tympanometry is a test used to assess whether there is fluid or infection in the tympanic membrane or middle ear. So, according to our case, this is an incorrect statement.

Option C: Only 2, 3, and 4 are correct

  • It is an incorrect option because statement 2 is tympanometry which is not used as a diagnostic test for facial nerve injury.

Option D: Only 1, 2, and 3 are correct

  • It is an incorrect option because statement 2 is tympanometry which is not used as a diagnostic test for facial nerve injury.
  • Tympanometry is a test used to assess whether there is fluid or infection in the tympanic membrane or middle ear. So, according to our case, this is an incorrect statement.

questions.text: A seventy-five-year-old male presents to your clinic with complaints of a decrease in his memory. He states he cannot remember the names of the new people he meets. The patient also says he feels no emotions, even for his close relatives, and sometimes has depressive thoughts. Investigations reveal that the person is in an early stage of Alzheimer's disease. Overactivation of caspases causes the destruction of neural cells, which is seen in Alzheimer's. Which of the following is a characteristic of caspases?

choices.text: It is an alanine protease in nature
Exists as zymogens and undergo cleavage to get activated
Independent of proapoptotic and antiapoptotic proteins

questions.solution:
Option B: Exists as zymogens and undergo cleavage to get activated

  • Caspases are a  group of enzymes involved in programmed cell death.
  • The activation of caspase enzymes causes apoptosis.
  • The stages of apoptosis are as follows:
    • Initiation phase in which some caspases become catalytically active
    • Execution phase in which other caspases trigger the degradation of critical cellular components
  • Caspases are inactive proenzymes, or zymogens, that must be cleaved by an enzyme to become active.
  • The presence of cleaved, active caspases is a sign that a cell is about to die.

Option A: It is an alanine protease in nature

  • Caspases are cysteine proteases in nature.
  • They are also called cysteine-aspartic proteases.

Option C: Independent of proapoptotic and antiapoptotic proteins

  • The activation of caspases depends on a finely tuned balance between the production of proapoptotic and antiapoptotic proteins.
  • Apoptosis is a highly controlled process.

Option D: Not required for embryogenesis

  • Caspases are required for embryogenesis.
  • They are involved in the following:
    • Implantation
    • Organogenesis
    • Developmental involution
    • Metamorphosis

questions.text:
Consider the following statements:-
The term ‘disease control’ describes ongoing operations aimed at reducing the
1. Incidence of disease
2. Financial burden to the community
3. Effects of infection including both physical and psychological complications
4. Duration of disease and its transmission
Of all these statements,
questions.solution:
• Disease control primarily refers to ‘primary and secondary levels’ of prevention
  • Disease control’ describes ongoing operations aimed at reducing the Incidence of disease, Financial burden to the community, Effects of infection, Duration of disease and its transmission

questions.text:
Arrange the structures from behind forwards crossing the linea terminalis:-
A) Internal iliac vessels.
B) Ureter.
C) Ovarian vessels in suspensory ligament of ovary
D) Vas deferens or round ligament of uterus
questions.solution:
Anterior 1/3rd of medial border of ilium forms a rounded arcuate line which is continuous infront with pectineal line of pubis at ilio pubic eminence. Arcuate line along with pectineal line and pubic crest form the linea terminalis. Linea terminalis forms the lateral boundary of pelvic inlet and is crossed by (behind forwards):

  1. Internal iliac vessels.
  2. Ureter.
  3. Ovarian vessels in suspensory ligament of ovary (in females)
  4. Vas deferens or round ligament of uterus.
  5. Obliterated umbilical artery.
  6. Median umbilical artery.

questions.text: A 36 years old woman recently treated for leukemia is admitted to the hospital with malaise, chills and high fever. Gram stain of blood reveals the presence of gram negative bacilli. The initial diagnosis is bacteremia and parenteral antibiotics are indicated. The record of the patient reveals that she had severe urticarial rash, hypotension and respiratory difficulty after oral pencillin V about 6 months ago. The most appropriate drug should be:
questions.solution:
Cross allergy : Individual allergic to one penicillin are also allergic to other beta lactam antibiotic except MONOBACTAMS.

Aztreonam is a monobactam antibiotic which donot show cross allergy and effective only against Gm-ve bacteria including gpseudomonas. Aztreonam is relatively nontoxic, but it may cause phlebitis, skin rash and, occasionally, abnormal liver function tests. This drug has a low immunogenic potential, and it shows little cross-reactivity with antibodies induced by other β-lactams. Thus, this drug may offer a safe alternative for treating patients who are allergic to other penicillins, cephalosporins, or carbapenems.

questions.text:
All of them are true in ocular ischemic syndrome except :
1. It occurs when the carotid artery obstruction reaches 90%
2.Typically affects younger patients
3.Delayed recovery of vision following bright light exposure is seen
4.Dull pain in orbital region which worsens on getting up
5. NVI is never seen
questions.solution:
Ocular ischaemic syndrome(OIS) results from chronic ocular hypoperfusion secondary to severe( more than 90%) ipsilateral atherosclerotic carotid stenosis.It typically affects older patients and may be associated with diabetes, hypertension, cardio-and cerebrovascular disease.

1. Symptoms are: Gradual loss of vision or sometimes amurosis fugax. Dull orbital pain worsens on getting up as perfusion furthur decreases. Delayed recovery of vision following bright light exposure is seen known as bright light amurosis fugax.

2. NVI ocurrs in 90% cases in ocular ischemic syndrome.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife due to high-grade fever, dyspnea, chills, and fatigue for the last 3 days. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Cardiac auscultation reveals a holosystolic murmur at the apex. Physical examination reveals painless, flat, and red lesions on the soles. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Infective endocarditis

  • Infective endocarditis (IE) is an infection of the endocardium that can involve one or more heart valves.
  • Common causative organisms of infective endocarditis include:

Pathogen

Association

Streptococcus viridans (Subacute IE)

Dental procedures

Staphylococcus aureus (Acute IE)

IV drug abuser

Staphylococcus epidermidis

Prosthetic heart valves

Streptococcus gallolyticus

Colorectal cancer

Enterococcus

Gastrointestinal and gastrourinary procedures

Candida albicans

Immunocompromised and IV drug users

Gram-negative HACEK organisms

  • Haemophilus
  • Aggregatibacter
  • Cardiobacterium
  • Eikenella 
  • Kingella
  
  • Pathophysiology:
    • It starts with damage to the endothelium of the valves leading to adherence of platelets and fibrin to the valve (sterile vegetation).
    • Later in the case of bacteremia, bacteria in the blood colonise this sterile vegetation causing further damage and functional loss of the valve.
    • Mitral valve is the most commonly involved valve in infective endocarditis.
  • Clinical features:
    • Fever
    • Tachycardia
    • Septic emboli
    • Roth spots (retinal haemorrhages with pale centre)
    • Janeway lesions (painless, red macules on palms and soles)
    • Osler nodes (painful raised nodules on fingers and toes)
    • Heart murmur depending upon the valve involvement
    • Splinter haemorrhages
    • Arthritis
    • Neurological manifestations
    • Pulmonary embolic
  • Diagnosis:
    • Diagnosis is made with the help of Duke criteria that requires multiple blood cultures and echocardiography (valvular vegetation, abscess, and regurgitation).

MAJOR CRITERIA

Persistently +ve blood culture for typical organisms

ECHO: vegetation, dehiscence, abscess

New valvular regurgitation murmur

Coxiella burnetii infection

DEFINITE ENDOCARDITIS

2 major clinical criteria

1 major & any 3 minor clinical criteria

5 minor clinical criteria

Histological findings

+ve Gram stain or cultures from surgery or autopsy

MINOR CRITERIA
Predisposing heart condition or IV drug use

Fever

Vascular: emboli to organs / brain, hemorhages

Immunologic: glomerulonephritis, Osler's nodes, Roth spots, rheumatoid factor

Positive blood cultures that do not meet

specific criteria

POSSIBLE ENDOCARDITIS

1 major and >1 minor clinical criteria

3 minor clinical criteria

 

REJECTED ENDOCARDITIS

Resolution within <4 days of Abx

Alternate diagnosis is made

No evidence of IE found at surgery or autopsy (after antibiotic therapy for ≤4 days)

Definite or possible criteria not met
  • Treatment consists of: Antibiotics depending upon the blood culture results.
    • Surgery in case of large vegetation, medication failure, difficulty in eradicating the bacteria, abscess, heart block, and fistula.

Option A: Acute rheumatic fever

  • Group A streptococcal infection causes rheumatic fever, which is characterised by:
    • Migratory polyarthritis
    • Pancarditis
    • Subcutaneous nodules
    • Erythema marginatum
    • Sydenham chorea

Option B: Myocarditis

  • Myocarditis can be caused by bacterial, viral, and parasitic infections. Other causes include drugs, toxins, and autoimmune diseases.
  • It can lead to dilated cardiomyopathy, heart failure, cardiac arrhythmias, and sudden cardiac death.

Option C: Acute pericarditis

  • Acute pericarditis is characterised by
    • Fever
    • Sharp chest pain that increases on inspiration and decreases on leaning forward
    • Diffuse ST elevation and PR depression on ECG

Which of the following statements are true regarding fungi?
1) Yeasts are unicellular fungi
2) Candida form pseudomycelium
3) Dermatophytes are filamentous fungi
4) Dimorphic fungi behave as molds in cultures at 37°C
questions.solution:
Dimorphic fungi show typical thermal dimorphism

They are hyaline septate molds at 25°C and yeast at 37°C.

  • Histoplasma capsulatum
  • Blastomyces dermatitidis
  • Sporothrix schenkii
  • Coccidioides immitis
  • Paracoccidioides brasiliensis
  • Penicillium marneffei

questions.text: A 12-year-old female presents to the neurology ward with a complaint of headache. She also complains of visual impairment but does not complain of photophobia. After a thorough assessment, a diagnosis of craniopharyngioma is made. The biopsy of the lesion confirms an adamantinomatous variant of craniopharyngioma. Which of the following is the least likely feature of this variant?

choices.text: Nests and cords of squamous epithelium embedded in the spongy reticulum
Papillae lined by well-differentiated squamous epithelium

questions.solution:
Option D: Papillae lined by well-differentiated squamous epithelium

  • The papillary variant is associated with papillae that are lined by well-differentiated squamous cell epithelium

Craniopharyngioma:

Description:

  • A relatively benign dysontogenetic tumour arising from a remnant of the Rathke pouch (ectodermal derivative)

Epidemiology

  • Bimodal distribution: 5–14 years; second peak at 50–75 years
  • Most common childhood supratentorial tumour

Clinical features:

  • The tumour arises in the suprasellar region and can extend into the intrasellar region.
  • Compression of the pituitary gland due to intrasellar extension → hypopituitarism
  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism
  • Failure to thrive
  • Central diabetes insipidus
  • Compression of the ventromedial hypothalamic nucleus → hyperphagia and obesity
  • Compression of the infundibular stalk → disconnection hyperprolactinemia
  • Compression of the optic chiasm → bitemporal hemianopsia
  • Compression of interventricular foramina and/or aqueduct → obstructive hydrocephalus

Diagnostics

  • Imaging: suprasellar calcified cyst with a lobulated contour
  • Biopsy: cholesterol crystals found in a motor oil-like fluid on gross examination

Histological variants

Adamantinomatous (common)

  • Reticular epithelial cells
  • Frequently associated with calcifications
  • Cysts and keratin nodules

Papillary

  • Metaplastic squamous cells
  • Calcifications and cysts are rare.
  • No keratin nodules

Treatment

  • Resection Adjuvant radiotherapy In the case of hypopituitarism: hormone replacement therapy

Option A: Nests and cords of squamous epithelium embedded in the spongy reticulum

  • The adamantinomatous variant comprises nests and cords of the squamous cell epithelium.

Option B: Compact, lamellar keratin formation ("wet keratin")

  • Wet keratin is one of the features of the adanmantinomatous variant of the craniopharyngioma

Option C: Dystrophic calcification and cholesterol crystals

  • Craniopharyngioma is one of the causes of dystrophic calcified masses.
  • It also has cholesterol crystals

questions.text: According to the report (2020) of the United Nations Development Programme entitled "Charting pathways out of multidimensional poverty", the incidence of multidimensional poverty in India was 27.9% in 2015–2016. The government accorded high priority to the issue of malnutrition problems resulting from this poverty and launched POSHAN Abhiyan. Which of the following statements about 'POSHAN' Abhiyan are true?

choices.text: Launched by the Prime minister in March 2018
It is the Prime Minister’s overarching scheme for holistic poverty
The focus is on health and nutrition in the first 200 days of life
Goals for this program include a reduction in unemployment and poverty

questions.solution:
Option A: Launched by the Prime minister in March 2018

  • Poshan Abhiyaan was launched in 2018  by the Government of India to tackle the malnutrition problem.
  • It is also known as the National Nutrition Mission (NNM).
  • It was implemented in 2017.
  • The mission is a multi-ministerial initiative that aims to eliminate malnutrition in the country by 2022.
  • Poshan Abhiyaan is India's flagship scheme to improve the nutritional outcomes of adolescents, children, pregnant women and lactating mothers
  • According to 'Mission 25 by 2020', the National Nutrition Mission aims to reduce stunting from 38.4% to 25% by 2022.

Option B: It is Prime Minister’s overarching scheme for holistic poverty

  • It is the prime minister's scheme against holistic malnutrition.
  • Poverty can lead to malnutrition.

Option C: The focus is on health and nutrition in the first 200 days of life

  • The focus is on health and nutrition in the first 1000 days of life.
  • This duration is most significant and has an impact on later life.

Option D: Goals for this program include a reduction in unemployment and poverty

  • The goals for this program include a reduction in stunting, undernutrition & low birth weight by 2% per annum and anaemia in young children by 3% per annum

questions.text: A 60-year-old male came with complaint of recurrent episodes of retrosternal chest pain. Such episodes occur when he climbs stairs or do some other physical activity, and pain gets relieved upon taking a sublingual tablet. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the drug?
questions.solution:
In this clinical setting, the most likely drug used is nitroglycerine to relieve symptoms of angina pectoris.

In patients with stable angina, the main contributory effect of nitrates is to the decrease in cardiac preload by causing venous dilatation and venous retention of blood. This also decreases cardiac workload and myocardial oxygen demand. Nitrates also have modest arteriolar dilation effects on coronary arterioles. Through systemic arteriolar dilatation, nitrates can decrease afterload. But a high dose of nitrates cause significant systemic arteriolar vasodilation and thus decrease blood flow in coronary arterioles. This leads to detrimental effects in angina pectoris.

Choice A: When atherosclerotic plaques cause narrowing of arterioles and resulting cardiac ischemia, the cardiac vessels are maximally dilated by innate mechanisms that attempt to dilate coronary vessels in ischemia. If a drug is given that does not decrease cardiac workload but dilates coronary vessels, it leads to coronary steal syndrome, where blood flows preferentially to pharmacologically dilated arteries of heart. This causes paradoxical decrease in blood flow to ischemic area, where vessels are already blocked by atherosclerotic plaque.

Choice B: an increase in diastolic blood pressure will lead to increased coronary perfusion pressure. It is during this diastolic phase of cardiac cycle that aortic valve is closed and aortic blood flows in the coronary artery. An increased diastolic blood pressure means increased afterload which in turn means increased workload for left ventricle. This is counterproductive in myocardial ischemia because of increased cardiac work and increased oxygen demand.

Choice D: decrease in arteriolar resistance will lead to decreased afterload, thus reducing cardiac work. Drugs like ACE inhibitors, ARBs and Calcium channel blockers decrease arteriolar resistance. Although decreased afterload will be helpful in angina, this is still not the best answer.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with symptoms including auditory hallucinations, decreased appetite, and occasional aggression. He appears anxious with limited eye contact, and his vital signs show a blood pressure of 130/90mmHg and a pulse rate of 80 beats per minute. Given a likely diagnosis of schizophrenia, he is prescribed an antipsychotic medication, with counseling about potential side effects such as dry mouth, sedation, and hypotension. Which receptors does the prescribed drug primarily target?
questions.solution:
Option A: D2, alpha-1, H1, and 5HT2 receptors

  • The patient is diagnosed with schizophrenia.
  • The drug is chlorpromazine, as its adverse effects include dry mouth, sedation, and hypotension.
  • Chlorpromazine (Propylamino-derivative phenothiazine) is a conventional (prototypical, first-generation) anti-psychotic agent.
  • It acts on D2 and 5HT2, H1, muscarinic and alpha receptors.
  • Actions on various receptors:
    • D2 and 5HT2 blocking action: Anti-psychotic effect
    • H1 blockade: Sedation
    • Muscarinic blockade: Dry mouth
    • Alpha blockade: Hypotension
    • D2 blockade: Extra Pyramidal Symptoms(EPS) and Hyperprolactinemia
  • Uses of Chlorpromazine:
    • Psychotic Disorders
    • Nausea and vomiting
    • Preoperative sedation
    • Treatment of acute intermittent porphyria
    • Adjunct in the treatment of tetanus.
    • Bipolar disorder

Option B: GABA Receptors

  • Gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) represents the major inhibitory neurotransmitter of the central nervous system.
  • Ethanol and benzodiazepines, as well as some anticonvulsant drugs, directly affect GABA receptors.
  • Gabapentin and valproate enhance the activity of GABA receptors.
  • Chlorpromazine does not affect GABA receptors.

Option C: Anti Muscarinic receptors

  • Muscarinic receptors are abundantly elicited throughout the brain.
  • They are also found in various other tissues in the body, such as the heart, the bladder, and the pulmonary system.
  • There are five muscarinic receptors M1, M2, M3, M4, and M5.
  • Muscarinic receptors are involved in
    • Peristalsis
    • Micturition
    • Bronchoconstriction
  • The M2 muscarinic receptors act to slow the heart rate. Donepezil, galantamine,  and rivastigmine act on muscarinic receptors.

Option D: H2 receptors

  • H2 receptor blocker medications reduce the amount of stomach acid released by the glands.
  • H2 blockers such as ranitidine and cimetidine reduce symptoms of heartburn.
  • Chlorpromazine does not affect H2 receptors.

questions.text: A newborn male was born to a 33-year-old mother at 32 weeks gestation via C-section. On physical examination, cleft lip and cleft palate, episodes of no breathing were noted along with having extra fingers on both hands, microphthalmia, and underside of the foot was also convex. The remainder of the physical examination was unremarkable. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
This child has multiple congenital birth defects that are consistent with Patau syndrome

Patau syndrome is a syndrome caused by a chromosomal abnormality, in which some or all of the cells of the body contain extra genetic material from chromosome 13. It is characterized by holoprosencephaly, cleft lip/palate, microphthalmia (small eyes), severe intellectual disability, polydactyly (extra digits), congenital heart disease, cutis aplasia (localized absence of skin at birth), and rocker-bottom feet . Patau syndrome can be detected upon prenatal screening. This disorder is associated with low survival rates, with death typically occurring in the first year of life.

INCORRECT ANSWERS

Option A: Deletion of 11p13 can be found in patients with Wilms tumors and aniridia (absence of the iris) as part of the WAGR complex (Wilms tumor, Aniridia, Genital anomalies, and Range of developmental delays).

Option C: Trisomy 18, is a genetic disorder caused by the presence of a third copy of all or part of chromosome 18, which is characterized by severe intellectual disability, prominent occiput, micrognathia, low-set ears, clenched fists with overlapping fingers, congenital heart defects, limited hip abduction, and rocker-bottom feet.

Option D: Down syndrome also known as trisomy 21, is a genetic disorder caused by the presence of all or part of the third copy of chromosome 21. Physical characteristics of Down syndrome include a single palmar crease, epicanthal folds, a flat facial profile, and hypotonia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Oral polio vaccine (OPV) is false

choices.text: Oral polio vaccine (OPV) was described by Sabin in 1957.
It contains live attenuated virus (types 1,2 and 3)grown in primary monkey kidney or human diploid cell cultures.
Ideally each virus type should be given separately as monovalent vaccine
The vaccine contains over 3,00,000 TCID 50 of type 2 poliovirus

questions.solution: Oral polio vaccine (OPV) was described by Sabin in 1957. It contains live attenuated virus (types 1,2 and 3)grown in primary monkey kidney or human diploid cell cultures. Ideally each virus type should be given separately as monovalent vaccine, but for administrative convenience,rather than efficacy, it is given as trivalent (TOPV} vaccine.The vaccine contains (i) over 3,00,000 TCID 50 of type 1 poliovirus (ii} over 1,00,000 TCID 50 of type 2 virus, and(iii} over 3,00,000 TCID 50 of type 3 virus per dose.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency at 32 weeks of gestation complaining of nausea and dull right flank pain for 2 days. On examination, her temperature is 100°F, PR is 96/min, and BP is 120/70 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows uterus midway between the xiphoid and umbilicus with FHTs at 148/min. Urinalysis reveals 50 to 100 WBCs/high power field. WBC is 18,800. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Pyelonephritis

  • This patient with right flank pain, fever and high WBC count likely has acute pyelonephritis.
  • Pyelonephritis in pregnancy may occur due to untreated or inadequately treated UTI or asymptomatic bacteriuria.

 

Option A: Duodenal ulcer

  • It presents with epigastric pain that resolves after taking a meal. There will not be any pain in the flank.
  • Urinalysis will be normal in case of duodenal ulcer.

Option B: Volvulus

  • It presents with abdominal pain, constipation and vomiting.
  • Urinalysis will be normal in case of volvulus.

Option C: Placental abruption

  • It presents with severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding and abnormal fetal heart rate.
  • There are no features of placental abruption in this patient.

questions.text: A drug is shown to activate dopaminergic D1 and D2 and adrenergic α and β1 but not β2 receptors. Which of the following can be the drug being talked about?
questions.solution: Dopamine has concentration dependent effects on various receptors. When infused at a rate of less than 2 μg/kg/min., it stimulates only dopamine receptors (resulting in renal vasodilation). At 2-10 μg/kg/min. infusion rate, it stimulates β1 receptors also and at a rate greater than 10 μg/kg/min. it causes vasoconstriction due to stimulation of α-receptors.

questions.text:
In a recent football game among Dallas cowboys and Philadelphia eagles, there was an onfield collision between two team players. The Dallas player who was going for the winning touchdown point, tackled a Philadelphia player who sustained injuries to his lower extremity. Later the next day, newspaper claimed that particular person had a ‘TERRIBLE TRIAD’ of injury. What are the features of this injury?
1. Foot is fixed to ground
1. Knee is in flexion
2. Twisting fall to same side
3. Dorsiflexion of the foot
4. Hyperextension of the arm
questions.solution:
It is also known as unhappy triad. This injury involves anterior cruciate ligament, medial meniscus and medial collateral ligament.

When a lateral force is applied to the knee while the foot is fixed on the ground, there is an increased valgus or abduction and rotational stress on the knee that results in over stretching of these structures. When the knee ligaments fail, there is an increased stress on the medial meniscus which leads to rupture of the meniscus. Symptoms include stiff knee, severe pain, excessive swelling and difficulty moving.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician for progressive right shoulder pain for 3 weeks and worsening lower back pain since past week. He has a history of chronic low back pain. He has tried several over-the-counter medications without significant reIief. He smokes 2 packs daily since past 40 years. A chest x-ray reveals a right superior lobe mass. Which of the following additional findings, if present, would Indicate a worse prognosis requiring urgent intervention?
questions.solution:
The description in the vignette is consistent with superior pulmonary sulcus (Pancoast) tumor, generally a subset of non-small cell lung cancer.

CLINICAL MANIFESTATIONS

Shoulder pain—The most common initial symptom of superior sulcus tumors is shoulder pain, present in 44 to 96 percent of patients. Pain can progress and radiate up to the head and neck, or down to the medial aspect of the scapula, axilla, anterior chest, or ipsilateral arm in the distribution of the ulnar nerve. Patients frequently receive treatment for presumed cervical osteoarthritis or shoulder bursitis, resulting in a delay in diagnosis of five to ten months in some series. Pain ultimately becomes persistent and of such severity that the patient may need to support the involved arm with the uninvolved hand in order to obtain relief. Adequate pain control measures are important when caring for patients with superior sulcus tumors.

Horner syndrome—Horner syndrome consists of ipsilateral ptosis with narrowing of the palpebral fissure, miosis, enophthalmos, and anhidrosis. It is caused by involvement of the paravertebral sympathetic chain and the inferior cervical (stellate) ganglion.

Neurologic complications involving the upper extremity-- Extension of tumor to the C8 and T1 nerve roots results in upper extremity neurologic findings in approximately 8 to 22 percent of cases. Involvement of these nerve roots may result in weakness and atrophy of the intrinsic muscles of the hand, or pain and paresthesia of the fourth and fifth digits and the medial aspect of the arm and forearm. Abnormal sensation and pain in the T2 territory (the axilla and medial aspect of the upper arm) may also be an early finding, and the triceps reflex may be lost.

Spinal cord compression develops in up to 25% of patients with pancoast tumor during the course of the disease and may result in paraplegia. Early recognition and appropriate therapy (which may include corticosteroid therapy, surgery, and radiation is crucial to preserve neurologic function.

Other findings—Supraclavicular lymph node enlargement and prominent weight loss are each observed in approximately 25 to 35 percent of cases. Superior sulcus tumors may produce a phrenic or recurrent laryngeal neuropathy or superior vena cava syndrome in 5 to 10 percent of patients

questions.text:
Commutation of death sentence cannot be done by
1. Additional sessions court
2. Sessions court
3. High court
4. Supreme court
5. President
questions.solution:
Correct Option B  - 1, 2:

  • Commutation of the death sentence cannot be done by the additional sessions court and sessions court.
  • Commutation of the death sentence is possible by the High court, Supreme court & the President.
  • The Sessions Court is established by the State Government (S.9, Cr.P.C.) and is usually located at the district headquarters.
  • It can only try cases which have been committed to it by a Magistrate (S.l93,Cr.P.C.).
  • It can pass any sentence authorised by law, but a sentence of death passed by it must be confirmed by the High Court (S.28 (2) and S.366, Cr.P.C.).
  • District Court: deals with civil cases.
  • An Assistant Sessions Court can pass sentence of imprisonment up to ten years and unlimited fine (S.28 (3), Cr.P.C.).

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C & D: Due to the above given reasons

questions.text: While on Emergency duty, a psychiatry resident is called to assess a 15-month-old child in the pediatric ward who has developed a muscle spasm in his neck causing him to have a twisted neck, and difficulty in opening his mouth for the last 1 hour. The child was admitted 4 days back in view of an abdominal infection for which he had been receiving appropriate treatment and care. Which of the following medications is the most likely cause for the patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
DOMPERIDONE: The child in the case vignette has drug-induced movement disorder, named Acute dystonia. It is an extra-pyramidal sign(EPS) and a common complication of Domperidone administration in infants and young children due to their poorly developed blood-brain barrier. It is a reversible condition that subsides after discontinuation of the offending agent.

Option A: Erythromycin - It is a macrolide antibiotic used to treat infections in pediatric and adult age groups. It does not cause EPS.

Option B: Pantoprazole - It is a Proton pump inhibitor not known to cause an acute dystonic reaction.

Option D: Metronidazole - It is the treatment of choice for anaerobic bacterial infections. Its toxicity can cause features of encephalopathy and seizures, but unlikely EPS.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to your clinic because he has had day and night urine incontinence. He reports that he can't "pee across the bathroom like some of the other boys at school." When he feels the urge to void, he has a little warning before urine starts to drain through his urethra. Ultrasound was done which showed the finding seen in the image given below. Your probable diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound image shows the Key-hole appearance of the bladder.

? Keyhole appearance on antenatal scan is a feature of posterior urethral valve.

? Ultrasound image showing multiple variable sized cystic lesions involving the renal parenchyma s/o polycystic kidney disease.

? Key hole appearance/linguine sign on breast MRI is a feature of intracapsular Breast implant rupture.

questions.text: A 30-year-old carpenter comes to the ENT OPD complaining of swelling in the left cheek and frequent epistaxis. On examination, loss of sensation of the left cheek was noted with nasal mass. Vital signs are normal. The cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Ohngren's line is an imaginary plane used by E.N.T specialists to diagnose maxillary sinus tumours. Which of the following describes the extent of the Ohngrens line?

choices.text: Medial canthus to the angle of the mandible
Lateral canthus to the angle of mandible
Medial canthus to the mastoid process
Lateral canthus to the mastoid process

questions.solution:
Option A: Medial canthus to the angle of the mandible

  • The early symptoms and imaging findings of sinonasal tumours are similar to rhinosinusitis with a runny and stuffy nose, lacrimation and epistaxis and therefore neglected both by the patients and doctors.
  • When late symptoms such as anosmia, visual disturbances, cranial neuropathy (CN II, IV, V, VI) or facial swelling appear, the patient is referred to sinonasal endoscopy or imaging. At the time of diagnosis, more than half of the tumours have reached an advanced stage with a poor prognostic outcome. 
  • So on imaging, an imaginary plane is drawn to know if the tumors prognosis and further management.

  • An imaginary plane is drawn, extending between the eye's medial canthus and the mandible's angle. This is the Ohngren's line
  • The line defines a plane orthogonal to a sagittal plane that divides the maxillary sinus into
    1. Anteroinferior part (Infrastructure): Good prognosis.
    2. Posterosuperior part (Suprastructure): Bad Prognosis.
  • So maxillary sinus tumours that are in the anteroinferior part have a good prognosis.

Option B: Lateral canthus to the angle of mandible

  • The lateral canthus to the angle of the mandible is not the extent of the Ohngren's line, which runs from the medial canthus to the angle of the mandible.

Option C: Medial canthus to the mastoid process

  • This is not the correct  answer because Ohngren's line runs from the medial canthus to the angle of the mandible.

Option D: Lateral canthus to the mastoid process

  • This is not the correct answer because Ohngren's line, which is an imaginary plane, runs from the medial canthus to the angle of the mandible.

questions.text: The chest x-ray of a 62-year-old woman who complains of weakness, dyspnea, and hemoptysis shows multiple nodules in the right lung. She states that the dyspnea is worse in the supine position (platypnea) and improves on sitting up. On examination, the physician notes multiple hemorrhagic telangiectasia in the mouth and in the skin of the upper chest wall. There is a mild increase in the erythrocyte count, and the PO2 is 90.  An angiogram shows multiple pulmonary arteriovenous (AV) fistula in both lungs. What should be the next step in treatment?
questions.solution: The presence of multiple masses on a chest x-ray should alert the physician to the possible diagnosis of pulmonary AV fistula. Needle biopsy and endobronchial biopsy of the lesion should not be attempted, because severe hemorrhage may be precipitated. Paradoxical emboli, brain abscess, and hemothorax are recognized complications. If the fistula is localized, resection is undertaken; in multiple lesions,therapeutic embolization is done. In addition to AV malformation, multiple masses on a chest x-ray could be due to metastasis, granulomatous infection, or sarcoid or rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female was referred to your dermatology clinic for a 10-day history of symptomless skin lesions on her trunk. The patient was otherwise healthy and had no history of taking any medication. During her physical examination, disseminated erythematous maculopapular eruptions with fine scales, having a typical “Christmas tree” appearance, were observed on her back and abdomen. A similar, but larger, lesion with a collarette scale was also detected on her abdomen. On the basis of her clinical findings, the probable diagnosis for the patient would be:
questions.solution:
Lichen planus Pityriasis rosea Psoriasis Tinea corporis
Type of rash Purple colored flat topped papules. Erythematous papules and plaques, annular, wrinkling. Salmon pink erythematous plaques Annular erythematous plaques
Site Wrists, ankles, lower back Trunk predominantly. Elbows, knees, scalp, extensors. Glabrous skin - commonly folds.
Scaling Absent Trailing edge collarette scale. Slivery white thick scaling Fine scaling on the leading edge
Itching ++ +/- + ++
KOH - - - +

Pityriasis rosea (PR)

  • Papulosquamous eruption of unknown etiology occurring more commonly in the spring and fall.
  • Its first manifestation is the development of a 2 to 6 cm annular lesion (the herald patch).

  • This is followed in a few days to a few weeks by the appearance of many smaller annular or papular lesions with a predilection to occur on the trunk.
  • The lesions are generally oval, with their long axis parallel to the skinfold lines.
  • Individual lesions may range in color from red to brown and have a trailing scale.
  • The eruption tends to be moderately pruritic and lasts 6-12 weeks.
  • The potassium hydroxide mount of the scrapings is negative.

questions.text: For defining undernourished in Nutritional programme for Adolescent Girls cut offs of weight in relation to age are:
questions.solution:
• It was initially started as a pilot project in 51 districts of the country and was taken up again in 2003-04.
  • It was stopped for a year in 2004-05 but taken on as a full project, in 2005-06, to be implemented by the Ministry of Women and Child Development.
  • The scheme was started in 51 backward districts and was restricted to only undernourished adolescent girls.

The scheme continues on a pilot project basis.

  • The funds are provided by the central government to the state government in the form of 100% grants. The food is meant to be provided through the public distribution system for no cost to the families identified in this scheme.
  • Free food grains @6 kg per beneficiary per month are provided to undernourished adolescent girls. The scheme targets girl children between the ages of 11 -19 years.
  • For defining the undernourished two cut offs are taken for weight in relation to age e.g. <30 kg for girls 11-15 years and weight <35 kg for girls 15-19 years.

questions.text:
Four days after surgical evacuation of an acute subdural hematoma, a 44-year-old man becomes mildly lethargic and develops asterixis. He has received 2400 mL of 5% dextrose in water intravenously each day since surgery, and he appears well hydrated. Pertinent laboratory values are as follows:

Serum electrolytes (meq/L): Na+ 118; K+ 3.4; C1− 82; HCO3− 24  
Serum osmolality: 242 mOsm/L  
Urine sodium: 47 meq/L
