Urine osmolality: 486 mOsm/L  

A correct statement about this patient’s fluid and electrolyte status is which of the following?

choices.text: His low serum sodium indicates sodium deficiency, which should be treated with 3% saline infusion
He probably has the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of anti-diuretic hormone
His blood glucose level should be checked because the hyponatremia may be artifactual
Water restriction is rarely effective in severe cases of hyponatremia

questions.solution: The patient presented has the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). Although this syndrome is primarily associated with diseases of the central nervous system or of the chest (e.g., oat cell carcinoma of the lung), excessive amounts of antidiuretic hormone are also present in most postoperative patients. The pathophysiology of SIADH involves an inability to dilute the urine; administered water is therefore retained, which produces dilutional hyponatremia. Body sodium stores and fluid balance are normal, as evidenced by the absence of the clinical findings suggestive of abnormalities of extracellular fluid volume. While hypertonic saline infusions can transiently improve hyponatremia, the appropriate therapy is to restrict water ingestion to a level below the patient’s ability to excrete water. Hypertonic saline may be dangerous, since it can shift accumulated water into the extracellular fluid and precipitate pulmonary edema in the patient who suffers from low cardiac reserves. Hyperglycemia cannot account for the hyponatremia seen in this patient because the serum osmolality, as well as the serum sodium, is depressed. Hyponatremia resulting from hyperglycemia would be associated with an elevated serum osmolality.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with complaints of paroxysms of headache, nausea, abdominal pain, vomiting, and palpitations. Urinary catecholamines and plasma metanephrine levels were found to be elevated. Which of the following is used preoperatively to control blood pressure during surgery?
questions.solution:
Option C: Irreversible alpha blocker

  • Complaints of paroxysmal headache, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and palpitations, along with elevated levels of urinary and plasma metanephrines levels lead to a probable diagnosis of Pheochromocytoma.
  • Pheochromocytoma is characterized by hypertension and low blood volume, resulting from an excessive concentration of catecholamines in the plasma. With insufficient preoperative antihypertensive management or untreated hypovolemia, the hemodynamic instability during surgical treatment of pheochromocytoma may be lethal.
  • The main goal of preoperative management of pheochromocytoma is to normalize blood pressure and heart rate, restore effective circulating blood volume, improve the metabolic condition, and prevent a patient from catecholamines storm and hemodynamic instability during surgery.
  • Phenoxybenzamine is a non-selective, non-competitive α-AR antagonist, which binds irreversibly with both α1 and α2-AR and causes vasodilation, and decreases blood pressure. Phenoxybenzamine is long-acting, and its effects persist long after it has been discontinued since the effect diminishes only after α-AR resynthesis.
  • The advantage of phenoxybenzamine is that its effect is profound and long-acting, even when excessive amounts of catecholamines reach the circulation.

Option A: Beta Blocker

  • Beta receptors normally cause vasodilation.
  • Since catecholamines have both alpha and beta receptor activity, they also cause some degree of vasodilation through beta receptors.
  • When beta blockers are used, then the vasodilatory effect of catecholamines through beta receptors is antagonized, and there is alpha receptors stimulation which can cause severe hypertension and end-organ damage.
  • So beta blockers are avoided.

Option B: Diuretic

  • Pheochromocytoma patients are already hypovolemic.
  • Using a diuretic to control hypertension would be detrimental to the patient.
  • A state of hypovolemia is classic for pheochromocytoma due to prolonged vasoconstriction by circulating catecholamines; further volume depletion can precipitate a crisis.

Option D: None of the above

  • Phenoxybenzamine (irreversible long-acting α blocker) is used to control blood pressure in pheochromocytoma.

questions.text: The CSF from a 2-week-old infant with meningitis shows rods with tumbling motility. These bacteria are found to be Gram-positive and do not form spores. What is the most likely agent?
questions.solution:
• Listeria has a tumbling motility when grown in broth, in this case CSF.
  • Clostridium can be eliminated because they are spore-formers.
  • Actinomyces and corynebacteria are both Gram-positive and nonmotile and are not common causative agents of neonatal meningitis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office with progressively enlarging ulcer on his lower lip. The ulcer is enlarging slowly and is painless. He works in the farms for the past 50 years. He smokes 1 pack of cigarette per day and occasionaly drinks vodka. The ulcer starts bleeding on touch. Physical examination shows a white man with multiple freckles and an ulcer on the lower lip. The ulcer is red witheverted edges and the skinaround theulcerisinflamed and indurated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Squamous cell carcinoma → Second most common skin cancer.

  • Associated with excessive exposure to sunlight, immunosuppression, chronically draining sinuses, and occasionally arsenic exposure.
  • Commonly appears on face , lower lip , ears, hands.
  • Locally invasive, may spread to lymph nodes, and will rarely metastasize. Ulcerative red lesions with frequent scale.

Histopathology: keratin “pearls”

- squamous cell carcinoma is the second most commonskincancer afterbasal cell carcinoma. It occurs as a result of the malignant transformation ofkeratinocytesin thestratum spinosum(prickle cell layer) of theepidermis. Typical locations include thelower lip,ears, andhands.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with complaints of intermittent abdominal discomfort, diarrhea, and melena. Her temperature is 98.8 F, BP= 126/86 mm Hg, PR = 86/min, and RR = 18/min. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Cardiac examination reveals no abnormality. The abdomen is soft, non-tender, and has no hepatosplenomegaly. The patient undergoes colonoscopy followed by total colectomy due to significant colonic abnormalities. The colectomy image is shown below. The attending doctor advises that her sister (who is 26 years old) should also undergo a screening colonoscopy and it is found that colonoscopy findings are similar in both of them. If left untreated, what is the most likely lifetime risk of colon cancer in the patient's sister?
questions.solution:
♥ This patient and her sister have innumerable colonic polyps, raising strong suspicion for the autosomal dominant hereditary disorder familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). Patients with this disorder develop hundreds or thousands of colonic polyps in the second or third decade of life.

♥ These polyps are associated with a progressive risk for high-grade dysplasia and transformation to invasive cancer as they enlarge. Because patients with FAP have innumerable polyps, the risk that one or more will transform into invasive colonic carcinoma is nearly 100%.

♥ Therefore, colectomy is generally recommended. FAP is caused by a germline mutation to the tumor suppressor gene adenomatous polyposis coli (APC). The APC gene encodes for a protein that destroys beta-catenin. Loss of the APC protein results in elevated beta-catenin levels, which stimulates a transcriptional activator that leads to the proliferation of intestinal crypt cells and the subsequent formation of polyps. Patients may also have extracolonic manifestations such as gastric or duodenal polyps, desmoid tumors, and brain cancer.

questions.text: A 25-year-old soldier is not able to move his legs after suffering a gunshot wound on the lower part of his back . On neurologic examination and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan there is injury of the cauda equina. Which of the following structure is most likely damaged.

choices.text: Dorsal roots of the thoracic spinal nerves
Ventral roots of the sacral spinal nerves

questions.solution:
• The cauda equina is the collection of dorsal and ventral roots of the lower sacral and lumbar spinal nerves below the spinal cord.
• The dorsal and ventral primary branches and the dorsal roots of the thoracic spinal nerves and the lumbar spinal nerves are not involved in the formation of the cauda equina.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient is brought to the clinic by his wife with a complaint of forgetfulness and inability to care for himself. Last week he was lost in the neighbourhood. The physician suspected early-onset Alzheimer's disease. The patient's wife asks the reason for developing early-onset Alzheimer's disease. Chromosomes involved in early-onset Alzheimer's disease are?
questions.solution:
Option A: 1, 14, 21

  • Young-onset (also called early-onset) Alzheimer's is an uncommon form of dementia that affects people younger than age 65.
  • About 5% to 6% of people with Alzheimer's disease develop symptoms before age 65.
  • Most people with young-onset Alzheimer's develop symptoms of the disease when they are between 30 and 60 years old.
  • Young-onset Alzheimer's can result from mutations in one of three genes (APP, PSEN1 or PSEN2), which can potentially be passed on to other family members.
  • Mutations in the protein from which Aβ is derived (APP) cause familial Alzheimer's disease, as does an increased copy number (either from small duplications or from trisomy 21) of the APP gene.
  • The two loci identified as causes of the majority of early-onset familial Alzheimer's disease encode the two presenilins (PS1 on chromosome 14 and PS2 on chromosome 1).

Option B: 1, 13, 21

  • Chromosome 1 carries the presenilin 2 gene, and chromosome 21 carries the APP gene from which amyloid precursor protein is derived.
  • Aβ amyloid is derived from amyloid precursor protein (APP) which normally undergoes alpha cleavage; beta cleavage results in Aβ amyloid.
  • Chromosome 13 does not carry any gene for presenilins or APP.
  • Therefore, it is not involved in early-onset Alzheimer's disease.

Option C: 3, 14, 20

  • Chromosome 14 carries gene PS1 for presenilin protein, which is involved in early-onset Alzheimer's disease.
  • Chromosome 3 & 20 does not carry any gene for presenilins or APP.
  • Therefore, these are not involved in early-onset Alzheimer's disease.

Option D: 3, 14, X

  • Chromosome 14 carries gene PS1 for presenilin protein, which is involved in early-onset Alzheimer's disease.
  • Chromosome 3 & X does not carry any gene for presenilins or APP.
  • Therefore, these are not involved in early-onset Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman was injured when an auto pushed her against a hard concrete wall. Vital signs were recorded to be normal but a pelvic fracture was suspected because of severe pain in the lumbar region and she was brought to the critical care center. On examination, her consciousness was clear and hemodynamics were stable. Severe pressure pain was felt at the anterior surface of the pubic bone and near the right sacrum. Macroscopic hematuria was found when a urethral catheter was inserted. A CT Cystography was performed on admission which revealed the following finding. Your probable management for this patient is

choices.text: No intervention needed as it has spontaneous healing
Surgical intervention is mandatory and then secondary healing is allowed

questions.solution:
Note in the image how the contrast dissects around the bladder but does not enter the peritoneal cavity.

In this case, imaging indicates that it is an intraperitoneal bladder rupture as the blood does not enter the peritoneal cavity.

So Simple catheter drainage will be the appropriate management for this patient.

Option A: False statement

Appropriate intervention is needed as it does not heal spontaneously.

Option C: False statement

Emergency laparotomy will be done only in the case of intraperitoneal bladder rupture.

Option D: False statement

In the case of intraperitoneal bladder rupture, surgical intervention is mandatory and then secondary healing is allowed.

Learning objective:

questions.text:
Match the following



Rifampin
Inhibits peripheral conversion of T4 to T3;


Sulfonamides

Induce metabolic degradation of T4/T3



Lithium
Inhibits thyroglobulin iodination and coupling reaction


Amiodarone
Inhibits thyroid hormone release
questions.solution:
Match Details
Lithium inhibits thyroid hormone release.
Amiodarone inhibits peripheral conversion of T4 to T3; also interferes with thyroid hormone action.
Sulfonamides, para-aminosalicylic acid inhibit thyroglobulin iodination and coupling reaction.
Phenobarbitone, phenytoin, carbamazepine, rifampin induce metabolic degradation of T4/T3.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician by her parents with the complaint of abnormally muffled voice since birth. Her past medical history is unremarkable except for an episode of croup one year back. On examination, there is no sign of respiratory distress. Laryngoscopy reveals a thin and translucent membrane between the vocal cords, narrowing the glottis. Which of the following is true about suspected pathology?

(1) Symptoms may be absent

(2) Usually involves the posterior part of the vocal cords

(3) The voice is of normal quality

(4) Excision should be performed as early as possible
questions.solution:
Option D: Only 1 is correct

  • The child presentation with a muffled voice and examination findings of a thin laryngeal membrane most likely suggest a laryngeal web.
  • Statement (1) is correct. If the web is small, usually there are no symptoms.
  • The magnitude of the symptoms depends upon the narrowing of the glottis.
  • Large-sized laryngeal webs can cause significant respiratory distress manifested by stridor, cyanosis, increased respiratory rate, nasal flaring, and intercoastal recessions.

Option A: 1,2,3,4 is correct

  • Statement (1) is correct. If the web is small, usually there are no symptoms.
  • Statement (2) is incorrect. The laryngeal webs usually involve the anterior part of the vocal cords.
  • Statement (3) is incorrect. Due to the narrowing of the glottis, the voice can be abnormal. Hoarseness or muffling of voice is usually present.
  • Statement (4) is incorrect. When the web is small and causes few symptoms, it is usually best to treat it conservatively.

Option B: Only 1,2,3 is correct

  • Statement (1) is correct. If the web is small, usually there are no symptoms.
  • Statement (2) is incorrect. The laryngeal webs usually involve the anterior part of the vocal cords.
  • Statement (3) is incorrect. Due to the narrowing of the glottis, the voice can be abnormal. Hoarseness or muffling of voice is usually present.

Option C: Only 1,2 is correct

  • Statement (1) is correct. If the web is small, usually there are no symptoms.
  • Statement (2) is incorrect.
  • The laryngeal webs usually involve the anterior part of the vocal cords.

questions.text: A 1st-year resident is explaining the anatomy and physiology of ureters. He mentions that the ureters pass obliquely through the bladder wall. Although there are no ureteral sphincters, the oblique passage tends to keep the ureters closed except during peristaltic waves, preventing urine reflux from the bladder. Ureteric peristalsis is triggered by?

choices.text: Pacemaker activity of the smooth muscle cells in the renal pelvis

questions.solution:
Option D: Pacemaker activity of the smooth muscle cells in the renal pelvis

  • Ureteric peristalsis has long been triggered by pacemaker atypical smooth muscle cells (SMC) located in the proximal regions of the renal pelvis.
  • Ureteric peristaltic contractions occur 1 to 5 times per minute.
  • There are specialized smooth muscle pacemaker cells in the region of the renal pelvis; the contractions arise here.
  • Ureteral peristalsis is triggered by calcium-dependent pacemaker cells in ureteral smooth muscle.
  • With obstruction, ureteral peristalsis increases in amplitude and frequency.
  • Peristalsis decreases with chronic obstruction and may cease entirely with concurrent infection.
  • Immediately after the obstruction is relieved, peristalsis slowly normalizes.

Option A: Sympathetic innervation

  • Ureters are innervated by sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves. Peristaltic waves may be modified by the action of splanchnic nerves (upper portion of the ureter) and by the hypogastric plexus (lower portion).
  • However, peristalsis is not due to sympathetic or parasympathetic innervation.

Option B: Parasympathetic innervation

  • Ureters are innervated by sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves. Peristaltic waves may be modified by the action of splanchnic nerves (upper portion of the ureter) and by the hypogastric plexus (lower portion).
  • However, peristalsis is not due to sympathetic or parasympathetic innervation.

Option C: Both (A) and (B)

  • Ureters are innervated by sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves. Peristaltic waves may be modified by the action of splanchnic nerves (upper portion of the ureter) and by the hypogastric plexus (lower portion).
  • However, peristalsis is not due to sympathetic or parasympathetic innervation

questions.text: Household air pollution caused by inefficient use of solid fuels leads to maximum mortality in case of:
questions.solution:
Although relatively clean sources of household energy predominate in developed countries, improvements in energy efficiency have led to homes being relatively airtight, reducing ventilation and raising indoor pollutant levels.  

4.3 million people die every year prematurely from illness attributable to the household air pollution caused by inefficient use of solid fuels. Among these deaths 12 percent are due to pneumonia, 34 percent from stroke, 26 percent from ischaemic heart disease, 22 percent from COPD and 6 percent from lung cancer.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea and a rash. The rash is maculopapular and pruritic. It is predominantly located on face and hands. He recently underwent bone marrow transplantation. The stool is positive for occult blood. Serum bilirubin is elevated. Which of the following cells are responsible for the disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described is typical for Acute graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).

Acute and chronic graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) are multisystem disorders that are common complications of allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplant (HCT). GVHD occurs when immune cells transplanted from a non-identical donor (the graft) recognize the transplant recipient (the host) as foreign, thereby initiating an immune reaction that causes disease in the transplant recipient. Clinical manifestations of acute GVHD include a classic maculopapular rash; persistent nausea and/or emesis; abdominal cramps with diarrhea; and a rising serum bilirubin concentration. Grafted immunocompetent T cells proliferate in the immunocompromised host and reject host cells with “foreign” proteins causing severe organ dysfunction.

questions.text: A child presented to you in emergency with abnormal respiratory pattern. On careful observation , you conclude that child has prolonged inspiration which is followed by prolonged expiration and you demonstrate the respiratory pattern by the following graph. Which are of brain is most likely inflicted in this case?
questions.solution:
The given description is suggestive of Apneustic respiration which is present when pons is damaged.

INJURY PATTERN COMMENTS
Normal Variable VT with normal respiratory pauses and sighs
Cortex Hyperpnea and tachypnea
Midbrain Cheyne-Strokes breathing: Gradually increasing and decreasing VT
Pons Apneustic breathing: Prolonged inspiration followed by prolonged expiration
Medulla and pons Biot's breathing: Rapid and irregular respiration with pauses

*Lung Volume vs time.

VT, Tidal volume

questions.text: Through which of the following layers does the light enter the retina?
questions.solution:
Option D: Retinal ganglion layer

  • Layers of the retina from inside to outside are:
    • Pigmented layer
    • The layer of rods and cones projecting to the pigment
    • Outer nuclear layer
    • Outer plexiform layer
    • Inner nuclear layer
    • Inner plexiform layer
    • Ganglionic layer
    • The layer of optic nerve fibers
    • Inner limiting membrane
  • The light from the lens, cornea, and vitreous humor enters the retina from inside the eye.
  • Light passes first from the ganglion cell layer, then through plexiform and nuclear layers, before reaching the layer of rods and cones.

Option A: Outer nuclear layer

  • Light strikes the retina on the retinal ganglion layer first.
  • The outer nuclear layer is not the first layer for the light to pass into the eye.

Option B: Inner nuclear layer

  • The inner nuclear layer is next to the inner plexiform layer.
  • Light enters the ganglionic cell layer and the inner plexiform layer to reach the inner nuclear layer.

Option C: Outer plexiform layer

  • The outer plexiform layer is not the first layer at which light strikes the retina.
  • It is far from the ganglionic cell layer, the first layer on which light rays strike in the retina.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of the persistent painful penile erection for 6 hours. He has a history of sickle cell trait and major depressive disorder and takes citalopram and trazodone. He is in acute distress. His temperature is normal, pulse is 110/min, respirations 18/ min. Examination shows fully rigid erection with no evidence of penile discharge. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
A fully rigid, painfulerectionlasting> 4 hoursindicateslow-flow priapism(LFP), a urological emergency. Common causes of LFP are drugs that are used to treaterectile dysfunction(e.g.,sildenafil), certainantihypertensives(e.g.,prazosin), and certainantidepressants(e.g.,trazodone).

Priapismis a common symptom in male patients withsickle cell disease, but it is not a symptom of the mildersickle cell trait.

questions.text: 45-year-old Zemo was cleaning his room. Suddenly he started feeling pain in his flank region of the abdomen. He noticed that the pain is radiating to the groin region. He also experienced other symptoms along with the pain such as nausea, sweating, and urinary urgency. On examination, the abdomen was normal but the patient seems to be distressed and restless. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The pain that the patient is experiencing is due to a ureteric calculus blocking the ureter. The pain is usually severe and colicky in nature and is usually radiating to the groin region. The patient will be usually restless because he cannot find a position of comfort. Due to the visceral stretch, there will be other associated symptoms like reflex vomiting.

Option A: Appendicitis usually manifests as vague periumbilical pain, migrating to the right lower quadrant with the development of peritonitis

Option B: Torsion of the testes manifests as sudden scrotal pain, and may have associated vague lower abdominal pain and vomiting.

Option D: The patient does not have a complaint of inability to urinate which is typically present in case of acute urinary retention.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presented with clinical features of Acute Myeloid Leukemia in peripheral blood smear. Initial investigation revealed leukostasis. Which of the following organ is mainly affected in patients with Hyperleukocytosis - Leukostasis syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Brain and Lungs (BOTH) are the most commonly affected organs by hyper leukocytosis and leukostasis syndrome
  • WBC counts in excess of >100,000/cu.mm leads to leukostatic plugging of the capillaries followed by endothelial damage to blood vessels.
  • The presence of dysnea, tachypnea and respiratory distress indicates pulmonary leukostasis.
  • CNSleukostasis presents with stupor, headache and dizziness.
  • The mortality occurs due to respiratory failure, intracranial haemorrhage and coma.
  • The low P02 is due to increased consumption of oxygen by leucocytes.
  • It is common with Acute leukemia subtypes like Acute promyelocytic leukemia, acute monocytic leukemia and T cell type of ALL

Causes of Leukostasis

  • Neutrophilic - Pyogenic infections, Sterile inflammation, Myocardial infarction, Burns
  • Eosinophilic - Allergic disorders(Asthma, Hay fever), Drug allergies, Allergic skin diseases(Pemphigus, Dermatitis herpetiformis) Parasitic infections ,Hodgkin's lymphoma ,SLE
  • Basophilic-CML Monocytosis - Chronic infections(Tuberculosis), Bacterial endocarditis, Rickettsiosis, Malaria Inflammatory bowel diseases
  • Lymphocytosis - Viral infections =Hepatitis, Cytomegalovirus, Infectious mononucleosis, Pertussis

questions.text: A 45-year-old female is brought to the emergency with a history of falling from the second floor. On examination, it’s evident that she has a spinal cord injury. The intern while informing his consultant over the phone says that the patient has ‘Sacral Sparing’. Which of the following will determine sacral sparing?
questions.solution:
Evidence of sacral sparing is evidence of an incomplete lesion. It enhances the possibility of the partial or complete return of motor power as well as of bladder and bowel function.

Sacral sparing can be evaluated through three tests of motor, sensory and reflex innervations:

1. Muscle testing of flexion of the great toe (S1 innervation)

2. Sensory testing of the perianal area (S2, 3, 4)

3. Reflex testing of the anal sphincter muscle (S2, 3, 4) since the bladder and bowel are innervated by the sacral nerve (S2, 3, 4), testing of these three areas gives a valid indication of the degree of sacral sparing and the possibility of the return of function.

The dermatomes can be difficult to remember so 5 important dermatomal landmarks can be remembered to make it easy to memorize the whole chart. Imagine eating a cake, it’s easier to at when cut in slices.

questions.text: A 20 year old patient presents with syncope. His current ECG is shown below. His elder brother had died suddenly while watching television. The patient was given Cardioversion and subsequent cardiac MRI revealed fibro-fatty changes in RV myocardium. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Arythmogenic RV dysplasia(ARVD)

  • ECG shows HR of 300/min with broad complex tachycardia.
  • Variation in amplitude of QRS complexes which indicates a diagnosis of polymorphic Ventricular Tachycardia.
  • In acute setting DC shock 200 J Biphasic should be given.
  • The Cardiac MRI report showing fibro-fatty changes in RV myocardium explains that the substrate for initiation of Polymorphic VT is originating from RV.
  • This confirms the diagnosis as Arythmogenic RV dysplasia(ARVD)
  • ECG - Presence of Epsilon wave.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with complaints of progressive vision loss in her left eye for 3 months and now blurred vision in her right eye for 10 days. She has a six-month history of frequent headaches that get worse in the morning and are accompanied by nausea and vomiting. She has been taking ondansetron and paracetamol with partial relief. Visual acuity in her right eye is 20/30, while she can only count fingers with the left eye. A fundoscopic examination is shown below. A left frontal brain lesion is visible on an MRI scan. These findings suggest a diagnosis of Foster-Kennedy syndrome. All of the following features are seen in Foster-Kennedy Syndrome except?

choices.text: Ipsilateral optic atrophy, ipsilateral central scotoma, bilateral progressive optic neuropathy
Contralateral papilledema, ipsilateral central scotoma, bilateral progressive optic neuropathy
Ipsilateral optic atrophy, contralateral papilledema, ipsilateral central scotoma
Contralateral anosmia, Contralateral central scotoma, bilateral progressive optic neuropathy

questions.solution:
Option D: Contralateral anosmia, Contralateral central scotoma, bilateral progressive optic neuropathy

Foster-Kennedy syndrome:

  • It is associated with intracranial masses such as olfactory or sphenoidal meningioma and frontal lobe tumours.
  • An intracranial mass causes direct compression on the optic nerve and olfactory nerve, causing ipsilateral optic atrophy and ipsilateral anosmia.
  • As the size of the mass enlarges, intracranial pressure increases, which results in contralateral papilledema.
  • Other symptoms include ipsilateral central scotoma and pupillary changes (afferent pupillary defect).

  • Edema of the right optic disc with blurred margins and increased disc diameter (image A).
  • Distinct margins of the left optic disc with a pale disc (image B).

Option A: Ipsilateral optic atrophy, ipsilateral central scotoma, bilateral progressive optic neuropathy

  • Due to direct compression, the presence of optic atrophy, central scotoma and progressive optic neuropathy are on the same side of the lesion.

Option B: Contralateral papilledema, ipsilateral central scotoma, bilateral progressive optic neuropathy

  • Central scotoma and optic neuropathy are present ipsilaterally due to direct compression from the tumour.
  • As the lesion size increases, intracranial pressure increases, resulting in swelling of the optic disc in the remaining intact optic nerve in the opposite eye.

Option C: Ipsilateral optic atrophy, contralateral papilledema, ipsilateral central scotoma

  • The presence of optic nerve atrophy and central scotoma on the same side of the lesion is due to direct compression.
  • Due to raised intracranial pressure, there is papilledema in the remaining intact optic nerve in the opposite eye.

questions.text: 77-year-old Adam is alone in his home. His children are working abroad. On a fine evening he started having back pain and increasing difficulty with initiating a urinary stream. He was taken to the hospital the next day morning by his Neighbour. Doctor did a digital rectal examination and found that he had a hard, irregularly enlarged prostate. prostate-specific antigen (PSA) was elevated and osteoblastic lesions were found on the vertebral column and bones of the pelvis. Well-differentiated adenocarcinoma was found on the needle biopsy of the prostate. Which of the following is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from metastatic adenocarcinoma of the prostate. The management is aimed at controlling the tumor for the palliation of the symptoms. Hormonal manipulation by orchiectomy or exogenous estrogen therapy is how we achieve the tumor control.

Option A: Transurethral prostatectomy not an adequate surgical therapy for prostate malignancy. It is usually done for benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Option B: Chemotherapy is used as an adjunct to radical surgical excision of localized disease. It is not indicated for metastatic disease.

Option D: Radical prostatectomy is done in patients whose malignancy is confined to the prostate gland alone.

questions.text: A 30 years old 4 month pregnant female comes to your clinic with complaints of dysuria and fever, it was diagnosed as a case of Urinary Tract Infection, which of the following medications should be avoided in this Patient?
questions.solution:
Doxycycline is a broad-spectrum tetracycline-class antibiotic Treat­ment of pregnant patients with tetracyclines may produce discoloration of the teeth in their children.

Option A - Amoxicillin Most uncomplicated urinary tract infections are caused by Enterobacteriaceae, and E. coli is the most common species. Aminopenicillins can be effective agents for urinary tract infections, but the high prevalence of resistance amongst E. coli and Klebsiella makes empiric use of these drugs for urinary tract infections challenging

Option B – Penicillin G

Penicillin G (IV), penicillin V (PO); IM depot formulations (benzathine, procaine) are used effectively in the treatment of Syphilis. Excellent activity vs. Treponema pallidum, β-hemolytic streptococci, N. meningitidis, gram-positive anaerobes

Option C – Cephalexin comes under the class of 1st Generation Cephalosporin Useful antibacterial activity against Streptococcib; Staphylococcus aureusc; some Proteus, E. coli, Klebsiella.

questions.text: A G2P1 female at 35 weeks experiences uterine contractions. No fetal distress is seen and membranes are not ruptured. Which of the following is to be done?
questions.solution:
The patient is having uterine contractions at 35 weeks of pregnancy.

At 35 weeks:

There is no role of Betamethasone (corticosteroid).”Current evidence supports the administration of a single course of antenatal corticosteroids between 24-34 weeks to enhance fetal lung maturation.

Tocolytic therapy: It is given for short-time use so that corticosteroids can act. Since at 35 weeks, there is no role of corticosteroid, So, therefore, no role of Tocolytic.

Cervical cerclage – no role at 35 weeks. Done before 32 weeks.

*Vaginal/rectal swab culture should be sent to detect group B streptococcus

questions.text: The 28 year old man brought in for management at the emergency was noticed to have suffered multiple injuries. Further investigation revealed a fractured femur, fractured tibia, fractured 8th-10th ribs and also flaying of the gastrocnemius muscle, possibly when the bus had run over his leg. What type of lacerated wound is flaying classified under?
questions.solution:
Option C: Avulsion

  • Produced by shearing force delivered at an oblique or tangential angle to detach (tear off) a portion of traumatized skin surface or viscus (tissue/organ) from their attachment.
  • Commonly seen in road traffic accidents where the rotating force of wheel tears off the skin over a large area. This is called flaying, and most frequently occurs on the legs.

Option A: Split

  • Split lacerations: Occur when soft tissues are sandwiched between a hard unyielding deeper structure and the agent applying the force. Scalp lacerations occur due to the tissues being crushed between the skull and some hard object.

Option B: Stretch

  • Stretch lacerations: Result from a heavy forceful frictional impact of blunt forces exercising localized ‘pressure with pull’. Overstretching of the skin and subcutaneous tissues may cause lacerations with the flapping of the skin, which may indicate the direction of the application of force.
  • They are seen in run over by motor vehicles, kicking and compound fractures.

Option D: Cut

  • Cut lacerations: Sometimes, a heavy sharp edged weapon causes a deep and wide cut over the body tissues.

questions.text: A patient present to OPD with decreased vision in left eye and opacification of cornea. He has a history of cataract surgery 6 years back. What is the line of management in this case?
questions.solution: In the given clinical picture, The patient had a cataract surgery six years before, it progressively forms corneal edema because of pseudophakic bullous keratopathy (PBK).keratoplasty is the only management that can be done in this condition.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old G2P1L1 woman presents at 28 weeks with complains of absent fetal movements. Ultrasound reveals a fetal demise with hydrops. On investigations
Blood group is B negative
CBC : Hb 8 gm%, TLC is 10500/cu.mm, platelet count is 2,10,1000/cu.mm Se bilirubin :0.5mg%, RBS 150 mg/dL
HIV/ HBsAg/ VDRL negative
Indirect Coomb’s test positive
Husband’s blood group is A positive, HIV/HBsAg/ VDRL negative
Which of the following is the most likely explanation of such fetal findings?

choices.text: Intrauterine fetal infection causing fetal anemia
Fetal RBC lysis by maternal antibodies

questions.solution:
This is a case of Rh isoimmunization suggested by negative blood group of mother and a positive blood group of father and a positive ICT.

Rh negative pregnancy with an Rh positive fetus causes an antibody response in the mother at the time of sensitization (when maternal blood comes in contact with fetal blood). The sensitization occurred most probably at the time of the first delivery, forming antibodies in the mother, which remained in circulation and incited a much stronger antibody response in the second pregnancy.

Fetal Rh D positive erythrocytes induce production of antibodies in maternal blood and these antibodies cross the placenta and destroy fetal erythrocytes in subsequent pregnancies.

Events which can cause sensitization:

  • Delivery (5-30ml)
  • Abortion
  • Molar pregnancy
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Trauma, Abruption
  • Sensitizing procedures : Amniocentesis, Chorionic villi sampling

Prevention of Rh isoimmunization: Inj Anti D at 28 weeks if ICT is negative and a repeat dose after delivery if baby’s blood group is positive and DCT (Direct Coombs test) is negative.

Hydrops fetalis is a condition when there is accumulation of fluid in at least two fetal compartments: ascites, pericardial effusion, pleural effusion or anasarca.

Immune hydrops (erythroblastosis fetalis) is where hydrops occurs secondary to mother's immunity causing fetal RBC hemolysis and is almost always due to Rh incompatibility.

  • Cardiac conditions like heart block
  • Infections like parvo virus (B19)
  • Hematological cause like alpha thalassemia
  • Gastrointestinal causes
  • Renal causes
  • Cystic hygroma

- Rh isoimmunization is the most common cause of immune hydrops fetalis. It occurs when the mother is Rh negative and father is Rh positive, such that if the fetus is Rh positive sensitization of maternal blood with fetal RBCs may occur at the time of contact. This may be prevented by antenatal and postnatal prophylaxis with Anti D.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of multiple red spots on his trunk. He first noticed these several months ago, and some appear to have increased in size. One day ago, he scratched one of these spots, which bled for several minutes. A photograph of the lesions is shown in the image:



Among the following clinical entities, which is this patient's most likely possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cherry hemangiomas

  • This patient most likely suffers from Cherry hemangiomas, benign vascular proliferations that commonly develop in adult patients.
  • The diagnosis is typically based on the clinical appearance of multiple bright red, dome-shaped papules on the trunk and upper extremities that bleed with trauma and usually blanch with pressure.
  • Cherry hemangiomas manifest more frequently with age and do not regress.
  • On histological examination, dilated interconnecting capillaries within the papillary dermis are seen.
  • The treatment is necessary unless lesions become bothersome such as frequent bleeding, or are cosmetically unappealing.
  • The treatment options for removal include electrocauterization, laser therapy, and excision.

Option A: Bacillary angiomatosis

  • The Bartonella henselae infections cause bacillary angiomatosis.
  • Bacillary angiomatosis manifests with vascular proliferations that bleed with trauma, like the lesions seen in this patient.
  • Although the lesions of bacillary angiomatosis can manifest with a papular appearance, they also commonly manifest as nodular, pedunculated, or verrucous lesions. In addition, this condition usually develops in patients infected with HIV, of which there is no indication here.

Option C: Strawberry angiomas

  • Strawberry angioma is characterized by benign, vascular proliferations that may bleed with trauma, like the lesions in this patient.
  • However, strawberry angiomas usually develop in the first weeks of life on the head or neck and then involute by 5–8 years of age.

Option D: Amelanotic melanoma

  • Amelanotic melanoma is characterized by a rare variant of melanoma that manifests as a skin-coloured or red papule or nodule.
  • Amelanotic melanoma may also bleed with trauma. However, unlike multiple lesions, this condition typically manifests as a solitary lesion.

questions.text: Axilla was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis 2 years ago when she was 13 years old. She was managed with steroid therapy. Now she presents to the ER with a 36-hour history of nausea, severe bloody diarrhea, and crampy abdominal pain. On examination, she is febrile and pale. She has a BP of 90/60 mmHg and an HR of 128 bpm. On examination, her abdomen is distended and diffusely tender. Leukocytosis is demonstrated in a CBC with a left shift. The patient receives IV fluid resuscitation and nasogastric tube decompression. Which of the following could be the choice for further therapeutic intervention?

choices.text: high-dose IV steroids and broad-spectrum antibiotics

questions.solution:
This patient presents with an acute exacerbation of ulcerative colitis with systemic toxicity. Toxic megacolon is potentially life-threatening and requires aggressive fluid resuscitation, bowel rest, and systemic antibiotics. High-dose steroids are initiated to treat colonic inflammation.

Option A: Opioid antidiarrheals are contraindicated in this case, because they may increase colonic distention and increase the risk of perforation.

Option B: Colonoscopy may cause increased colonic distention with perforation.

Option C: 6-mercaptopurine is also an immunosuppressive agent that may be beneficial in the treatment of steroid-refractory colitis, but they are not indicated in the management of an acute toxic exacerbation.

questions.text: A Cricket player was hit in the head & becomes unconscious. After sometimes he becomes conscious. After the match, he lost his consciousness & was taken to the hospital. The diagnosis could be
questions.solution:
This patient is showing lucid interval seen in Extradural haemorrhage

Lucid interval

  • The period of consciousness between two unconsciousness

The patient lose consciousness immediately on impact due to concussion then regains his consciousness then again becomes unconsciousness due to brain compression eventually leading to death.

Medico-legal importance in Lucid interval-

  • Valid will
  • Valid evidence
  • Criminally viable

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman, P3L3 presents to the physician with amenorrhea since 10 months. Her previous cycles were regular, coming at one month intervals, however since the last one year the cycles gradually kept delaying with increasing intervals between periods. Her pregnancy test is negative and a pelvic ultrasound done shows no significant pathology. Her laboratory reports show TSH 4.5 mIU/mL, FSH 42 mIU/mL, Hb 8.9 gm%. Which of the following is the correct explanation of such presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient, in menopausal age group has presented with secondary amenorrhea with raised FSH, this is suggestive of menopause. Menopause is caused by ovarian failure. Presence of delayed cycles may be noted prior to menopause.

Menopause occurs due to Ovarian failure which occurs due to programmed apoptosis of ovarian follicles.

The HPO axis remains intact even in older women and because of the integrity of this axis, there is an increase in FSH due to loss of inhibitory feedback of estrogens on pituitary. Due to exhaustion of ovarian function after menopause, the estrogen levels decline. As a result of low estrogen, the feedback inhibition of gonadotropins is lost, thus increasing levels of FSH and LH.

An FSH level of >10 mIU/mL is suggestive of menopause and >40 mIU/mL is diagnostic of menopause.

- Menopause is characterised by absence of periods in women of menopausal age group and raised FSH, due to absence of negative feedback of estrogens. Estrogen deficiency occurs secondary to ovarian failure.

questions.text: A student researcher is trying to decipher the path of a biochemical reactions that take place in the liver using labelled isotopes. When he supplies nitrogen isotope (14N) labelled glutamate to cultured hepatocytes he finds that the label is first showing up in the oxaloacetate and finally in aspartate after some time. Which of the following substances is most likely involved in this reaction?
questions.solution:
The glutamate is undergoing transamination in which labelled NH3 group is getting transferred to oxaloacetate and then finally to aspartate in a transamination reaction as shown in figure below.In a transamination reaction, amino group is transferred to the α-keto acid from one amino acid, converting the α-keto acid into an amino acid.

Pyridoxine (vitamin B6)in the form of pyridoxal phosphate is a required cofactor for the transaminases as well as decarboxylases in amino acid metabolism

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient is being planned for spine surgery on the lumbar spine. The surgeon has opted for an anterior approach through the abdomen. He asks the resident to contact the blood bank and the ____bank. The resident thinks he has misheard the second term. What do you think the consultant has said?
questions.solution:
? With anterior exposures of the lower lumbar spine, there is a small risk of retrograde ejaculation attributed to autonomic nerve injury. If this approach is selected, some patients may want to use a sperm bank preoperatively. Intraoperatively, limiting the use of electrocautery and gently dissecting only the area needed to access the disc space reduces this risk.

? Knowing what complications can result as a part of the surgery will make a surgeon much more able to deal with them preemptively. It's a good surgeon who knows how to plan instead of just reacting.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male patient presented to the emergency department from a local hospital seven hours after a snake bite. He maintained oxygenation till the evening of admission day when he suddenly developed desaturation episodes. The trachea was intubated for management of respiratory failure following the neurotoxic snake bite. The intracuff pressure of tracheal tubes to prevent tracheal mucosal injury is
questions.solution:
The ideal intracuff pressure of tracheal tubes to prevent injury to the trachea is 20-30 cm H2O or 15-22 mmHg.

>40 cm H2O or 30 mm Hg is considered high

<20 cm H2O or 15 mm Hg is considered low

questions.text: A 56-year-old construction worker came into your office complaining of knee pain. He stated that, his nature of work requires to be on his knee for hours together for several times in a week. Which bursae will be most likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patella and the overlying skin and the prepatellar tendon is the location of the prepatellar bursa. It is lined by synovium and contains very little fluid. The main function is to minimize or diminish the friction and ensure the maximal range of motion at the knee. Chronic trauma (like repeated kneeling) is one cause of prepatellar bursitis. It is also called as ‘housemaid’s knee’. commonly seen in roofers, plumbers and carpet layers.

Knee pain, swelling, redness, and inability to flex the knee on the affected side are common symptoms of prepatellar bursitis. Physical examination will reveal tenderness to palpation, erythema, crepitance and fluctuant edema over the lower pole of the patella.

Choice A, B & D - prolonged kneeling is not associated with the suprapatellar, popliteal or gastrocnemius inflammation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old women presents to the office with the complains of aching and morning stiffness about the shoulders, hip girdle, and neck. Her ESR and CRP are elevated. Rheumatoid factor (RF) and anticyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies, are negative. The patient was eventually diagnosed with polymyalgia rheumatica. Which one of the following is true about polymyalgia rheumatica?

choices.text: It is associated with giant cell (temporal) arteritis.
It does not respond to low-dose corticosteroids.

questions.solution:
Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is an inflammatory rheumatic condition characterized clinically by aching and morning stiffness about the shoulders, hip girdle, and neck. It can be associated with giant cell arteritis (GCA, also known as Horton disease, Horton giant cell arteritis, and temporal arteritis); the two disorders may represent different manifestations of a shared disease process.

- Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is an inflammatory rheumatic condition characterized clinically by aching and morning stiffness about the shoulders, hip girdle, and neck. It can be associated with giant cell arteritis.

questions.text: A bacterium can divide every 20 minutes. Beginning with a single individual, how many bacteria will be there in the population if there is exponential growth for 3 hours?
questions.solution:
P = C (1 + r)n

Where, P = Final value

C = Initial value

r = fraction increase

n = no. of times increase

In the given question,A bacterium can divide every 20 minutes and exponential growth is for 3 hours,

Thus, C = 1,

And r = 1 (it doubles every time)

n = 3 hours/20 minute = 9 times

Thus P = C (1 + r)n = 1 (1 + 1)9 = 29 = 512

  • One another Simple Way of Doing IT ·
  • Given information: A bacterium can divide every 20 minutes (3/hour) ·
  • Thus in 3 hours, it will total divide 3/hour ´ 3 hours = 9 times ·
  • Thus 9 times multiplication will successively yield 2, 4,8,16,32,64,128,256,512 bacteria. So at end of 9 hours, there will be 512 bacteria

questions.text: A 34-years-old male comes to the outdoor patient department with complaints of episodic headaches, palpitations, and sweating. On physical examination, his chest shows pectus excavatum and a high extremities-to-body ratio. Growth is seen on her tongue, and a mass on the left flank is also palpated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: MEN2B

  • The clinical picture is closest to MEN2B, which is caused by the gain of function in the RET gene that regulates the membrane-bound tyrosine kinase receptor responsible for cell cycle regulation.
  • Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia is a group of inherited diseases caused by proliferative lesions (hyperplasias, adenomas & carcinomas) of multiple endocrine organs.
  • Types of MEN are MEN1, MEN2A, and MEN2B.
  • The patient complains of episodic headaches, palpitations, and sweating with a mass in the left flank, indicating Pheochromocytoma, the adrenal medulla tumour that releases catecholamines.
  • His pectus excavatum (grooved chest) and high extremities-to-body ratio indicate Marfanoid habitus, which is associated with MEN2B.
  • A growth in his tongue can be suspected of the mucosal neuroma, a benign growth of nerve tissue mostly seen on the tongue and intestine (presented as constipation when occurring here). It is the hallmark of MEN2B.
  • MEN2B is the combination of Pheochromocytoma, Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid, and Mucosal Neuroma and is closely associated with Marfanoid habitus.
MULTIPLE ENDOCRINE NEOPLASIA

MEN 1
  • Pituitary adenoma [prolactin secreting macro-adenoma]
  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pancreatic tumours [Zollinger Ellison syndrome]

MEN 2A
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Parathyroid adenoma
MEN 2B
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Marfanoid habitus
  • Mucosal neuromas

Option A: MEN 1

  • MEN 1 presents as a combination of Pituitary, Pancreas, and Parathyroid tumours.
  • It is caused by a mutation in Menin, a tumour suppressor gene.

Option B: MEN2A

  • MEN2A is a combination of Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma, Pheochromocytoma, and Parathyroid adenoma.
  • A mutation in RET gene causes it.

Option D: Neurofibromatosis type 2

  • Neurofibromatosis type 2 is caused by a mutation in the NF2 tumour suppressor gene (merlin).
  • It can present with many tumours, such as Meningiomas, Bilateral Shwannomas, Ependymomas, etc.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida at 38 weeks started experiencing pain and was taken to the gynecology emergency room. On examination by the first-year junior resident on duty, it was found that she had real labor pain, delivery was vacuum-assisted, and the neonate was kept in the NICU for low birth weight and elevated bilirubin levels. The nurse on duty in the NICU observes an edematous, non-tender swelling over the left parietal bone with distinct margins not crossing suture lines, which is firm and boggy. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option A

Option A. Cephalhematoma: This is the correct answer. A cephalhematoma is a collection of blood between the periosteum and the skull bone. It typically occurs due to birth trauma, such as during vacuum-assisted delivery. The swelling is usually limited by the suture lines, leading to distinct margins. Over time, the blood undergoes resorption, causing the swelling to become firm and boggy. Cephalhematomas do not cross suture lines and are non-tender. Elevated bilirubin levels might suggest hyperbilirubinemia due to hemolysis, which can be associated with traumatic birth. Unlike other conditions, cephalhematomas do not communicate with other potential spaces in the scalp.

Incorrect option 

B.Caput succedaneum: Caput succedaneum refers to edema that occurs over the presenting part of the fetal head during labor or delivery. It often crosses suture lines and tends to be soft and pitting rather than firm and boggy. It's a result of pressure during delivery and resolves without specific treatment.

C.Subgaleal hemorrhage: Subgaleal hemorrhage involves bleeding into the potential space between the scalp and the cranial aponeurosis. It can be extensive, leading to a boggy and fluctuant swelling that crosses suture lines. It carries a risk of severe blood loss and hypovolemia.

D.Subdural hematoma: Subdural hematomas are located beneath the dura mater within the cranial cavity. They usually result from significant trauma and are not typically associated with vacuum-assisted deliveries. Subdural hematomas can lead to neurological symptoms due to pressure on the brain.

questions.text:
Which among the following is/are the examples of primordial prevention?
1. Adopting healthy lifestyles from childhood                                                                                                                                        2. Immunization of infants                                                                                                                                                                                  3. Screening of cervical cancer
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution: Immunization and screening are examples of primary prevention

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman has consulted the doctor to abort her 10-week-old fetus. The woman allegedly has been harassed by her in-laws and is not willing to continue with the pregnancy. The husband and his parents are threatening the doctor to not proceed with the abortion. According to the MTP Act of 1971, consent from whom is needed by the doctor to legally proceed with the abortion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - pregnant women:

  • Only the consent of the pregnant woman is necessary.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Guardian:

  • For a minor or insane person – consent from a guardian is required.

Option C - Pregnant women and husband:

  • Only the consent of the pregnant woman is necessary.
  • Consent from the husband is not necessary.

Option D - Husband of the lady:

  • Consent from husband- not necessary.

questions.text: During thyroidectomy, while attempting to ligate the inferior thyroid artery, the surgeon damages a nerve that lies in close proximity to it. Which nerve is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The thyrocervical trunk (a branch of subclavian artery) gives rise to the inferior thyroid artery. Superior thyroid arteries (branches of external carotid arteries) along with inferior thyroid arteries provide blood supply to the thyroid and parathyroid glands. From the thyrocervical trunk the inferior thyroid artery courses deep to the vagus nerve, common carotid artery and internal jugular vein before turning toward the thyroid. Before entering the thyroid gland this artery courses just superficial to the recurrent laryngeal nerve. The recurrent laryngeal nerve is a branch of vagus nerve that loops below the aortic arch on the left and below the subclavian artery on the right to provide motor innervation to the muscles of the larynx.

Choice A- accessory nerve. It exits the jugular foramen and supplies the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles on either side.

Choice B- hypoglossal nerve. It innervates all the intrinsic muscles of the tongue (except palatoglossus). this nerve exits the cranium through the hypoglossal canal.

Choice C- ansa cervicalis. It is a loop of cervical plexus that receives contributions from CI,C2 & C3. these branches innervate sternohyoid, sternothyroid and omohyoid muscles.

Choice D- superior laryngeal nerve. It is a branch of vagus nerve. It has internal and external branches. Superior thyroid artery courses with the external branch of this nerve

questions.text: A 19-year-old man is admitted to the psychiatry ward with concerns that his classmate has been spying on him for the last 6months. He stopped attending college a month back and appears withdrawn at home, frequently seen muttering while alone. He has stopped attending phone calls and prefers to keep the phone with his parents in another room. In the interview, he appears guarded about the reasons for his changed behavior. He reports keeping his phone away for ‘safety reasons. On prompting further, he writes on a paper “they are watching all day, please leave or else they will know”. He makes frequent gestures to himself in the examination room but refuses to admit the same. The patient’s mother recalls her father being treated for a similar illness while she was young. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Schizophrenia: The above case vignette presents a case of Primary psychotic disorder, most likely Schizophrenia. The young patient in the above case scenario has a delusion against his friend, a delusion of being constantly watched. He appears guarded about hearing voices or seeing images but is found exhibiting hallucinatory behavior at home and in the examination room. There is a family history of psychiatric illness in the patient’s maternal grandfather which indicates a genetic predisposition to the same. The symptoms meet the duration criteria of 6 months. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is Schizophrenia.

Option A: Schizoid personality disorder: This can be differentiated from Schizophrenia by the presence of sub-threshold features characterized by long-standing patterns of discomfort in making close relationships, odd beliefs, and thinking patterns. In the given scenario, the patient has an onset of symptoms for 6 months, before which his social and occupational functioning was adequate.

Option B: Borderline personality disorder: It is a personality disorder characterized by a pervasive pattern of variable mood, intense anger, depression, lasting for few hours to days, intense and unstable relationships, chronic sense of emptiness, self-harm behaviors. None of these features are present in the given clinical scenario.

Option D: Delusional disorder: It is a primary psychotic disorder presenting with false, unshakeable beliefs. Symptoms like auditory hallucinations, visual hallucinations, disorganized speech, negative symptoms are classically absent in delusional disorder.

questions.text: A cataract is an opacity in the clear lens that leads to blurry vision. The opacities have different shapes depending on the cause. In shield cataracts, the opacity is shaped like a shield. Which of the following statements is true about shield cataracts?

choices.text: Seen in the 5th-6th decade of life
Dense anterior subcapsular plaque that wrinkles the anterior capsule

questions.solution:
Option D: Dense anterior subcapsular plaque that wrinkles the anterior capsule

  • Shield cataracts have an anterior subcapsular opacity.
  • This opacity is shaped like a shield.
  • It wrinkles the anterior capsule leading to blurry vision.

Option A: It is mostly unilateral

  • Shield cataracts are usually bilateral.
  • They mature rapidly.

Option B: Seen in the 5th-6th decade of life

  • Shield cataracts are seen in the 2nd-4th decade of life.
  • Senile cataracts are seen in the 5th-6th decade.

Option C: Associated with blunt trauma

  • Shield cataracts are due to atopic dermatitis.
  • Stellate cataracts are associated with blunt trauma.

questions.text: Read the pedigree chart and identify the pattern of transmission:
questions.solution:
If each affected individual in chart have affected previous generation: it is dominant condition. If there is selective male to female transmission: most likely it is X linked condition. Male to male transmission is seen in autosomal condition.

In any situation when previous generation of affected individual is not affected, the condition is recessive.

In X linked recessive disease, female won’t be having the disease but she will transmit to her son.

questions.text: A city with 800 deaths per year. In mortuary body is stored for an average duration of 8 days with 80% occupancy in a year. What number of mortuary beds are needed per day?
questions.solution:
Option A: 14

Total number of beds = no. of deaths X average duration of storage

= 800 X 8

= 6400 beds per year

Bed needed Per day = 6400/365 = 17.5 beds per day

This is true for 100% occupancy.

Since in this question they asked for 80% occupancy,

= 17.5/80 X 100

= 14 beds per day

Learning Objective

  • Total number of beds = no. of deaths X average duration of storage

questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of the following levels of prevention?

Specific protection
Early diagnosis and prompt treatment
Disability limitation and rehabilitation
Health promotion

Select the correct sequence from the code given below:
questions.solution:
Option B: 4, 1, 2, 3

The correct sequence:

  • Health Promotion, Specific protection (Primary Level), Then early diagnosis and prompt treatment (Secondary level) then followed by disability limitation and rehabilitation (Tertiary level).

LEVELS OF PREVENTION

Primordial level

  • Before the emergence of risk factors
  • Modes of Intervention: Health education

Primary level

  • Risk factors are present, but no disease
  • Can prevent disease or outcome
  • Modes: Health promotion & Specific protection

Secondary level

  • Disease possibly started
  • Cannot prevent
  • Modes: Early diagnosis & Treatment

Tertiary level

  • Disease in progression or over
  • Modes: Disability limitation & Rehabilitation

Option A: 1, 2, 3, 4

  • This is not the correct sequence of prevention.

Option C: 2, 3, 4, 1

  • The correct sequence: Health Promotion, Specific protection (Primary Level), Then early diagnosis and prompt treatment (Secondary level) then followed by disability limitation and rehabilitation (Tertiary level).

Option D: 3, 4, 1, 2

  • This is not the correct sequence of prevention.

questions.text: A 37-year-old primigravida has conceived after ovulation induction and presents for routine antenatal evaluation. She has no complains at present and she is 12 weeks gestation from her date of last menstrual period. Her doctor advises her for an aneuploidy screening test, considering her advanced age of conception. She has no past or family history of aneuploidies. Which of the following is the most appropriate test(s) to be prescribed at this stage?

choices.text: Dual marker + ultrasound for nuchal translucency
Quadruple marker + ultrasound for nasal bone

questions.solution:
Dual marker along with ultrasound for nuchal translucency is a first trimester screening test for aneuploidies (Downs’s syndrome and other trisomies). Chorionic villous sampling is also done at this gestation, but it is a diagnostic test.

Screening tests for aneuploidies

FIRST TRIMESTER:11-13 weeks: DUAL MARKER + Nuchal Translucency (80% sensitive)

PAPP-A Free B hcg
DUAL MARKER Decreases Increases

SECOND TRIMESTER : TRIPLE/ QUADRUPLE MARKERS (16-18 weeks)

Free B hcg AFP Unconjugated estriol Inhibin A
TRIPLE MARKER Increases Decreases Decreases
QUADRUPLE MARKER (80% sensitive) Increases Decreases Decreases Increases

INTEGRATED SCREENING: First + second trimester screen: 94-96% sensitivity : BEST for screening

Ultrasound level II or detailed anomaly scan to look for soft tissue markers to be done at 18-22 weeks

Diagnostic tests

  1. Chorionic villus sampling - done at First trimester (10-13th weeks)
  2. Amniocentesis - done at second trimester (16-18th weeks)
  3. Percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (cordocentesis) - done after 18 weeks.

- Screening for downs syndrome can be done by serum markers in the first trimester ( Dual marker: PAPP-A and bHCG) and second trimester( Triple marker with bHCG, AFP, uE3 or Quadruple with Inhibin added), USG in First trimester (for Nuchal translucency and nasal bone detection) & second trimester (anomaly scan)

questions.text:
Match the following




1. Biliopancreatic diversion
2. Roux-en-Y gastric bypass
3. Sleeve gastrectomy
4. Vertical banded gastroplasty
5. Laparoscopic adjustable gastric band


a) Restrictive procedure
b) Largely restrictive & mildly malabsorptive
c) Largely malabsorptive & mildly restrictive
d) Malabsorptive procedure
questions.solution:
(Option C)1 - c; 2 - a; 3 - a; 4 - b; 5 - a is the answer.

Bariatric surgery

Bariatric procedures are classified as restrictive, malabsorptive, or a combination of restrictive and malabsorptive based on the mechanism of weight loss.

Bariatric operation Mechanism of action

− Vertical banded gastroplasty

− Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding (Safest & reversible)

- Sleeve gastrectomy

 - Restrictive
− Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB): MC performed procedure now-a-days − Largely Restrictive / Moderately malabsorptive

Bilopancreatic diversion(Maximum weight loss)

Duodenal switch

 Largely Malabsorptive/Mildly Restrictive

Learning objective:

Gastric bypass and other weight-loss surgeries are collectively known as bariatric surgery which can be done either through open surgery or with the use of laparoscopy. It involves making changes to the digestive system to help patients to lose weight. Bariatric surgery is done when diet and exercise haven't worked or when the patient has serious health problems because of obesity. Every bariatric procedure follows certain mechanisms.

Primarily Restrictive - Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding (LAGB), Sleeve gastrectomy (SG).

Primarily Malabsorptive - Biliopancreatic diversion (BPD), Duodenal switch (DS).

Combination of both restrictive and malabsorptive - Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB).

questions.text: In a population of 5000, the number of new cases of TB is 500; old cases in the same population are 150. What is the prevalence of TB?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: 13%

  • Prevalence is the total number of cases at the given point of time.
  • Prevalence = total number of cases [new+old cases]/ total population x 100 = (650/5000) ×100 =13%

questions.text: A 30 years old car driver was involved in an accident. He is brought to ER with complaints of breathlessness. On physical examination, vitals are PR: 110/min, BP= 90/60 mm Hg and temperature of 37oC. Extensive bruising is noticed on right side of the chest. An urgent beside chest X-ray was performed. What is the best management of this case?
questions.solution:
• Patient is unstable as the pulse rate is > 100 & SBP < 100mmhg
  • X ray performed suggests the diagnosis of Flail chest as 2 or more ribs fracture at 2 consecutive places.
  • Preferred treatment for Flail chest is Elective intubation and IPPV.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department one hour after sustaining a traumatic injury during a high-speed motor vehicle collision. There are multiple bruises over the face, trunk, and right upper and lower extremities. There is swelling of the right elbow and wrist. The right lower extremity is shorter than the left lower extremity. There are multiple traumatic lacerations on both lower limbs, as shown in the image below:



 

 

 

 

 

Which of the following is the most appropriate term to describe the traumatic injury of this patient shown in the picture?

choices.text: Separation of skin and subcutaneous tissue
Separation of tendon exposing the bone

questions.solution:
Option B: Separation of skin and subcutaneous tissue

  • This patient most likely suffers from a traumatic degloving injury due to trauma sustained during the high-speed motor vehicle accident.
  • A degloving injury is characterized by an injury in which the skin & subcutaneous fat are stripped by avulsion from the underlying fascia leaving neurovascular structures, tendons or bone exposed, such as bilateral degloving injury of lower limbs due to a truck trampling.
  • The diagnosis is by clinical examination and detailed history.
  • Managing the degloving injury is by surgical debridement followed by immediate full-thickness skin grafting.

Option A: Separation of skin

  • This option does not describe the degloving injury.

Option C: Separation of fascia exposing tendons

  • This option does not describe the degloving injury.

Option D: Separation of tendon exposing the bone

  • This option does not describe the degloving injury.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male, came with History of Snake bite. On examination,patient had localised swelling (Progressive).Patient was started on Anti snake venom to neutralize the snake venom. Snake venom contains which of the following phospholipases?
questions.solution:
• Snake venom
  • Contains Phospholipase A2 (PLA2)
  • PLA 2 hydrolyze the ester bond at position 2 of phospholipids present in plasma membrane of various cells, eg : erythrocytes.
  • PLA 2 also affects neurons at pre-synaptic or post-synaptic cleft to cause neurotoxicity.
Phospholipases
A1 A2 C D
Present in Pancreatic fluid Present in Erythrocytes and snake venom Major toxins secreted by bacteria Role in Mammalian signal transduction

questions.text: A physician is called to a factory to help a worker who amputated his finger in a machine. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management in this situation?

choices.text: Place the amputated finger in a plastic bag with water and bring it along with the patient to the emergency department
Place the amputated finger in a plastic bag with alcohol and bring it along with the patient to the emergency department
Place the amputated finger in saline moistened gauze in a plastic bag; place the bag on a bed of ice and bring it along with the patient to the emergency department
Place the amputated finger in antiseptic solution and bring it along with the patient to the emergency department

questions.solution:
The amputated limb or digit should be wrapped in sterile gauze, moistened with sterile saline, and placed in a plastic bag. The bag should be then placed on ice and transported with the patient to the nearest emergency department. The amputated part should not be allowed to freeze. Packaging of the amputated part in this manner prolongs the viability of the part for up to 24 hours.

Choice A: The amputated part should not be immersed in water as this may make digital vessel repair more difficult.

Choices B and D: The amputated part should not be placed in antiseptic solution or alcohol as chemical injury may occur.

Note: In case of amputation injury, amputated parts should be wrapped in saline-moistened gauze, sealed in a plastic bag, placed on ice and brought to the emergency department with the patient.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the ER for nose bleeding. He reports having similar episode 6 months ago when he returned back to the US from India. He is an engineer by profession. He works out 5 times a week and has an active lifestyle. On physical examination there are several papules on his lips. This patient also has digital clubbing. Rest physical examination is normal. His hematocrit is elevated. What is the most liely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome (hereditary hemorrhagictelangiectasia) is an inherited disorder of blood vessels. Findings: blanching skin lesions (telangiectasias), recurrent epistaxis, skin discolorations, arteriovenous malformations (AVMs), GI bleeding, hematuria.

arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) in the lungs can shunt blood from right to left side of the heart, causing chronic hypoxemia and reactive polycythemia.

Patients with Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome can develop pulmonary AVMs. Think about this diagnosis in patient with recurrent nose bleed and oral lesions.

questions.text: Correct sequence in Gram staining?

choices.text: Methyl violet → Iodine → Acetone → Carbol fuchsin
Carbol fuchsin → Iodine → Acetone → Methyl violet
Methyl violet → Acetone → Iodine → Carbol fuchsin
Methyl violet → Carbol fuchsin → Acetone → Iodine

questions.solution:
Option a, b, c, d

1. Gram stain: It was devised by Christian Gram, a Danish microbiologist, in 1884, as a convenient method for classifying bacteria. The Gram staining method essentially consists of four steps:

  • (i) Primary staining with basic dyes, such as methyl violet, crystal violet, etc.
  • (ii) Application of mordant in the form of dilute solution of iodine.
  • (iii) Decolorization with ethanol, acetone, or aniline.
  • (iv) Counterstaining with acidic dyes, such as carbol fuchsin, safranine, or neutral red.

2. Gram-positive bacteria are those that resist decolorization and retain the primary dye-iodine complex, appearing violet. They have a relatively thick amorphous wall and more acidic protoplasm which are believed to retain the basic violet dye and iodine complex within the cell.

3. Gram-negative bacteria are decolorized by organic solvents and take counterstain, appearing pink. The decolorizing agent, such as acetone or ethanol, used during staining disrupts this membran-ous envelope, and the dye and iodine complex is washed out of Gram-negative bacteria.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman is suffering from carcinoma of the uterus (fundus area). Cancer cells are likely to metastasize directly to which of the following lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
• The superficial inguinal nodes receive lymph from the buttocks, labia majora, the upper part of the uterus, and the lower parts of the vagina and anal canal.
• These nodes have efferent vessels that drain primarily to the external iliac and common iliac nodes and eventually to the lumbar (aortic) nodes.
• The internal iliac nodes receive lymph from the upper rectum, vagina, uterus, and other pelvic organs and drain into the common iliac nodes and then into the lumbar (aortic) nodes

Part of uterus Draining lymph nodes
Fundus Pre and para aortic lymph nodes
Isthmus Round ligament lymphatics- superficial ingiunal LN
Mid uterus External iliac LN
lower uterus(cervix) everywhere except inguinal LN

questions.text: A 16-years-old male is brought to the outdoor patient department with painless swelling on his neck. On examination, swelling is smooth, non-tender, moving well with deglutition, and moving upon the tongue's protrusion. Microscopically, the mass cystic lesions lined by pseudostratified columnar epithelium, with no lymphoid tissue present. Which of the following is the appropriate diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Thyroglossal duct cyst

  • Painless swelling in the neck that moves up on the protrusion of the tongue is suggestive of a thyroglossal duct cyst
  • The thyroid gland arises from the Thyroid Diverticulum that arises from the floor of the primitive pharynx and then descends into the neck. It is connected to the tongue by the thyroglossal duct. Normally Thyroglossal duct disappears but may persist as a cyst or pyramidal lobe of the thyroid.
  • A Thyroglossal cyst is a cystic remnant of the thyroglossal duct. It is due to persistence and cystic dilation of the thyroglossal duct.
  • Most commonly found in the hyoid region, always close to the midline.
  • It is congenital, but the usual age of presentation is between 15 - 30 years.
  • There is an increased risk of malignancy such as papillary Carcinoma.
  • The cyst moves with deglutition and the only swelling that moves up on tongue protrusion.
  • Histologically, it contains an epithelial lining of squamous or pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium and ectopic thyroid gland tissue in the duct wall.

Option B: Branchial cleft cyst

  • A branchial cleft cyst is also present as a mass in the anterior neck, but it does not move up with the protrusion of the tongue.
  • It is caused by persistent cervical sinus.

Option C: Dentigerous cyst

  • Dentigerous cyst is an odontogenic cyst that includes a tooth that does not complete the eruption process and occurs around the crown by accumulating fluid between the layer of the enamel organ.

Option D: Dermoid cyst

  • A dermoid cyst is a sac-like growth present at birth.
  • It contains structures such as hair, teeth and skin glands, etc.
  • It is usually seen in the face, skull, ovaries, and lower back.

questions.text: What is the failure rate of male Condoms with typical use?
questions.solution:
Option A: 10-14/HWY

The failure rate of condom with

  • Perfect use is 2-3/HWY
  • Typical use is 10-14/HWY

Option B: 5-21/HWY

  • When using female condoms, this failure rate happens.
  • The failure rate of female condoms in pearl index is 5-12/HWY

Option C: 0.1-2/HWY

  • This least rage of failure occurs in OCP.
  • The failure rate of OCPs in pearl index is 0.1-2/HWY

Learning Objective

PEARL INDEX OF DIFFERENT CONTRACEPTION:

  • Male condoms: 2-14/HWY [14- best answer]
  • Female condoms: 5-21/HWY [21- best answer]
  • IUD: 1-5 / HWY [2- best answer]
  • OCPs: 0.1-2/HWY [1- best answer]
  • Sterilization 0.1/HWY
  • Vaginal sponge: 9-20/HWY

More effective method of sterilization is vasectomy > tubectomy.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presented acutely with worsening frontal headaches. She had a 3-month history of lethargy, reduced appetite, weight loss, cough, and intermittent fevers. A chest X-ray showed a left upper lobe consolidation, and a CT head showed multiple enhancing lesions with significant surrounding edema in both cerebral hemispheres. Tuberculoma was suspected and sent to the radiological department for MR spectroscopy. Which peak on MR spectroscopy is seen in tuberculoma?
questions.solution:
• MR-spectroscopy usually reveals a large lipid lactate peak at 0.9 to 1.33 ppm and reduced NAA.
  • The lipid peak in tuberculoma is primarily due to the predominant lipid content in the cell wall of tubercle bacillus.
  • Presence of lactate indicates anaerobic glycolysis and necrosis within the Tuberculoma.
  • However, lipid lactate peak can also be seen in other conditions having necrosis like high grade gliomas [GBM].

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a history of stage IV pancreatic adenocarcinoma was referred for a second opinion for a worsening dry cough in the setting of cavitary ground-glass opacities and non-cavitating nodules found on chest CT.
