The previous workup was non-diagnostic and his CT findings were atypical for pulmonary metastasis. Due to his extensive alternative therapy use, he was diagnosed with interstitial lung disease (ILD). Flexible bronchoscopy with transbronchial cryo biopsies revealed adenocarcinoma with intestinal/pancreaticobiliary differentiation consistent with metastatic pancreatic cancer. The most common gene mutation that you would expect in a case of pancreatic adenocarcinoma is :
questions.solution:
Pancreatic cancer

  • Pancreatic cancer is more common in older adults with most patients being 75 to 84 years old. It is slightly more common in men than women. Risk factors include family history, smoking, alcohol and coffee consumption, diet high in fat and low in fibre, fruits and vegetables, diabetes mellitus, chronic pancreatitis
  • About two-thirds of pancreatic adenocarcinomas arise within the head or uncinate process of the pancreas; 15% are in the body and 10% are in the tail with the remaining tumours demonstrating diffuse involvement of the gland
  • Ductal adenocarcinoma makes upto 75% of nonendocrine cancers of the pancreas. Other less common types include adenosquamous carcinoma, acinic cell carcinoma
  • Genetics of pancreatic cancer
    • The K-Ras oncogene is currently thought to be the most commonly mutated gene in pancreatic cancer with approximately 90% of tumours having a mutation. The Her2/neu oncogene is overexpressed in pancreatic cancer. Multiple tumour suppressor genes are deleted and/or mutated in pancreatic cancer, including p53, p16 and DPC 4(Smad 4) and in a minority of cases , BRCA2
    • Rare familial cancer syndromes that are associated with an increased risk of pancreatic cancer include BRCA2, Familial atypical multiple mole melanoma syndrome , Hereditary pancreatitis, Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), Hereditary non polyposis colorectal cancer, Peutz Jeghers syndrome and Ataxia telangiectasia

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complains of episodes of feeling of intense warmth and flushing, followed by sweating. These episodes subside on their own and are aggravated by hot temperatures. She has no history of palpitations, weight loss. She had a hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy 6 months back for fibroid uterus. Examination shows PR 76/min, BP 110/76 mmHg, temp: 98.6’F, chest and CVS examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the next best step in management of this patient?

choices.text: Temperature charting and oral paracetamol sos

questions.solution:
This patient has presented with vasomotor symptoms that occur after menopause due to estrogen deficiency, in this case menopause is secondary to hysterectomy with oophorectomy. Estrogen replacement (hormone replacement therapy) is indicated for vasomotor symptoms.

Menopause occurs due to Ovarian failure which occurs due to programmed apoptosis of ovarian follicles. Due to exhaustion of ovarian function after menopause, the estrogen levels decline. As a result of low estrogen, vasomotor symptoms are caused. Symptoms of menopause

  • Vasomotor symptoms : hot flashes : feeling of intense warmth, flushing followed by sweating
  • Urogenital atrophy : vaginal dryness, urinary infections
  • Breast atrophy
  • Sexual dysfunction
  • Psychological : mood swings, irritability, depression

Hormone Replacement Therapy is indicated in menopausal women to overcome the short term and long term consequences of estrogen deficiency. Indications of hormone replacement therapy in a menopausal woman

  • Relief of vasomotor symptoms: hot flushes
  • Prevention and treatment of osteoporosis
  • Urogenital atrophy
  • Premature Menopause

- Vasomotor symptoms present after menopause due to estrogen deficiency. Hormone replacement is the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: A 16 year old female thalassemia patient has come to the hospital for follow-up. She has complained of weakness and shortness of breath. CBC shows haemoglobin less than 6 mg/dl. The consultant planned to transfuse 2 units of blood. On duty, an intern was sent to the blood bank to arrange the blood. The blood bank personnel told the intern that the blood units had been in storage for a long time. Which of the following is the most likely complication of transfusing prolonged stored blood?
questions.solution:
Option B: Potassium toxicity

  • Red blood cells degrade progressively during the weeks of refrigerated storage.
  • Preservative solutions can lengthen the shelf life of red blood cells by as long as 7 weeks.
  • Transfusion of stored RBCs, particularly those at the end of the approved shelf life, has been associated with adverse clinical outcomes.
  • Prolonged storage of blood can lead to hyperkalemia due to lysis of RBC.
  • Prolonged stored blood may show increased extravascular haemolysis, disruption in iron hemostasis, and the circulating non–transferrin-bound iron formation.

Option A: Citrate intoxication

  • Citrate intoxication → Hypocalcemia, manifested by circumoral numbness and/or tingling sensation of the fingers and toes.
  • It is a complication of massive transfusion of blood.

Option C: Circulatory overload

  • Circulatory overload is a complication of massive blood transfusion.
  • Circulatory overload → Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO).
  • Signs and symptoms of TACO are dyspnoea and bilateral infiltrates on CXR with systolic hypertension and elevated levels of Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP).

Option D: Haemorrhagic diathesis

  • Haemorrhagic diathesis refers to an abnormal tendency to severe spontaneous bleeding.
  • It occurs due to vascular problems, vitamin K deficiency, low platelet counts, increased platelet destruction, liver disease, kidney failure, and anticoagulant therapy.

questions.text:
Consider the following four events of development of fetus:

Centers of ossification for calcaneum
Centers of ossification for lower end of femur
Centers of ossification for talus
Centers of ossification for cuboid

What is the order in which they appear from lower to higher gestation?
questions.solution:
Option A: 1, 3, 2, 4

The order in which they appear from lower to higher gestation:

1. Centers of ossification for calcaneum

  • 20 weeks: Center of ossification for calcaneum appears.

3. Centers of ossification for talus

  • 28 weeks: Center of ossification for talus appears.

2. Centers of ossification for lower end of femur

  • Ossification centers for lower end of femur (36–37 weeks).

4. Centers of ossification for cuboid

  • Cuboid and Capitate appear at birth.

questions.text: All the following spread by auto infection except:
questions.solution:
Parasites causing autoinfection are(C2HEST)
C- Capillaria philippinensis
Cryptosporidium parvum
H- Hymenolepis nana
E- Enterobius vermicularis
S- Strongyloides stercoralis
T- Taenia solium(Pork tapeworm)

Taenia solium have proglottids responsible for causing autoinfection.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about polyarteritis nodosa?
1) Leucocytoclastic vasculitis
2) ANCA positivity
3) HBsAg positivity
4) Renal involvement is absent
questions.solution:
This condition is characterized by necrotizing immune complex inflammation of small- and medium-sized arteries.

  1. It is marked by the destruction of arterial media and internal elastic lamella, resulting in aneurysmal nodules.
  2. There is an association with hepatitis B viral infection in 30% of patients.
  3. There is no association with ANCAs
  4. Clinical manifestations often include fever, weight loss, malaise, abdominal pain, headache, myalgia, and hypertension.

Polyarteritis nodosa is seen in the following sites:

  1. Kidneys, with immune complex vasculitis in the arterioles and glomeruli; renal lesions, and hypertension cause most deaths from polyarteritis nodosa.
  2. Coronary arteries, resulting in ischemic heart disease
  3. Musculoskeletal system, resulting in myalgia, arthralgia, or arthritis
  4. Gastrointestinal tract, manifesting as nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain
  5. Central nervous system (CNS) or peripheral nervous system, the eye, or skin

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is reported to have gestational diabetes mellitus during her first pregnancy. Her blood glucose levels came back to near normal after the child birth but her glucose levels during fasting remained modestly elevated. Her medical history indicated no past complications of any type but maternal side family history indicated a genetically predisposed gestational hyperglycemia. Based on this information, she most likely has deficiency of which one of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Post prandial (fed state) utilization of glucose is done byGlucokinaseenzyme due to lower affinity of this enzyme for glucose than other hexokinases. So, it acts as a glucose sensor for pancreatic beta cells and has a role in the insulin secretion based on the blood glucose levels entering the beta cells by controlling the flux of glucose to glycolytic pathway in these cells explained as:

After a meal, the blood glucose enters the beta cells through insulin independent GLUT-2 channels. This glucose is phosphorylated to glucose-6-P for entry in to glycolytic pathway ultimately resulting in the production of high amount of ATP by aerobic respiration in these cells. A high ATP to ADP ratio results in the closure of ATP-sensitive potassium (KATP) channels. Depolarization of beta cells results in opening of voltage-dependent calcium channel and resulting in insulin release due to high intracellular calcium levels.

Hereditary deficiency of glucokinase enzyme due to heterozygous mutation in glucokinase gene results in a diminished insulin secretion from beta cells resulting inmaturity-onset diabetes of the young. This condition is characterized by mild, non-progressive hyperglycemia that often worsens with pregnancy-induced insulin resistance.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male visits the clinic with complaints of abdominal discomfort for the last few months. He has no significant past medical history and does not take any medications. On examination, abdominal distension is found. On further investigations, a mass having the c-kit mutation is found. Which of the following is associated with this patient's underlying condition?

choices.text: Duodenum is the most common site
The high propensity of malignant change
Arises from intestinal cells of Cajal

questions.solution:
Option C: Arises from intestinal cells of Cajal

  • This patient, with a history of abdominal discomfort, distension, and a mass having the c-kit mutation, most likely has a Gastrointestinal stromal tumour (GIST).
  • GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumour of the abdomen.
  • It arises from benign pacemaker cells called intestinal cells of Cajal.
  • The majority of tumours have activating mutations of c-KIT / PDGFRA tyrosine kinases which respond to kinase inhibitors.

Option A: Duodenum is the most common site

  • The stomach is the most common site of GIST, not the Duodenum.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option B: High propensity of malignant change

  • GIST has a very low propensity for malignant change, and 90% of stomach GISTs are found to be benign.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option D: Histology shows squamous-shaped cells

  • The histology of GIST shows elongated spindle-shaped cells/ plumper epithelioid cells.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding atazanavir?

choices.text: Resistance is due to mutation in codon 50, isoleucine to valine substitution
Combination with Ritonavir does not have any advantage

questions.solution:
Option B: Resistance is due to a mutation in codon 50 isoleucine to valine substitution

  • Atazanavir belongs to a class of protease inhibitors.
  • Protease inhibitor medications inhibit protease enzymes. As a result, the HIV life cycle is disrupted because protease enzymes cannot play their part in helping HIV to multiply.
  • The resistance to atazanavir is due to a mutation in codon 50 isoleucine to valine substitution.

Option A: Effective against only HIV-1

  • Atazanavir is effective against HIV 1 and HIV 2, but NNRTI is effective only against HIV 1.

Option C: Decrease cholesterol and triglyceride levels

  • Protease inhibitors, including atazanavir, are notorious for causing lipid abnormalities and insulin resistance
  • Although this risk is lower with atazanavir, atazanavir does not decrease cholesterol and triglyceride levels.

Option D: Combination with Ritonavir does not have any advantage

  • CYP3A4 metabolises atazanavir, and Ritonavir is a potent CYP3A4 inhibitor.
  • So, their bio-availability is substantially improved with the addition of Ritonavir.
  • Combination with Ritonavir has an advantage due to the phenomenon of Ritonavir boosting.

questions.text: A 20-year-old girl, presents with history of rapidly developing hirsutism and amenorrhea with change in voice. To establish a diagnosis, you would like to proceed with which of the following tests in blood:
questions.solution:
‘Rapidly’ progressing hirsutism points to developing androgen secreting tumors, which could be a Leydig sertoli tumor of the ovary. For which estimation of androgens specifically serum testosterone should be an initial investigation along with a pelvic scan

A 17 OH progesterone should be estimated as well to rule out a late onset Congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

questions.text: A G3P2L2, previous 2 normal deliveries, presents to the labour room with labour pains and leaking PV. An HIV test done a few days back is positive, all other antenatal tests and obstetric USG are normal. She is not currently on ART and her viral RNA load is unknown. On examination, her BP is 120/78 mmHg, PR is 86/min, chest, CVS unremarkable, uterine contractions are 3 in 10 mins, fetal heart tracing is reactive. Pelvic exam shows a cervical dilatation of 5 cms, membranes ruptured with clear liquor and head is at +1 station. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Start a zidovudine drip and allow spontaneous delivery
Start a zidovudine drip and allow spontaneous delivery with episiotomy to reduce bearing down efforts
Start zidovudine drip and apply forceps to cut short second stage of labour

questions.solution:
This is an HIV positive patient presenting in active labour with ruptured membranes. An emergency caesarean section would not offer any advantage over a vaginal delivery now. This patient has no contraindication to vaginal delivery and has had two normal deliveries previously.

Mode of delivery

  • Caesarean section is advised if viral load is >1000 copies/ mL or in case of any obstetric indication. An elective LSCS is planned at 38 weeks to avoid spontaneous labour onset.
  • If patient presents in labour or membranes have ruptured, there is no advantage of doing caesarean.
  • Vaginal delivery can be done when there is no obstetric contraindication, viral load is <1000 copies/ml, or if patient presents in labour or with ruptured membranes

Intrapartum management

  • A zidovudine drip is started if viral load is > 1000 copies/mL or unknown near delivery or 3 hours before elective caesarean section
  • Artificial rupture of membranes, fetal scalp electrode placement, episiotomy and instrumentation should not be performed unless clearly indicated for obstetric reasons
  • Labour augmentation can be done to shorten interval to delivery to lower transmission
  • Delayed cord clamping for preterm neonates is acceptable
  • Neuraxial block for labour analgesia is acceptable
  • PPH is best managed with oxytocin and PG analogues. Methylergometrine is avoided in patients on protease inhibitors and reverse transcriptase inhibitors as it may cause severe vasoconstriction.

- Caesarean section is advised for HIV positive pregnant woman, if viral load is >1000 copies/ mL or in case of any obstetric indication. Vaginal delivery can be done when there is no obstetric contraindication, viral load is <1000 copies/ml, or if patient presents in labour or with ruptured membranes. For a patient presenting in labour, a zidovudine drip is started if viral load is > 1000 copies/mL or unknown near delivery. Artificial rupture of membranes, fetal scalp electrode placement, episiotomy and instrumentation should not be performed unless clearly indicated for obstetric reasons.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents because of multiple brown spots on his body. He has a history of mild developmental delay. Physical examination reveals flat, light brown spots on the skin approximately 5mm diameter in size, and freckling in his armpits areas. Ophthalmological examination reveals a tiny bump on the iris of the eye. A mutation on which of the following chromosomes is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is a multisystem genetic disorder that is characterized by cutaneous findings, most notably café-au-lait spots, and axillary freckling, by skeletal dysplasias, and by the growth of both benign and malignant nervous system tumors, most notably benign neurofibromas. Mild learning disabilities or developmental delay are also found in patients with NF1. It is caused by a loss of function of the NF1 gene, located on chromosome 17. This NF1 gene normally functions to regulate cell growth; mutated NF1, therefore, allows cells to undergo uncontrolled growth.

Option A: Tuberous sclerosis (TS), or tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC), is a rare genetic condition that causes noncancerous, or benign, tumors to grow in your brain, other vital organs, and skin. It is characterized by adenoma sebaceum, shagreen patches, cardiac rhabdomyomas, and cortical tubers. It can be caused by defects on chromosome 16.

Option C: Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is a hereditary condition most commonly associated with bilateral vestibular schwannomas, also known as acoustic neuromas. These are benign (noncancerous) tumors that occur on the nerves for balance and hearing leading to the inner ear but are not associated with the dermatological or ocular findings observed in this patient. It is caused by a defect on chromosome 22.

Option D: Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome is a hereditary condition associated with tumors arising in multiple organs. VHL-related tumors include hemangioblastomas, which are blood vessel tumors of the brain, spinal cord, and retina. But this disease does not cause the dermatologic or ocular findings seen in this patient. It is caused by defects on chromosome 3.

questions.text: Pneumocystis carnii pneumonia (PCP) is usually caused in AIDS patient. Which of following method is mostly used for its detection:-
questions.solution:
• Both methenamine-silver and toluidine blue stain pneumocysts nonspecifically.
  • These preparations are difficult to read because background material may nonspecifically stain black or blue.
  • Pneumocystis carinii cannot be routinely cultured from human specimens. Both IFA and DFA tests are FDA-approved and available for detection of P. carinii.
  • The advantage of DFA is that it is quicker (45 to 60 min versus 3 h) and there is less nonspecific fluorescence observed in the preparation.

questions.text: Imaging reveals a major blockage of his right coronary artery near the crux of the heart just proximal to the origin of the posterior interventricular artery. Which part of the heart would be affected by the ischemia that results from this blockage?

choices.text: Anterior two thirds of the interventricular septum

questions.solution:
• The AV nodal artery, which branches from the right coronary artery proximal to the origin of the posterior interventricular artery, usually supplies the AV node.
  • Option A: The SA node is supplied by the SA nodal artery, a branch of the proximal part of the right coronary artery, or by the circumflex branch of the left coronary artery.
  • Option C: The left anterior interventricular artery (LAD) supplies the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum.
  • Option D: The marginal branch of the right coronary artery supplies most of the right ventricle. Its origin is well proximal to the crux of the heart and would not be affected by this blockage.
Note:
The crux of the heart is the area on the lower backside of the heart where the coronary sulcus (the groove separating the atria from the ventricles) and the posterior interventricular sulcus (the groove separating the left from the right ventricle) meet.

questions.text:
Laryngeal paralysis may be unilateral or bilateral. Involvement of laryngeal nerve supply leads to vocal cord paralysis resulting in different positions on laryngeal examination. Which of the following statements are incorrect regarding the position of vocal cords?

1) Median position of vocal cords is in the midline

2) Paramedian position of vocal cords is 1.5 mm from the midline

3) Cadaveric position of vocal cords is 3.5 mm from the midline

4) Gentle abduction position of vocal cords is 9.5 mm from the midline
questions.solution:
Option D: Only 4

DIFFERENT POSITIONS OF THE VOCAL CORD
Position Distance of vocal cord from the midline Occur normally during Disease
Median Midline Speech Right laryngeal nerve paralysis
Paramedian 1.5 mm Whisper Right laryngeal nerve paralysis
Intermediate (Cadaveric) 3.5 mm Neutral position Paralysis of both recurrent and superior laryngeal nerves
Gentle abduction 7.0 mm Quiet respiration Paralysis of adductors
Full abduction 9.5 mm Deep inspiration -

 

The gentle abduction position of vocal cords is 9.5 mm from the midline.

  • Gentle abduction of vocal cords is the position of vocal cords when they lie at 7.0mm from the midline.
  • It occurs during quiet respiration in a healthy individual and due to paralysis of the vocal cord adductors.

Option A: All are incorrect

  • The median position of vocal cords is in the midline.
  • The paramedian position of vocal cords is 1.5 mm from the midline.
  • The cadaveric position of the vocal cords is 3.5 mm from the midline.
  • The gentle abduction position of vocal cords is 9.5mm from the midline.

Option B: Only 1, 2, and 3 are incorrect

  • The median position of vocal cords is in the midline
  • The paramedian position of vocal cords is 1.5mm from the midline.
  • The cadaveric position of vocal cords is 3.5mm from the midline.

Option C: Only 1 & 2 are incorrect

  • The median position of the vocal cords is in the midline.
  • The paramedian position of vocal cords is 1.5mm from the midline

questions.text:
Which of the following vaccines is/are contraindicated in pregnancy?
1. Rubella
2. Hepatitis-B
3. Diphtheria
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution: All live vaccines are contraindicated in pregnancy. Of the given options, only Rubella is a live vaccine.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with the chief complaints of asymptomatic loss of hair at multiple sites over the scalp for 2 months. Hair loss was annular in pattern as it was more obvious at the periphery compared with the center of the patch. There was no history of similar illness in family members and also no history of drug intake and trauma. On examination, there were multiple well-defined annular patches of non-scarring alopecia with short, easily extractable broken hairs at the margins of the bald patches. Your Probable diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
• Alopecia areata is an autoimmune disease that involves the hair follicle.
  • Alopecia areata affects all age groups and different ethnicities.
  • AA can occur on virtually any hair-bearing area.
  • It affects the scalp in approximately 90% of cases
  • The characteristic initial lesion of alopecia areata is a circumscribed, hairless, smooth patch. The skin within the bald patch appears normal or slightly reddened.
  • Short, easily extractable broken hairs, known as exclamation mark hairs, are often seen at the margins of the bald patches during active phases of the disease
  • Regrowth is often at first fine and non-pigmented, but usually, the hairs gradually resume their normal calibre and colour.
  • An intriguing feature of alopecia areata is the sparing of white hairs. In patients with grey hair, which is an admixture of

pigmented and non-pigmented hair, the disease process appears preferentially to affect pigmented hair, so that non-pigmented or white hair is spared.

  • Loss of Hair following a stress, infection etc – Telogen effluvium
  • Loss of hair after Chemotherapy – Anagen effluvium
  • Frontotemporal Recession – Androgeneticalopecia

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic because of a 2-day history of facial erythema and rash, which also appeared today over the trunk and extremities. These symptoms were preceded by 3 days of low-grade fever before the onset of the rash. She had previously been in good health. His immunization is not up to date. He has no family history of any medical problems. Vital signs show a temperature of 37.2 C, PR of 92/min, and BP of 115/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows discrete erythematous maculopapular rash involving the entire face, extending to the trunk and extremities with tender posterior auricular lymphadenopathy as shown in the image given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is unvaccinated against rubella. Rubella called the “German measles” or the “three-day measles.”Rubella is a viral infection characterized by a fever followed by an erythematous rash that begins on the face and spreads to the trunk and extremities. Rubella spreads when someone who is infected coughs or sneezes tiny germ-filled droplets into the air and onto surfaces. People who catch the virus are contagious for up to a week before and a week after the rash appears.

Physical examination typically shows a rash described as pink, coalescing macules that spread down to the trunk as a fine, desquamating rash. When acquired during pregnancy, the child may have congenital heart disease (patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary artery hypoplasia), cataracts, and deafness, thrombocytopenia, a rash described as a “blueberry muffin rash,” microcephaly, and hepatomegaly.

Protection against the rubella virus is made possible by the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine which is a live-attenuated vaccine given at 12 months of age and ages 4 to 6 years. This vaccine is also protective against mumps and measles.

Option A: Coxsackie A virus is a virus that causes hand-foot-mouth disease seen in young children. It causes painful red blisters in the throat and on the tongue, gums, hard palate, inside of the cheeks, and the palms of hands and soles of the feet.

Option B: Measles is caused by the Rubeola virus, which belongs to the Paramyxovirus family. It is characterized by an erythematous, maculopapular rash that starts on the neck and spreads down to the trunk, and is associated with Koplik spots (rash of the buccal mucosa) and conjunctivitis.

Option C: Parvovirus B19 infects only humans. It most commonly causes fifth disease, a mild rash illness that usually affects children. It is characterized by an erythematous, maculopapular rash on the cheeks, arms, trunk, and legs.

questions.text: A histopathology research fellow wants to study the different neurological diseases and their association with the protein defect or deposition. Which of the following neurological disease is associated with defective proteins?

choices.text: Alzheimer's disease is associated with α-synuclein
Parkinson’s disease is associated with androgen receptors
Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD) is associated with Kuru plaques
Spinal bulbar muscular atrophy (SBMA) is associated with Aβ plaques

questions.solution:
Option C: Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD) is associated with Kuru plaques

  • Kuru plaque is a pathognomonic feature in the brain of patients with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.
  • Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is the most common spongiform encephalopathy.
  • It is usually sporadic and rarely can arise due to exposure to prion-infected human tissue (e.g., human growth hormone or corneal transplant).
  • It presents as rapidly progressive dementia associated with ataxia (cerebellar involvement) and startle myoclonus.
  • Periodic sharp waves are seen on electroencephalography (EEG)
  • It results in death, usually in < 1 year.

Option A: Alzheimer's disease is associated with α-synuclein

  • Alzheimer's disease is associated with Aβ plaques.
  • Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia.
  • Morphological features include cerebral atrophy with narrowing of the gyri, widening of sulci, and dilation of the ventricles.
  • Neuritic plaques are extracellular core comprised of Aβ amyloid with entangled neuritic processes.
  • Aβ amyloid is derived from amyloid precursor protein (APP) which normally undergoes alpha cleavage; beta cleavage results in Aβ amyloid.
  • Neurofibrillary tangles are intracellular aggregates of fibres composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein.
  • Loss of cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option B: Parkinson’s disease is associated with androgen receptors

  • Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is associated with α-synuclein
  • Parkinson's disease is characterised by a degenerative loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra of the basal ganglia.
  • In Parkinson's disease, histology reveals loss of pigmented neurons in the substantia nigra and round, eosinophilic inclusions of an α-synuclein protein (Lewy bodies) in affected neurons.
  • Clinical features are tremors, rigidity, akinesia/bradykinesia, and postural instability.
  • Dementia is a common feature of late disease.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Spinal bulbar muscular atrophy (SBMA) is associated with Aβ plaques

  • Spinal bulbar muscular atrophy (SBMA) is associated with androgen receptors.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A brain biopsy is submitted to the histopathological department. The consultant pathologist ordered certain markers for this biopsy. The marker report turns out to be negative for glial fibrillary acidic protein. Which of the following tumour is GFAP negative?
questions.solution:
The tumor that is typically negative for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) is:

Option B. Medulloblastoma

Explanation: Medulloblastoma is a type of brain tumor that originates from the cerebellum and is composed of primitive neuroepithelial cells. Unlike many other brain tumors, medulloblastomas are generally negative for GFAP, as they arise from cells that are not glial in origin. GFAP is commonly used as an immunohistochemical marker to identify glial cells, and it is typically expressed in astrocytomas and ependymomas, which are tumors of glial origin.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Astrocytoma: Astrocytomas are positive for GFAP. GFAP is a marker for astrocytic differentiation, and it is typically expressed in astrocytomas.

Option C. Giant cell glioma: Giant cell gliomas, which are a subtype of glioblastoma, can show GFAP expression. While not all cells within the tumor may express GFAP, it is not typically negative in giant cell gliomas.

Option D. Ependymoma: Ependymomas are positive for GFAP. GFAP can be expressed in ependymal tumors, as these tumors often arise from ependymal cells lining the ventricles of the brain and central canal of the spinal cord.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy was brought to the ER because of a rash of small red spots that begin on his palms and soles. The rash often spreads to the arms, legs, and torso. 8 days ago he developed a headache, fever, and muscle pain, for which he took some herbal medicines. He said he recently hiked El toro with his elder cousin 2 weeks before but he is unsure if he was bitten by a tick. Physical examination shows a rash on his hands, feet, and trunk as shown in the image given below. Which of the following you think would be the diagnosis of this boy?
questions.solution:
RMSF is caused by Rickettsia rickettsii and is transmitted by Dermacentor ticks. It typically begins with a fever and headache, which is followed a few days later with the development of a rash. The rash is generally made up of small spots of bleeding and starts on the wrists and ankles. Other symptoms may include muscle pains and vomiting.

Option A: Rubella, also known as German measles or three-day measles, is an infection caused by the rubella virus. A rash may start around two weeks after exposure and last for three days. It usually starts on the face and spreads to the rest of the body. German measles is also associated with systemic symptoms including malaise, low-grade fever, and arthralgias. Patients may have lymphadenopathy, particularly in the postauricular area.

Option B: Lyme disease, also known as Lyme borreliosis, is an infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. The most common sign of infection is a ring of expanding red rash, known as erythema migrans, that appears at the site of the tick bite about a week after it occurred. Fever, headache, myalgias, and arthralgias may also be present.

Option C: Measles is a highly contagious infectious disease caused by the measles virus. Although the maculopapular rash of measles, , can include the palms and soles, it typically begins along the hairline in frontal and temporal regions and then spreads down the trunk to the limbs. Systemic symptoms include prodromal fever and malaise several days prior to rash eruption. Koplik’s spots on the buccal mucosa also typically precede the rash and are pathognomonic for measles

questions.text: Enteropeptidase (also called enterokinase) is an enzyme produced by cells of the duodenum and is involved in digestion in humans and other animals. Enterokinase is an activator of?
questions.solution:
Option A: Trypsinogen

  • Trypsin is secreted as inactive trypsinogen, which is converted into active trypsin by enterokinase.
  • Enterokinase present in intestinal juice activates trypsinogen into trypsin.
  • In turn, trypsin is an enzyme that aids with digestion. An enzyme is a protein that speeds up a specific biochemical reaction. Trypsin is found in the small intestine

Option B: Trypsin

  • Autocatalytic action: Once formed, trypsin itself converts trypsinogen into trypsin.
  • Trypsin is an enzyme that helps us digest protein.
  •  In the small intestine, trypsin breaks down proteins, continuing the digestion process in the stomach.
  •  It may also be referred to as a proteolytic enzyme or proteinase.

Option C: Chymotrypsin

  • It is secreted as inactive chymotrypsinogen, which is activated into chymotrypsin by trypsin.
  • Chymotrypsin is another serine protease produced by the pancreas that hydrolyses the peptide bonds of tryptophan, leucine, tyrosine, and phenylalanine.
  • The pancreas synthesizes two forms of chymotrypsin (1 and 2) as inactive chymotrypsinogens.

Option D: Antitrypsin

  • A substance that inhibits the action of trypsin
  • The Liver produces elastase inhibitors, especially α1 -antitrypsin, which prevent the destruction of elastic tissues.

questions.text: A 24-year-old-male was taken to the operating room for a lumbar disc hernia operation. At the 30th minute of the operation, tachycardia (120/min) was observed followed by bradycardia and cardiac arrest occurred at the 45th minute of the operation. After resuscitation, his fever was 39.5°C (103.1°F), then the fever rose to 40°C (104°F). CPK-MB level was high. The patient died on the seventh day after the operation and the cause of death was suspected to be malignant hyperthermia. All are seen in malignant hyperthermia except
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia never happens in malignant hyperthermia.

Clinical Manifestations of Malignant Hyperthermia:

Early Signs:

  • Elevated end-tidal carbon dioxide
  • Tachypnea and/or tachycardia
  • Masseter spasm, if succinylcholine has been used
  • Generalized muscle rigidity
  • Mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis
  • Profuse sweating
  • Mottling of skin
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Unstable blood pressure

Late Signs

  • Hyperkalemia
  • Rapid increase of core body temperature- body temperature rises by 10C every 5 minutes
  • Elevated creatine phosphokinase levels
  • Gross myoglobinemia and myoglobinuria
  • Cardiac arrest
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation

questions.text: The light brown perinuclear pigment seen on H & E staining of the cardiac muscle fibers in the grossly normal-appearing heart of an 83-year-old man at autopsy is due to deposition as:
questions.solution:
Regarding other options

  • Hemosiderin: It is a pigment deposited in condi­tions of excess iron.
  • Anthracotic pigment: It is pigment seen in the lung of coalworkers.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented to the physician's office with a complaint of whitish vaginal discharge. On vaginal examination, the findings were confirmed, and a pH test was 6. Which of the following conditions is the most likely the cause of the vaginal discharge?
questions.solution:
Option D: Gardnerella vaginitis

Bacterial vaginosis:

  • This disease is caused by the abnormal vaginal flora when the symbiotic relationship shifts for unknown reasons leading to the overgrowth of anaerobes, including Gardnerella vaginalis, Ureaplasma urealyticum, Mycoplasma hominis, and Mobiluncus species.
  • Risk factors associated with Bacterial vaginosis are oral sex, douching, black race, cigarette smoking, sex during menses, intrauterine device, early age of sexual intercourse, new or multiple sexual partners, and sexual activity with other women.
  • It is associated with a significant reduction or absence of normal hydrogen peroxide-producing Lactobacillus species.
  • The normal pH of the vagina is 3.8 to 4.5. A vaginal pH of 6 is alkaline, favouring other organisms' growth, leading to Trichomoniasis and Bacterial vaginosis. Further testing that supports the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis is clue cells with bacterial clumps on saline wet prep microscopic examination.
  • Bacterial vaginosis is more common. The patient presents with a complaint of thin, grey or white adherent discharge with a fishy odour, often increased after intercourse and menses. There is non-irritating, malodorous vaginal discharge without vaginal erythema.

Option A: Atrophic vaginitis

  • Also called Senile vaginitis. It occurs due to an estrogen deficiency.
  • The vaginal epithelium becomes thin and atrophic, the glycogen content and acidity of the vagina are lowered, and the ever-present mixed pathogen obtains a footing.
  • It occurs due to menopause, prolonged lactation or premature menopause in women who have undergone oophorectomy. As a result, there is an estrogen deficiency leading to atrophic vaginitis.
  • The patient presents with a dry vagina, dyspareunia and a purulent, often slightly blood-tinged discharge. The vagina is inflamed and tender, and the mucosa is excoriated. The urinary symptoms of frequency and dysuria are common.

Option B: Candidal vaginitis

  • Candida vaginitis occurs due to Candida albicans. Seen in warmer climates in obese patients with immunosuppression, diabetes mellitus, pregnancy and recent use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • The patients present with pruritis, pain, vulvar erythema and oedema with excoriations. The vaginal discharge is curdy or cottage cheese-like. There are yeast buds and hyphal forms on microscopic examination of vaginal discharge with saline and potassium hydroxide. The vaginal pH is < 4.5 as opposed to bacterial vaginosis, which occurs with a pH of > 4.5 (e.g. 6).

Option C: Doderlein's bacillus

  • The Doderlein's lactobacillus converts glycogen into lactic acid under estrogen. This makes the vaginal pH acidic (4-4.5).
  • ​​​​​​​It is not pathogenic.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented to the outpatient clinic with a mass in her right breast. Her medical history is unremarkable. Physical examination revealed a 2cm solid mass behind the nipple. An ultrasound revealed a high likelihood of malignancy. A biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of ductal carcinoma. Which of the following gene mutations is most frequently linked to inherited breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Option C: BRCA1 

  • BRCA 1 and BRCA 2 mutations cause 55% and 35% of familial breast cancer, respectively. 
  • The most common genetic mutation associated with single-gene familial breast cancer is BRCA 1. 
  • The majority of cancers associated with BRCA 1 and BRCA 2 mutations are TNBC and ER-positive, respectively. 
  • The BRCA 1 and BRCA 2 genes are involved in the repair of double-standard DNA breaks. 
  • Because of gene mutations, there is a risk of permanent DNA damage, which could lead to oncogenic mutations. 
  • BRCA gene mutations are linked to breast cancer for the following reasons. 
    • Breast and ovarian cells are vulnerable to the type of genetic mutations repaired by BRCA genes. 
    • Interaction with complex proteins and its role in transcription
    • BRCA genes also function as tumour suppressors, and their mutation can result in carcinoma development. 
  • The majority of BRCA 1 and BRCA 2 carriers develop breast cancer by age 70. 
  • The mutations of BRCA 1 and BRCA 2 are distributed widely in the chromosome. 
  • Due to the complexities, genetic testing is only available to people with a strong family history. (Ashkenazi Jewish Population)
  • Identifying carriers is becoming increasingly important in reducing the overall disease burden.
  • Other genes that are associated with breast carcinoma are 
    • TP53
    • PTEN
    • STK1
    • CDH1
    • ATM
    • CHEK2

Option A: CHEK 2

  • It only accounts for 5% of familial breast cancers. 
  • Because of the moderate penetration raises the risk by 2 to 4 times. 
  • This gene is also involved in the repair of double-stranded DNA breaks. 
  • The majority of CHECK2 mutation-associated carcinomas are also ER positive. 

Option B: GATA2

  • GATA2 mutations are associated with the following syndromes 
    • MonoMAC syndrome (Monocytopenia and non-tuberculous mycobacterial infection)
    • Dendritic cell, monocyte, B and NK lymphoid (DCML) deficiency (Increases the risk of viral infections)
    • Familial myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS/AML)
    • Emberger syndrome (primary lymphedema, warts, increased risk of MDS/AML)

Option D: TP53

  • The TP53 gene mutation is responsible for less than 1% of familial breast carcinoma. 
  • Other carcinomas associated with TP53 mutation are 
    • Sarcoma 
    • Leukaemia 
    • Brain Tumours 
  • Breast cancer caused by Tp53 mutation is mostly ER and HER2 positive.

questions.text: There is a stab wound at the fifth intercostal space along the midclavicluar line. The victim is conscious but in distress. Which structure is most likely be punctured?
questions.solution:
Lungs occupy most of the volume in the thoracic cavity. The apex of the lungs extends into the neck just above the first rib. The lung bases are in direct contact with the diaphragm. The diaphragm separates the right lung from the liver and the left lung from the left lobe of the liver, the stomach and the spleen. The anterior surface of the heart is partially covered by the lungs and is located behind the sternum. Left ventricle forms the apex and is covered by the left lung. It lies behind the fifth left intercostal space at the left midclavicular line. The right ventricle forms the anterior surface of the heart. The inferior surface is formed by the right and left ventricles. The posterior surface is mainly formed by the left atrium.

Penetrating injury to the chest wall (fifth intercostal space) at left midclavicular line would most likely injure the left lung. At the same location, much more deeper penetrating injury would injure the apex of the heart.

Choice A- right ventricle is medial to the left mid clavicular line. It forms the anterior surface of the heart and majority of the right ventricle forms the inferior surface as well.

Choice C- left atrium forms the base of the heart and is located posterior to the left ventricle

Choice D- inferior vena cava lies to the right of the midline.

questions.text: Panhypopituitarism in adults may lead to all of the following, except?
questions.solution:
Option B: Pigmentation of the skin

  • Pigmentation is due to the effect of MSH secreted by the pituitary.
  • Panhypopituitarism in adults leads to:
    • Hypothyroidism causes intolerance to cold
    • Depressed production of glucocorticoids by adrenal glands.
    • Loss of sexual functions due to suppressed secretions of the gonadotropic hormones
  • In panhypopituitarism, levels of MSH decrease, thus no pigmentation of the skin.

 

 

Option A: Loss of secondary sexual characteristic

  • MSH level is low in panhypopituitarism; therefore, no skin pigmentation is seen.
  • Hypothyroidism causes intolerance to cold.
  • Depressed production of glucocorticoids by adrenal glands.
  • Loss of sexual functions due to suppressed secretions of the gonadotropic hormones

 

Option C: Intolerance to cold

  • MSH level is low in panhypopituitarism; therefore, no skin pigmentation is seen.
  • Hypothyroidism causes intolerance to cold.
  • Depressed production of glucocorticoids by adrenal glands.
  • Loss of sexual functions due to suppressed secretions of the gonadotropic hormones

 

Option D: Infertility

  • MSH level is low in panhypopituitarism; therefore, no skin pigmentation is seen.
  • Hypothyroidism causes intolerance to cold.
  • Depressed production of glucocorticoids by adrenal glands.
  • Loss of sexual functions due to suppressed secretions of the gonadotropic hormones

questions.text: A gynecological surgeon is performing a hysterectomy for a case of endometriosis with pelvic adhesions. On opening the abdomen, there are multiple adhesions obscuring pelvic anatomy. Which of the following is an INCORRECT statement regarding normal pelvic anatomy?

choices.text: Ureter lies beneath the uterine artery
Mucosa of fallopian tube is lined by ciliated cells
Pouch of douglas lies between the bladder and the uterus
AExternal iliac artery lies superior to ovarian fossa

questions.solution:
• Ureter lies beneath the uterine artery (Water under the bridge)
  • The mucosa of the fallopian tube is lined by ciliated cells
  • The pouch of Douglas is posterior to the uterus lying between the rectum and the uterus.

- Ovarian fossa is bound superiorly by external iliac artery and vein, anteriorly by broad ligament, posteriorly by ureter, internal iliac artery and vein, inferiorly by obturator nerve and vessels

questions.text: Two-point discrimination test exhibits maximum sensitivity in which of the following areas?
questions.solution:
Option C: Finger pads

  • Almost all sensory pathways produce lateral inhibitory signals when they get excited; these inhibitory signals extend to the sides of the excitatory signal and inhibit nearby neurons. Take an activated neuron in the dorsal column nucleus as an example. In addition to the core excitatory signal, nearby neurons also receive inhibitory messages through short lateral channels carried by extra interneurons that produce inhibitory transmitters.
  • The reason lateral inhibition is significant is that it prevents the lateral spread of excitatory impulses, which raises the level of contrast in the sensory pattern that is received by the cerebral cortex.
  • Lateral inhibitory signals are present in the dorsal column system at every synaptic level, including 
  1. The dorsal column nuclei of the medulla
  2. The ventrobasal nuclei of the thalamus
  3. The cortex  
  • Each of these levels has lateral inhibition working to prevent the excitatory signal's lateral propagation. As a result, the excitation peaks are more noticeable, and most of the diffuse stimulation around them is inhibited.
  • Two-point discrimination is the ability to discern that two nearby objects touching the skin are truly two distinct points, not one. It is often tested with two sharp points during a neurological examination and is assumed to reflect how finely innervated an area of skin is.
  • The maximum sensitivity for this test is in the lips and fingertips, which can be remembered as the body's most sensitive areas.

Option A: Back of the body

  • A technique known as tactile discrimination testing is widely utilized to assess a person's so-called "two-point" discriminating ability. During this test, two needles are softly pushed against the skin simultaneously, and the subject decides whether they feel one stimulation point or two, respectively. Even when the needles are 1 to 2 millimeters apart on the tips of the fingers, a person can often discern two distinct points. On the back of the person, however, two distinct locations often need to be identified at a distance of 30 to 70 millimeters. This distinction is brought about by the varying densities of specific touch receptors in the two regions.
  • Therefore, the skin of the back does not have the maximum sensitivity for two-point discrimination.

Option B: Knee

  • The body's ability to move and operate depends on the feeling of proprioception.
  • This sense makes it possible to know how your body moves and where it is in space.
  • This sensation is typically brought on by tissues pressing on proprioceptor cells with pressure or tension.
  • Proprioception is normally distributed evenly across the body's joints, but the knee has the highest concentration of proprioceptors. It is due to the intricate nature of the knee, which is also the biggest joint in the body. The combination of various bones and muscles is responsible for moving and stabilising the knee, although it is a hinge joint that only moves in one plane.
  • The knee joint does not have maximum two-point discrimination.

Option D: Elbow

  • The bony prominences of the sternum, elbow, and ankle are often used in tuning fork tests to check the body's vibration sense.
  • Vibration is perceived by two types of mechanoreceptors: Meissner corpuscles and Pacinian corpuscles.
  • Meissner's Corpuscles are large myelinated fibres that detect low-frequency vibration and are found in glabrous (smooth, hairless) skin on fingertips and eyelids.
  • Pacinian Corpuscles are large myelinated A-beta fibres that detect high-frequency vibration and deep pressure and are found in deeper layers of skin, ligaments, and joints.

questions.text: The mean of the eight plasma volumes  is 3.00 litres and the standard deviation is 0.41 litres . The standard error of the mean is therefore estimated as:
questions.solution:
Standard error = Standard deviation (SD)/ Square root of sample size

In the given question, n = 8, Standard deviation (s) = 0.41, Mean (μ) =3.00 litres,

Thus, standard error = = 0.14

 SE mean is the measure of difference between sample and population values. The standard error measures the amount of variability in the sample mean; it indicates how closely the population mean is likely to be estimated by the sample mean. The standard deviation measures the amount of variability in the population.

Sampling distribution gives us the spread of values we would get if we took a large number of additional samples; this spread depends on the amount of variation in the underlying population and on our sample size. The standard deviation of the sampling distribution is called the standard error and is equal to the standard deviation of the population, divided by the square root of n. This means that approximately 95% of the values in this theoretical sampling distribution of sample means lie within two standard errors of the population mean. This fact can be used to construct a range of likely values for the (unknown) population mean, based on the observed sample mean and its standard error. Such a range is called a confidence interval.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with a 2.5-cm mass in the anterior triangle of the left neck. The mass moves with swallowing and has slowly enlarged over the past 1–2 years. The patient’s past medical history is notable for high-dose irradiation to the chest and abdomen for Hodgkin’s lymphoma 8 years prior to presentation. Thy-roid scan shows a “cold” lesion. Fine-needle aspiration cytology is “suspicious.” Core-needle biopsy shows features suggestive of a fol-licular neoplasm. True statements regarding this patient’s condition include

choices.text: Prior radiation to the chest, if any-thing, would diminish the risk of subsequent thyroid cancer
In the setting of abnormal cytology, an initial course of TSH suppres-sion by thyroid hormone is recom-mended
In the setting of a possible follicular   neoplasm, radioactive iodine (131I) ablation is recommended
Total thyroidectomy is an accept-able treatment for this patient

questions.solution: Thyroid nodules are somewhat less common in men and should always suggest malignancy. The history of irradiation to the chest and the findings on biopsy mandate resection of the lesion in this patient, since prior exposure to radiation, even at low dosage, is a strong risk factor for the subsequent development of thyroid cancer. The optimum management of thyroid carcinoma remains controversial. Thyroid lobectomy, subtotal thyroidectomy, and total thyroidectomy are all acceptable techniques for treatment. Removal of the gland permits more accurate histologic diagnosis, particularly with regard to the relatively radioresistant Hürthle-cell follicular variant. Removal of the gland also makes subsequent treatment of metastases with radioactive iodine more effective. Suppression with thyroid hormone  in the setting of abnormal cytology is not recommended

questions.solution: While it is recommended to keep LDL levels below 100 mg/dl, LDL cholesterol level are autoregulated in body, with dietary modification playing only a minor role. Other modifications are recommended to lower the risk.

questions.text:
Urine flow rate = 1 ml/min
Urine inulin concentration = 100 mg/ml
Plasma inulin concentration = 2 mg/ml
Urine urea concentration = 50 mg/ml
Plasma urea concentration = 2.5 mg/ml

What is the net urea reabsorption rate?
questions.solution:
The net urea reabsorption rate is equal to the filtered load of urea (GFR [50 ml/min] × plasma urea concentration [2.5 mg/ml]) − urinary excretion rate of urea (urine urea concentration [50 mg/ml] × urine flow rate [1 ml/min]). Therefore, net urea reabsorption

= (50 ml/min × 2.5 mg/ml) − (50 mg/ml × 1 ml/ min) = 75 mg/min.

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following enzymes does not cause hyperuricemia?
questions.solution:
Option C: Adenosine deaminase

  • The deficiency of ADA stops the first reaction of purine catabolism. Adenosine cannot be converted to inosine, so, no uric acid is synthesized. Thus, leading to hypouricemia.

Option A: Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRT)

  • HGPRT is responsible for converting hypoxanthine and guanine to IMP and GMP, respectively.
  • The deficiency of HGPRT leads to the accumulation of hypoxanthine and guanine.
  • Excess hypoxanthine and guanine are diverted towards the degradative pathway forming uric acid and leading to hyperuricemia.
  • The deficiency of HGPRT causes Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

Option B: Aldolase B

  • Aldolase B catalyzes the conversion of fructose-1-phosphate to glyceraldehyde and dihydroxyacetone phosphate in fructose metabolism.
  • The deficiency of aldolase B causes hereditary fructose intolerance.
  • Hyperuricemia is a common finding in patients with a deficiency of aldolase B because of increased turnover and breakdown of adenosine.

Option D: Glucose-6-phosphatase

  • Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency causes von Gierke’s disease.
  • In von Gierke's disease, hyperuricemia occurs due to overproduction and reduced renal clearance of uric acid.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the doctor with complaints of irregular cycles for a few months. Her cycles are 35-45 days long, lasting for 3 to 4 days with mild to moderate blood flow. There is, however, no passage of clots and no dysmenorrhea. Which of the following accurately describes this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Oligomenorrhea

  • Oligomenorrhea is the medical term for having infrequent menstrual periods. A normal menstrual cycle occurs every 28 days and lasts from four to seven days. The period can range from every 21 days to every 35 days and still be considered normal.
  • However, in oligomenorrhea, periods are unpredictable. There may be intervals of more than 35 days without a period. Instead of having periods monthly, menstrual cycles can range from six to eight periods a year.
  • Following are the frequent abnormalities in the menstrual cycle.
    • Oligomenorrhea → Infrequent and irregularly timed bleeding episodes usually occur at intervals of more than 35 days.
    • Polymenorrhea → Frequent episodes of menstruation usually occur at intervals of 21 days or less.
    • Menorrhagia → Enhanced menstrual flow or increased duration at regular menstrual cycles.
    • Hypomenorrhoea → Decreased bleeding and shorter days of bleeding.
    • Metrorrhagia → Irregular bleeding in between the cycles
    • Menometrorrhagia → Enhanced menstrual flow as well as irregular bleeding between the cycles

Option A:  Amenorrhoea

  • It is a false option.
  • Amenorrhea refers to absent periods.

Option C:  Polymenorrhea

  • It is a false option.
  • It means frequent episodes of menstruation, usually occurring at intervals of less than 21 days

Option D: Menorrhagia

  • It is a false option.
  • It means Increased menstrual flow/Increased duration at regular cycles.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not a part of the auditory pathway?
questions.solution:
Option A: Medial lemniscus

  • Electrical signals generated by the inner hair cells in the organ of Corti are conveyed to the medulla's dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei.
  • From cochlear nuclei, they reach the superior olivary nucleus of the pons and then to the inferior colliculus in the midbrain via the lateral lemniscus (the medial lemniscus is not involved).
  • After other relays, the pathway leads to the medial geniculate bodies of the thalamus.
  • Thalamus then sends projections to the auditory cortex.

Option B: Lateral lemniscus

  • The second-order neurons run in the lateral lemniscus from the superior olivary nucleus to the inferior colliculus.
  • Hence, it is a part of the auditory pathway.

Option C: Inferior colliculus

  • Inferior colliculi accept signals from superior olivary nuclei via the lateral lemniscus.
  • They then send signals to the medial geniculate body.

Option D: Medial geniculate body

  • The medial geniculate body receives fibers from inferior colliculi.
  • It then sends fibers further to the auditory cortex.

questions.text:
Physical Quality of Life Index consists of:

Per capita GNP                
Life expectancy at age one             
Infant mortality rate             
Literacy

Of these components:
questions.solution: Various attempts have been made to reach one composite index from a number of health indicators. The “Physical quality of life index” is one such index. It consolidates three indicators, viz. infant mortality, life expectancy at age one, and literacy.

questions.text: A patient of age 55 presented with the complaint of watery eyes, sensitivity to light and pain in the eyes. Later on, he is diagnosed with corneal dystrophy. Which of the following statements are true about macular  corneal dystrophy?

choices.text: Abnormal stromal deposits of mucopolysaccharides which stain positive with Alcian blue
Opacities are present throughout the cornea, with clear spaces in between

questions.solution:
Macular corneal dystrophy is a rare genetic disorder that affects the cornea of the eye. Let's review the statements:

Option A. Autosomal dominant inheritance - Incorrect. Macular corneal dystrophy is typically inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, which means that two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) are needed for the disease to manifest.

Option B. Laser therapy can be done - Correct. Laser therapy, specifically phototherapeutic keratectomy (PTK), can be used to treat some of the symptoms associated with macular corneal dystrophy, such as reducing the corneal opacities and improving vision.

Option C. Abnormal stromal deposits of mucopolysaccharides which stain positive with Alcian blue - Incorrect. Macular corneal dystrophy is characterized by the abnormal accumulation of mucopolysaccharides in the corneal stroma. These deposits typically stain negative with Alcian blue.

Option D. Opacities are present throughout the cornea, with clear spaces in between - Incorrect. In macular corneal dystrophy, the corneal opacities are typically not evenly distributed throughout the cornea with clear spaces in between. Instead, there is a progressive accumulation of opacities, primarily in the central and mid-peripheral cornea, leading to visual impairment.
